confession of the lover maad and compyled by Johan Gower squire borne in walys

to Genyus priest of venus upon the causes of love in his five wits and suum
dedely synues / as in this said book al alonge appyereth / and by cause there
been comprysed therein diverse hystories and fables towchyng every matere / I
have ordained a table here following of al such hystoryes and fables where and
in what book and leef they stand in as here after follows

tOrpor hebes seusus scola perua labor minimusque / Causant quo minimus ipse
minora canam / Qua tum eugisti lingua canit insula bruti / Anglica carmente

Hic in principio libri declarat qualiter in Anno Regis Ricardi Secundi
Sextodecimo Johannes Gower presentem litellum conposuit et finaliter compleuit
/ quem streunuissimo domino suo. Domino Henrico De Lancastria tunc Derbie
Comiti cum omni reuerencia sp ^^ialiter destinauit /

oF hem that written us to fore / The books duesbe and we therefore Ben taught
of yt was written thoo For thy good is that we also / In our time among us here.
Do write of new sum matter

Ensampled of the old wise
So that it might in such a wise
When we be deed and else where
Believe to the worlds ere
In time comend after this
But for men seyn and s^the it is
That who that al of wysedom write
It dulleth often a man's wit
To him that shall it al^ay read
For thylke cause if that ye read
I wol goo the myddel wey
And write a book between the twey
Somewhat of lust / and somewhat of lore
That of the less or of the more
So^me man may like of that I write
And for that few men en dyte
In our en glysshe for to make
A book for englondes sake
The year xvj of king Richard
What shall byfalle here afterward
God wot / for now upon this tide
Man see the world on every side
In sundry wise so dyuersed
That it well nygh stant al reuersed
Als for to speak of time a goo
The cause why it changes so
It needs naught to specyfye
The thing so open is at the ^ye
That every man it may behold
And netheles by days old
When that the books weren lever
Writing was byloued ever
Of hem that weren virtuous
For here in earth among us
I^ noman write how it stood
^he prys of hem that were good
Should as who says a great party
Be lost so for to magnyfye
The worthy princes that tho were
The books shown here and there
Whereof the world ensampled is
And tho that dyden then ne amys
Though tyranny and cruelte
Right us they stonden in degree
So wa^ the writing of the werk
Thus I which am a borell clerk
Purpose for to write a book
After the world that whylome took
Long time in old days passyd
But for men seyn it is now lassed
In wers plyght than it was tho
^ thenke for to touch also
The world which neweth every day
So as I can / so as I may
Though I sickness have upon hond
And long have had yet wol I fond
To write and do my business
That in some party so as I guess
The wise man may be aduysed
For this prologue is so assised
That it to wisdom al bylongeth
That wise man that it vnderfongeth
He shall draw in to remembrance
The fortune of the worlds chance
The which noman in his person
May know but the god allone
When the prologue is so dispended
The book shall afterward be ended
Of love which does many a wondre
And many a wise man has put under
And in this wise I thenke trele
Toward them that now be great
Between the virtue and the vice
Which longs unto this office
But for my wits ben to small
To tell every mannys tale
This book upon amendment
To stond at his commandment
With whom mine heart is of acorde
I send unto mine own lord
Which of lancastre is henry named
The high god has him proclaimed
Full of knyghthode and al grace
So would I now this werk embrace
With hoole trust and hoole believe
God grant I mote it well acheue

i Shall draw in to my mind* The time passed than I find / The world stood
in all his welthe Tho was the life of man in health / To was plente tho was Ry
chesse / Tho was fortune tho was prowess / Tho was knyghthode in prys by name
/ Whereof ye wide worlds fame Write in Chronicles is yet withhold Justice of
law tho was hold

The pryuelege of Regalye
Was fast / and all the Baronye
Worshipped was in his astate*
The Cytees knew no debate
The people stood in obeysaunce
Under the reule of governance
And pees with rightwysenesse keste
With charity tho stood in rest
Of mannys heart the courage
Was showed then in the vysage
The word was lyche to the conceyte
Wtthout semblaunt of deceyte
Tho was there vnenuyed love
Tho was virtue set above
And vice was put under foot
Now stant the crop under the rote
The world is changed oueral
And thereof most in specyal
That love is fall in to discord
And that I take in to record
Of every* land for his party
The common voys* which may not lie
Naught upon one but upon all
Is that men now clepe and call
And seyne that regnes ben divided
Instead of love is hate guyded
The werre wol no pees purchase
And law has take her double face
So that Justice out of the way
With ryghtwysenes is gone awey
And thus to look on every halue
Men seen the soore without salve
Which all the world has overtake
There is no reygne of al out take
For every clymat has his dyele
After the tornynge of the whele
Which blyude fortune overthrows
Whereof the certain noman knows
The heuene wot what is to done
But we that duelle under the moon
Stond in this world upon a were
And namely but the power
Of hem that been the worlds guydes
With good counseylle on every sides
Ben kept upright in such a wise
That hate break naught thassise
Of love which is all the chyef
To keep a reygne out of meschyef
For all reason would this
That unto him which the heued is
The members buxom shall bo we
And he should eke her troth allow
With all his heart and make hem chere
For good counseyl is good to here
Al though a man be wise him selue
Yet is the wysedom more of tivelue
And if they stand both in one
To both it were then anon
That god his grace would send
To make of thylk werre an end
Which every day now grows new
And that is gretely for to rewe
In specyal for cristes sake
Which would his own life forsake
Among the men to yeuen pees
But now men tellen netheles
That love is from the world departed
So stant the pees vneuene parted
With hem that lyuen now a days
But for to look at al assayes
To him that would reason seche
After the common worlds speech
It is to wonder of thylk werre
In which none wot who has yt werre
For land him self deceyueth
And of dysese his part receives
And yet take men no keep
But thylk lord which al may keep
To whom no counseyl may be hyd
Upon the world which is be tyd
Amend that whereof men pleynen
With true hertes and with pleyne
And reconsyle love ayene
As he which is king sovereign
Of all the worlds governance
And of his high purucaunce
Afferme pees between the lands /
And take here cause in to his hondes
So that the world may stand appesed
And his godbeede also be plesed

d Estatu cleri vt dicunt secundum spiritualia / videlicet tempore To ^^th

O thynk upon the days old
The life of clerkys to be hold.
Men seyn how yt they were tho
Ensample and (...) wle of al tho
Which of wysedom the virtue souten
Unto the god first they bysoughten
As to the substance of here scole
That they ne should not be fool
Her wit upon none erthly works
Which were ayene the astate of clerkis
And yt they myghten flee the vice
Which Simon has in his office
Wrerof he takyth gold in hand
For thyke time I understood
The lumbard made none exchange
The bisshopryches for to change
Ne yet a letter for to send
For dignyte ne for prouende
Or curyd / or without cure
The church kay in adventure
Of arms and of brigantaylle
Stood no thing then upon bataylle
To fight or for to make cheste
Yet thought hem then not honest
But of symplycyte and pacyence
They maden then no defense
The court of worldly regaille
To hem was then no bataylle
The vein honor is naught desired
Which has the proud heart fyred
The humylyte was tho withholde /
And pride was a vice hold
Of holy church the largess /
Yafe then and did great alms
The pour men that had need
They were eke chaste in word and deed
Whereof the people ensample took
Her lust was al upon the book
Or for to preche or for to pray
To wise men the right way
Of such as stood the troth vnlered
Lo thus is petrus barge stered
Of hem that ylke time were
And thus came first to mannys ere
The feyth of christ and al good
Through hem that then ware good
And sobre and chaste large and wise
And now men seyn is other wise
Simon the cause has under take
The worlds swerd in hond is take
And that is wonder netheles
When crist him self has bode pees
And set it in his testament
How now that holy church is went
Of that her law posyzyf
Has set to make werre and stryf
For wordly goods which may not
last / God wot the cause to the last
Of every right and wrong also
But while the law is rewlyd so
That clerks to the werre intend /
I not how that they shall amend
The woeful world in other things /
To make pees between kings
After the law of charity
Which is the propre dewte /
Belonged unto the preesthode
But as it thinks to make manhood*
The heaven is for the world is nyghe
And vain glory is eke to sleygh
Which couetyse has now withhold
That they none other thing behold
But only that they myghten win
And thus the werres they begin
Whereof the holy church is taxed
That in the point as it is axed
The dysme goth to the bataylle
As though crist might not avail
To do hem right by other way
In to the swerd the church kaye
Is turned and the holy bid
In to cursyng and every stead
Which should stand upon the feyth
And to this cause an ere leyth
Astonyd is of the quarrel /
That should be the worlds heel
Is now men sayn the pestyle nce
Which has expellyd pacyence
Fro the clerge in specyal
And that is showed oueral /
In every thing when they be greuyd
But if gregory be believed
As it is in the books write
He does us somdele to wete
The cause of thylke Prelacye
Where god is naught of company
For every work as it is foundyd
Shall stand / or else be confoundid
Who that only for cristes sake
Desires care for to take
And naught for pride of thylk astate
To bear a name of a prelate
He shall by reason do proufyte
In holy church upon the plyte
That he has set his conscience
But in the worlds reverence
There be of such many glad
When they to sylke astate be made /
Naught for the merit of the charge
But for they would hem self discharge
Of pouerte and become great /
And for pomp and for beyete
The scry^e and eke the pharysee
Of moses upon the sea
In the chair on high ben set
Whereof the feyth is often let
Which is bytake hem to keep
In crystes*cause al day they sleep
But of the world is naught foryete
For well is him that now may get
Office in court to be honouryd
The strong Coffre has al deuouryd
Under the kaye of auaryce
The tresour of the benefyce
Whereof the pour shulne clothe
And* ete and drink and house both
The charity goth al unknow
For they no greyne of pity know
And slouthe kepyth the lybrarye
Which longs to the sayntuarye
To study upon the worlds lore
Suffisith no^ght without more
Delycacye his sweet tothe
Has it suffryd / so that it fordoth
Of abstynence all that there is
And for to loken over this
If ethna brenne in the clergy
Al openly to the man's eye
At Auynyon they peryence
Thereof has youen an euydence
Of that men seyn hem so divided
And yet the cause is naught decyded /
But it is said and ever shall
Between two stoles lyth the fall
When that men wenen best to sytte
In holy church of such a flytte
Is for to rewe unto us all
God grant it mote well byfalle
Toward him which has ye troth
But often is seen that mochel sloth
When men ben drink of the cup
Does much harm wha^ ye fire is up
But if somwho the flamme stau^che
And so to speak upon this brau^che
Which proud envy has made to spring
Of scysme causes for to bring
This new sect of lollardye
And also many an heresye
Among the clerks in hem selue
It were better dyke and delue
And stand upon the right feyth
Than know al yt the bible says
And err as some clerks do
Upon an hond to were a sho
And set upon the foot a glove
Acordeth not to the behoue
Of reasonable man's use
If men bebelden the vertuse
That crist in earth taught hyere
They should not in such manner
Among hem that be hold wise
The papacye so desguyse /
Upon diverse electyon
Which stant after thaffection /
Of sendry lands al about
But when god wol it shall weve out
F^^ truth mote stand at last
But yet they argumenten fast
Upon the pope and his astate
Whereof they fallen in great debate
This cl^rk said ye / that other nay
And this ^^ey drive forth the day
And each of hem him self amendeth
^^ worlds good but none entendeth
To if at which common proufyte were
They seyen that god is mighty there
And shall ordeyne what he will
There make they none other skylle
Where is the peril of the feyth /
But every clerk his heart leyth
To keep his world in specyal
And of the cause general
Which unto holy church longs
Is none of hem that vnderfongeth
To shapen any resystence /
And thus the right has no defense /
But there I love there I hold
^o thus to broke is Cristes fold
Whereof the flok without guide
Devoured is on every side
In lak of hem that be vnwar
Shepeherdes which her wits beware
Upon the world in other halue
The sharp pryk instead of salve
They vsen now / whereof the hele
They hurt of that they should hele
What sheep that is full of wulle
Upon his bak they tose and pulle
While there is any thing to pylle
And though there be none other skylle
But only for they would win
They leave naught when they begin
Upon her act to proceed
Which is no good shepeherdes deed
And upon this also men seyn
That fro the lose / which is pleyn
In to the breres they forcatche
Here of for that they wolden lache
With such duresse and so bereue
That shall upon the thorns leave
Of wolle which the brere has tore
Whereof the sheep ben al to tore
Of that the herdes make hem lose
^o how they feynen chalk for chese
For though they speak and teache well
They done ^em self / thereof no dele
For if the wolf come in the wey
Here goostly staf is then aweye
Whereof they should here flok defend
But if the pour sheep offend
In any thing though it be lyte
They ben al*redy for to smite
And thus how ever that they tale
The strokes fall upon the small
And upon other that been great
Hem lacks heart for to beat
So that under the clerks law
Men seen the merel al mysdrawe
I wol not say in general
For there be sum in specyal
In whom that al virtue duelleth
And tho ben as thappostel tells
Qiu vocatur a deo tanquam Aaron
That god of his electyon
Has cleped to perfectyon
In the manner as Aawn was
They be nothing in thylk caas
Of Simon which the foldes gate
Has let and goth in other gate
But they gone in the right weye
There ben also sum as men say
That folowen Simon at heles
Whose carte goth upon wheles
Of couetyse and worlds pride
And holy church goth beside
Which she weth out ward a vysage
Of that is naught in the courage
For if men look in holy church
Bitwene the word and that they werche
There is a full great difference
They prechen us in audyence
That noman shall his soul empeyre
For all is but a chery feyre
This worlds good so as they tell
Also they fayen there is an hell
Which unto mannys sin is due
And bydden us therefore eschew
That wykked is / and do the good
Who that here words understood
It thenketh they would do the same
But yet between ernest and game
Full oftyme it turned other wise
With holy tales they deuyse
How merytory is thylke deed
Of charity to clothe and feed
The pour folk and for to part
The worlds good / but they depart
No thing naught / for that they have
Also they feyn good is to save
With penance and with abstynence
Of chastyte the contynence
But pleynly for to speak of that
I not how that ylke body fat
Which with that deynte metes keep
And leyen it soft for to sleep
When it has else al his will
With chastyte shall stand stylle
And netheles I can not say
In aunter that I myssay
Touchend of this*how ever it stand
I here and will naught understand
For thereof have I naught to done
But he that made first the moon
The high god of his goodness
If there be cause he it redress
But what as any man can accuse
This may reason of truth excuse
The vice of hem that been vngood
Is no repreef to the good
For every man his own works
Shall bear / and thus as of the clerks
The good men ben to commend
And al these other god amend
For they be to the worlds eye
The myrrour of examplarye
To reulen and taken head
Bet wene the men and the godbede

nOw for to speak of yt comune
It is to dread of that fortune
which has bifalle in so^dry lo^ des /
But often for defaute of bonds
Al sodenlyche or it be wist
A tonue when his lie aryst
To breken and run al about
Which endless should naught gone out
And eke full often a little skare
Upon a bank or men be ware
^ete in ye streme which with great peyn^
If every man it shall restreyne
where law faylleth / error grows
He is not wise who that ne troweth
For it has proved often er this
And thus the common clamor is
In every land where people duelleth
And each in his compleynt tells
How that the world is myswent
And thereupon his Judgment
Yeueth every man in sundry wise
But what man would him self auyse
His conseyence and naught mysuse
He may well at the first excuse
His god which ever stant in one
In him there is defaute none
So must it stand upon us ^elue
Naught only upon ten ne twelve
But plenerlyche upon us all
For men is cause that shall byfalle

Mine ho^d and set al in euene /

So great things to compass
But I mote let it over pass
And treten upon other things
For thy the style of my wrytynges
Fro this day forth I thenke change
And speak of thing is not so strange
Which every kind has upon hand
And thereupon the world mote stand
And has done sith it began
And shall while there is any man
And that is love of which I mean
To trete as after shall be seen
In which there can noman him reule
For laws love is out of reule
That of to much or of to lyte
Well nyghe is every man to wit
And netheles there is no man

Which wol no reason understand
For love is blind and may not see

Upon the point that is byfalle
Of love in which yt j am fall
I think tell my matere
Now herkne who that wol it here
Of my fortune how it has ferde
This endyrday as j forth ferde
To walk as you tell may
And that was in the month of may
When every ^ryd has chose his make
And the^keth his myrthes for to make
Of love that he has acheued
But so was I nothing releued
For I was forther fro my love
Than earth is from the heuene above
And for to speak of any speed
So wist I me none other read
But as it were a man for fare
unto the wode I began to fare
Not for to sing with the birds
For when j was ye wode amyddes
I fond a soote grene pleyne
And I began my woe there complain
Wysshyng and weeping al mine one
For other myrthes made I none
So hard me was that ylke throw
That often sythes overthrow
To ground I was without breath
And ever I wysshed after death
When I out of my pain awoke
And cast up many a pytous look
Unto the heuene and said thus
O thou cupyde / O thou venus
Thou god of love and thou goddess
Where is pity where is meekness
Now does me plainly live or dye
For certes such a maladye
As I now have and long have had
It might make a wise man mad
If that it should long endure
O venus queen of loves cure
Thou life thou lust thou man's hele
Behold my cause and my quarelle
And give me sompart of thy grace
So that I may find in this place
If thou be gracious or none
And with that word I saw anon
The king of love and the queen both
But he that king with eyes wroth
His chere aweyward fro me cast
And forth he passed at the last
But netheles or he forth went
A fyry dart me thought he sent
And threw it thorugh mine heart rote
In him fond I none other bote
For benger him list no^ to duelle
But she which is the source and well
Of well and woe that shall betyde
To hem that louen at that tide
Abode for to allen here
She cast on me uoo goodly chere
Thus netheles to me she said
What art thou sone and I abrayde
Right as a man does out of sleep
And thereof she took right good keep
And bad me^nothyng be adrad
But for all that I was nothing glad
For I ne saw no cause why
And efte she axed what was I
I said a Caytyf that lies here
What would ye my lady dear
Shall I be hool or else deye
She said tell thy maladye
What is thy soore of which thou pley nest /
Ne hyde it nout for if thou feynest /
I can do the no medycyne
Madame I am a man of thine
That in thy court have long served
And ask that I have deserved
Some well after my long woe
And she bygan to loure thoo
And said there be many of you
Faytours and so may be that thou
Art right such one and by feyntyse
Seyst that thou have me do seruyse
And netheles she wist well
My word stood on an other whele
Without any feyterye
But algate of my maladye
She bud me tell and say her truth
Madame if ye would have routhe
Quod I then would I tell you
Sey forth quod she and tell me hou
She we me thy sekenes every dele
Madame that I can do well
Be so my life thereto wol last
With that her look on me she cast
And she said in aunter if thou live
My will is first that thou be shryue
And netheles how that it is
I wot my self but for all this
Unto my priest which comes anon
I wol thou tell it one and one
Both of thy thought and al thy werk

Come forth and here this man's shryft
Quod venus tho and I vplyft
My head with that and began behold
The self priest which as she would
Was ready there and set him down
To here my confession

Unto his own harm it grows

A tale to be ware thereby
Thyn eye for to keep and ward

mY sone as i shall the inform
There ben yet of another form
Of dedly vices seven applied
Whereof the heart is often plied
To thing which after shall him grieve
The^ first of hem thou shall believe
Is pride which is princypal
And has with him in especyal
Mynystres syue full diverse

iWote not fadre what ye mean
Bnt this I would you beseech
That ye me by somwey teache
What is to ben an Ipocryte
And if I be for to wit
I wol beknowe as it is
mY sone an Ypocryte is this
A man which feyneth co^seyen
As though it were al innocence
Without and is not so within
And does so for he would win
Of his desire the wine astate
And anon when he come there at
He she weth than what he was
The corn is turned in to gras
That was a Rose is than a thorn
And he that was a lamb byforne
Is than a wolf and thus malice
Under the color of Justice
As had / and as the people tells
These ordres wyten where he duelleth
As he that of her counseyll is
And thylk world which they or this
Forsakes and drawn in ayene
He cloteth riches as men seyn
Under the symplest of pouerte
And does to seem of great deserte
Thing which is little worth within
He seyth in open fie to sin
And in secreet there is no vice
Of which that he nys noryce
And ever his chere is sobre and soft
And where he goth he blessed often
Whereof the blind world he dretcheth
But yet al only he ne stretches
His rewle upon Relygyon
But next to that condicyon
In such as clepe hem holy church
It shows eke how he can worche
Among the wide furred hodes
To get hem the worldly goods
And they hem self by thylke same
That setten most the world in blame
But yet in contrary of his lore
There is nothing they louen more
So that seemed of light they work
The deeds which are inward derke
And thus this double ypocrysye
Which is devout apparancye
A byser set upon his face
Whereof toward the worlds grace
He seems to be well right thewed
And yet his heart is al beshrewed
But netheles he stant byleued
And has his purpoos often acheued
Of worship and of worlds welthe
And takyth it as who said by stelthe
Thorugh couerture of his fallas
And right so in semblable caas
This vice has eke his officers
Among these other seculeres
Of great men for of the sinale
As for to account he set no tale
But they that pass the comune
With such hem like to comune
And where he says he would socoure
The people there he wol devour
For now a day is many one
Which speaks of Peter and of John
And thinks Judas in his heart
There shall no worlds good astert
His hand and yet he gives Alms
And fasteth often and hereth mess
With mea culpa which he seyth
Upon his breast full often he leyth
His hond and case up ward his eye
As though Crystes face he syghe
So that it seems at the sight
As he alone al other might
Rescue with his holy deed
But yet his heart in other stead
Among his bedys most devout
Goth in the worlds cause about
How that he might his waryson

Toward love in all wise
For who that would him well advise
What has byfalle in this matere
He should naught with feyned chere
Deceive love in no degree
To love is enery heart fre
But in deceyt of that thou feynest
And thereupon thy lust atteynest
That thou have won with thy wyle
Though it be like for a while
Thou shall it afterward repent
And for to prove mine entente
I find ensample in a Cronyque
Of hem that love so beswyke

IT byfesse by old days thus
Whylome the emperor Tiberius
The Monarche of Rome thus lad
There was a worthy Romayn had
A wife and she Pauline hight
Which was to every mannys sight
Of all the Cite the fairest
And as men sayden eke the lest
It is and has been ever yet
That so strong is that no man's wit
Which through beauty ne may be with
draw / To love and under the law
Of thylke frele bore kind
Which makes the heart eyes blind
Where no reason may be comuned
And in this wise so fortuned
This tale of which I wol mean
This wife which in her lusts grene
Was fresshe and tender of age
She may not let the courage
Of him that wol on her assote
There was a duk and he was hot
Mundus which had in his bayllye
To lead all the chyualrye
Of Rome and was a worthy knight
But he was naught of such might
The strength of love not to withsto^de
That he ne was brought to hand
That maulgry where he would or no
This young wife he loves so
That he has put al his assay
To win thing which he ne may
Get of her grant in no manner
By yefte of gold ne by prayer
And when he sa we that by no mede
Toward her love he might speed
By sleyght feyned than he wrought
And thereupon he him bythought
How that there was in the Cite
A temple of such auctoryte
To which with great devotion
The noble women of the town
Most comonlyche on pylgremage
Gone for to pray thylke image
Which the goddess of Chyldyng is
And cleped was by name Isys
And in her temple than were
To rewle and to mynystre there
After the law which was tho
Abouen al other prestes two
This duk which thout his love get
Upon a day hem two to mete
Has bid and they come at his haste
Where they had a rich feste
And after mete in preuy place
This lord which would his thank pur
chase / To each of hem than gaf a gift
And spak so that by way of shryfte
He drough hem in to his couyne
To help and shape how paulyne
After his lust deceive might
And they her trouthes both plyght
That they by night her should win
In to the temple and he therynne
Shall have of her al his intent
Thus acorded forth they went
Now list thorugh which Ipocrysye
Ordained was the trecherye
Whereof this lady was deceived
These prestes hadden well conceived
That she was of great holiness
And with a counterfeyt symplenesse
Which hyd was in falls courage
Feyned an heavenly message
They come and said to her thus
Paulyne the God Anubus
Has sent us both prestes here
And says he wol to the appear
By nyghtes time him self allone
For love he has to thy person
And thereupon he has us bid
That we in Isys Temple a stead
Honestly for the purueye
Where thou by night as we the seye
Of him shall take a vysyon
For upon thy condycyon
The which is chaste and full of feyth
Such price as he us told he leyth
That he wol stand of thyn acord
And for to bear hereof record
He send us hyder both two
Glad was her Innocence tho
Of such words as she herd
With humble chere and thus ansuerd
And said that the gods will
She was al ready to fulfylle
That by her housbondes leave
She would in Isys Temple at eve
Upon her gods grace abide
To seruen him by night tide
The prestes gone home tho again
And she goth to her sovereign
Of gods will and as it was
She told him all the pleyne cas
Whereof he was deceived eke
And bad that she should her meke
Al hoole unto the gods heeste
And thus she which was honest
To god ward after her intent
At night to the temple went
Where that the false prestes were
And they receyuen her there
With such a tokue* of holiness
As though they sawen her Goddess
And al within a preuy place
A soft bed a large space
They had made and enterc^rteyned
Where she was afterward engyned
But she which al honor supposes
The false prestes than opposes
And axeth by what obseruaunce
She might most to the plesau^ce
Of god that nyghtes reule keep
And they her bydden for to sleep
Lyggend upon the bed a lofte
For so they sayden al stylle and soft
God Anubus her would awake
The counseylle in this wise take
The priests fro this lady gone
And she that wist of gyle none
In the manner as it was said
Tho to sleep upon the bed is leyd
In hope that she should acheue
Thing which stood than upon bileue
Fulfilled of all holiness
But she has failed as I guess
For in a closet fast by
The duk was hyd so pryuely
That she might not perceive
And he that thought to deceive
Has such array upon nome
That when he would unto her come
It should seem at her eye
As though she verily syghe
God Anubus and in such a wise
This ypocryyte of his queyntyse
Awayteth ever till she slepte
And than out of his place he crepte
So stylle that she nothing herd
And to the bed stalkynge he ferde
And suddenly or she it wist
Beclypt in arms he her kyst
Whereof in womannysshe ^rede
She wooke and nyst what to read
But he with soft words mylde
Comfort her and said with child
He would her make in such a kind
That all the world shall have in mind
The worship of that ylke sone
For he shall with gods wone
And ben him self a god also
With such words and with moo
The which he feyneth in his speech
This ladies wit was al to seche
As she which al troth weneth
But he that al untruth meneth
With blind tales so her lad
That al his will of her he had
And when him thout it was ynou
Again the day he him withdrough
So pryuely that she ne wyste
Where he bycome as he list
Out of the temple be goth his way
And she bygan to bydde and pray
Vpond the bare ground knelend
And after that made her offrende
And to the prestes yeftes great
She yafe and home ward in the street
The dnke her met and said thus
The mighty god which Annbus
^s hot he save the paulyne
For thou art of his disciplyne
So holy that no man's might
May do that he has do to night
Of thing which thou have ever esche
ued / But I his grace have so pursued
That I was made his lyeutenaunt
For thy by way of covenant
Fro this day for ward I was thine
And if the like to be mine
That stond upon thine own will
sHe herd this tale and bare it stylle
And home she went as it bifelle
In to her chambr^ and there she fille
^^on her bed to weep and cry
And said O derke ypocrysye
Thorugh whose dissimulacyon
Of falls ymagynacyon
I am wykkedly thus deceived
But that I have it apperceyued
I thank vuto the gods all
For though it thus byfalle
I shall never eft whiles I live
And thylk auowe to god I give
And thus wepend she compleyneth
Her fair face and al dysteyneth
With woeful teres her eye
So that upon this agonye
Her housbond is in come
And saw how she was overcome
With sow we and axeth her what her ey
leth, And she with yt her self bewei^eth
Well more than she did therefore
And said allas wyfhode is love
In me which whysome was honest
I am no more than a beeste
Now am I defouled of two
And as she might speak tho
Ashamed with a pytous onde
She told unto her housbonde
The sothe of all the hole tale
And in her speech deed and pale
She swouneth well nyghe to the last
And he her in arms fast
Vphelde and often swore his oath
That he with her is nothing wroth
For well he wot she may there nout
But netheles within his thought
His heart stood in a sorry plyght
And said he would of that despyte
Be auengyd how so ever it fall
And sent unto his friends all
And when they were comen in fere
He told hem upon this matere
And axed hem what was to done
And they auysed were sone
And said it thought hem for the best
To set his wife first in rest
And after pleyne to the king
Upon the matter of this thing
Tho was his woeful wife comforted
By all ways and disported
Till that she was somdele amended
And thus they a day or tuo dispe^ded
The third day she goth to pleyne
With many a worthy Cytezeyne
And he with many a Cytezeyne
When the emperor it herd seyne
And knew the falshede of the vice
He said he would do Iustyee
And first he let the prestes take
And for they should it not forsake
He put hem in to question
But they of suggestion
Ne could not one word refuse
Bnt for they would hem self excuse
The blame upon the duke they laid
But there ayene the cou^seyl said
That they be naught excused so
For he is one and they be two
And two have more wit than one
So thylke excusement was none
And over that was said hem eke
Than when men would virtue seek
Men should it in the prestes find
Her order is of so high a kind
That they be tuterers of the weye
For thy if any man forswey
Thorugh hem they be not excusable
And thus by law reasonable
Among the wise Inges there
The prestes both dampened were
So that the preuy trecherye
Hyd under falls ypocrysye
Was than openly showed
That many a man hem has beshrewed
And when the prestes were deed
The temple of thylke horrible deed
They thoughten purge and thylk image
Whose cause was the pylgremage
They drouen out and also fast
Fer in to the Tyber they it cast
Where the River it has defied
And thus the temple puryfyed
They have of thylke horrible sin
Which was that time do therynne
Of this point was thus advise
But of the duk was otherwise
For he with love was bestad
His dome was naught so hard lad
For love put reason awey
And can naught see the right wey
And by this cause he was respyted
So that the death him was acquyted
But for all that he was exybed
For he his love had so begyled
That he shall never come ayene
For he that is to truth vnpleyne
He may not faylen of vengeance
aNd to taken remembrance
Of that ypocrysye has wrought
On other halue men shall naught
To lightly leave all that they here
But than should a wyseman stere
The ship when such wyndes blow
For first thouh they begin low
At end they be naught meuable
But al to broke mast and cable
So that the ship with sodeyne blast
When men lest wene is over cast
As now fuloften a man may see
And of old time how it has be
I find a great experyence
Whereof to take euydence
Good is and to be war also
Of the peril or him be woe

At troy also if we begyn^
Ipocrysye it has bytrayd
For when ye greeks had al assayed /
And fond that by no bataill
Ne by no syege it might auayll
The town to win through pro wesse
This vice feyned of symplesse
Thorugh sleyghte of Calcas and Cryse
It wan by such a manner wise
An horse of bras they let do forge
Of such entaylle and of such a forge
That in this world was never man
That such another werk began
The crafty werkman Epius
It made and for to tell thus
The greeks that thoughten to begyle
The king in Troy in thylke while
With Anthenor and with Enee
That were both of the Cite
And of the counseylle the wysest
The rychest and the myghtyest
In pryue place so they trete
With fair byhestes and yeftes great
Of gold that they have engyned
To gedre and when they be couyned
They feynen for to make a pees
And under that yet nevertheless
They shopen the destructyon
Both of the king and of the Town
And thus the false pees was take
Of hem of Greece and undertake
And thereupon they fond awey
Where strength might not awey
That sleyghte should help thanne
And of an ynche a large spanne
By color of pees they made
And telden how they were glade
Of that they stonden in acord
And for it shall ben of record
Unto the king of Troy sayden
By way of love and thus they pra yden
As they that would his thank deserve
A sacryfyce unto myuerne
The pers to keep in good intent
They must offer or that they went
The king counseyled in the cas
By Anthenor and Eneas
Thereto has youen his assent
So was the pleyne truth blent
Thorugh counterfete ypocrysye
Of that they sholden sacryfye
The Greeks under the holiness
Anon with all business
Here horse of bras let fair dyghte
Which was to seen a wonder syghte
For it was trapped of him selue
And had of small wheles twelve
Upon the which men enough
With craft toward ye Town it drough
And goth glystrend against the son
Tho was there joy enough begone
For Troy in great denocyon
Came also with procession

With great honor and in this wise
Unto the gates they it brought
But of here intent when they sought
The gates weren al to small
And thereupon was many a tale
But for the worship of Mynerue
To whom they comen for to serve
They of the Town which understood
That all this thing was do for good
For pees / whereof they be glade
The gates that Neptunus made
A thousand winter there to fore
They have anon to broke and tore
The strong wallys down they break
So that in to the large street
This horse with great solempnyte
Was brought within the Cite
And offered with great reverence
Which was to Troy an euydence
Of love and pees for euermo
The Gregoys token leave tho
With all the hole felauship
And forth they wenten in to ship
And crossen sail and made hem yare
Anon as though they wolden fare
But when the blak winter night
Without Moan or sterre light
Bederked has the water stronde
Al pryuely they gone on land
Full armed out of the nauye
Simon which was made her efpye

When time was a tokne fyred
And with that their wey they holden
And comen right as they wolden
There as the gates were to broke
The purpoos was full take and spoke
Er any man may take keep
While that the Cite was a sleep
They slowen all that was within
And token what they might wyn
Of such good as was suffysaunt
And brenden up the remenaunt
And thus come out the trecherye
Which under falls ypocrysye
Was hyd / and they that wened pees
Tho myghten find no relees
Of thylk swerd which al devoured
Fulofte and thus the sweet soured
When it is know to the taste
He spylleth many a word wast
That shall with such a people trete
For when he weneth most beyete
Than is he shape most to leese
And right so if a woman chese
Upon the words that she hereth
Some man when he most true appears
Than is he forthest fro the truth
But yet fulofte and that is routhe
They speden that be most untrue
And louen every day a new
Whereof the lyef is after loath
And love has cause to be wroth
But that man that his lust desires
Of love and thereupon conspyreth
With weeds feyned to deceive
He shall not fail to receive
His pain as it is often seen
Confessor
For thy my sone as I the mean
It fyt the well to take heed
That thou eschew of thy manhede
Ipocrysye and his semblaunt
That thou ne naught be deceyuaunt
To make a woman to believe
Thing which is not in thy believe
For in such feynt Ipocrysye
Of love is all the trecherye
Thorugh which love is deceyned often
For feyned semblannt is so soft
Uneaths love may beware
For why sone as I well dare
I charge the to fle that vice
That many a woman it has made nyce
But look thou dele not with all
Iwys fadre no more I shall
Confessor
Now sone keep that thou have swore
For this that thou have herd before
Is said the first point of pride
And next upon that other side
To shryne and speak over this
Touchend of pride yet there is
The point second I the behote
Which Inobedyence is hot

it is vice of Inobediencie
Again the reule of co^seyence
Al yt is humble he disaloweth
That he toward his god ne boweth
After the laws of his heste
Not as a man but as a best
Which goth upon his lusts wild
So goth this proud vice vnmylde
That he dysdeyneth al law
He not what is to be felawe
And serve he may not for pride
So is he led on every side
And is that selue of whom me^ speak
Which wol not bow or that he break
I not if love might him plye
For else for to Iustyfye
His heart I not what might duayle
For thy my sone of such entayle
If that thyn heart be disposed
Tell out and let it naught be glosed
For if that thou vnbuxome be
To love I not in what degree
Thou shall thy good world acheue
Amans
My fadre ye shall well believe
The young whelpe which is affayted
Has not his master better waited
To couche when he seyth go low
Than I anon as I may know
My lady will ne bow more
But other while I grutche sore
Of some things that she does
Whereof tha. I wol tell soth
For of two points I am bethout
That I would I might naught
Obey unto my lady hest
But I dar make this byhest
Sauf only of that ylke two
I am vnbuxome of no mo
Confessor opponit
What / ben tho two tell on quod he
My fader this is one that she
Commands me my mouth to close
And that I should naught here oppose
In love of which I often preche
But preuelyche of such a speech
Forbere and suffer her in pees
But that ne might I netheles
For all this world obey I wys
For when I am there as she is
Though she my tales naught allow
Ayene her will yet mote I bow
To seche if that I might have grace
But that thing may I not embrace
For ought that I can speak or do
And yet full often I speak so
That she is wroth and says be stylle
For I that heest shall fulfylle
And thereto ben obedyent
Than is my cause fully shent
For speech les may noman speed
So wot I not what is to read
But certes I may naught obey
That I ne mote algates seye
Somewhat of that I would mean
For ever it is alyche grene
The great love which I have
Whereof I can not both save
My speech and this obedyence
And thus fulofte my silence
I break and is the first point
Whereof that I am out of point
In this and yet it is no pride
Now then upon that other side
To tell my disobeysaunce
Full sore it stant to my greuaunce
And may not synke in to my wytt
For oftyme she me bytt
To leave her and chese a new
And says if I the soth knew
How fer I stand out of her grace
I should love in other place
But thereof wol I disobeye
For also well she might seye
Go take the moon where it sytte
As bring that in to my wit
For there never roted tree
That stood so fast in his degree
That I ne stand more fast
Upon her love and may cast
Mine heart awey as though I would
For god wot though I never should
Seen her with eye after this day
Yet stont it so that I ne may
Her love out of my breast renew
This is a wondre retenue
That maulgre where she wol or none
Mine heart is ever more in one
So that I can none other chese
But whether that I win or lose
I mote her love till I deye
And thus I break as by that weye
Here hestes and here commau^dynges
But trulyche in none other things
For thy my fadre what is more
Touchand to this ylke lore
I you byseche after the form
That ye pleynly me would inform
So that I might mine heart reule
In loves cause after the reule

tOward the vice of which we trete /
There be twey of thilk estrete*
Here name is murmur and co^pleynt /
There can noman here chere peynt.
To set a glad se^blaunt therinne
For though fortune make hem win
Yet grutche they and if they lose
There is no weye for to chese
Whereof they might stand appesed

There may no welthe ne pouerte

For oftyme they despise
The good fortune as the badde

Thorugh pride whereof they be blind

There was whylom by days old
A worthy knight as men ^old
He was neue we to them perour
And of his Court a Courteour
Wyfles he was Florent he hyghte
He was a man that mochel might
Of arms he was desirous
Chyualrous and amerous
And fame of worlds speech
Strange auentures for to seche
He rood the marches all about
And fell a time when he was out
Fortune which may every threde
To break and knytte of man's speed
Shope as this knight rood in a pas
That he by strength take was
And to a Castle they him ladde.
Where that he few friends had
For so it fell that ylke stou^de
That he had a dedely wound
Frghtend his own hands slain
Branchus which to the Capytayn
Was sone and heir whereof ben wroth
The fadre and the modre both
That knyt Branchus was of his ho^de
The worthyest of al his land
And seyn they would do vengeance
Upon Florent but remembrance
That they took of his worthynes
Of knyghthode and of gentylnes
And how he stood of cosynage
To the emperor took assuage
And durst not sleyn him for fere
In great despute son they were
Among hem self that was the best
There was a lady the slyest
Of all that men knew tho
So old she might uneaths go
And was grandame unto the deed
And with that bygan to read
And she said she would bring him ynne
That she shall him to death win
Al only of his own grant
Thorugh strength of very covenant
Without blame of any wight
Anon she sent for this knight
And of her sone she aleyde
The death / and thus to him she seyde
Florent hou so thou be to wit
Of Branchus death men shall respyte
As now to take a^engement
Be so thou stand in Judgment
Upon certain condycyon
That thou unto a questyon
Which I shall axe shall ansuere
And over this thou shall eke swear
That if thou of the soth fail
There shall none other thing avail
That thou ne shall the death receive
And for men shall the not deceive
That thou thereof might be aduysed
Thou shall have day and time assysed
And love saufly for to wend
Be so that at thy days end
Thou come again with thyn auyse
This knyt which was worthy and wise
This lady prays that he may wit
And have it under seals write
What question it should be
For which he shall in that degree
Stand of his life in Ieopardye
With that she feyneth company
And says Florent on love it longs
All that to mine axyng longs
What al women most desire
This wol I axe and in thempyre
Where thou have most knoulechyng
Take counceylle of this axyng
Florent this thing has undertake
The time was set and day take
Under his seal he wrote his oath
In such a wise and forth he goth
Home to his emes court again
To whom his adventure pleyne
He told of that him is byfalle
And upon that they were all
The wysest of the land assent
But netheles of one assent
They might not acorde plat
One said this another that
After the disposicion
Of natural complexyon
To sum woman it is plesau^ce
That to another is greuaunce
But such a thing in specyal
Which to hem al in general
Is most plesaunt and most desired
Above al other and most conspyred
Such one can they not find
By Constellacyon ne by kind
And thus Florent without cure
Must stand upon his adventure
And is al shape unto the lyere
And as in defaulte of his ansuere
This knight has lever for to dye
Than break his truth and for to lie
In place where he was swore
And shapith him gone ayene therefore
When time come he took his leave
That longer would he not believe
And prayth his eme he be not wroth
For that is a point of his oath
He says that noman shall him wreke
Though afterward here men speak
That he parauenture dye
And thus he went forth his weye
Alone as a knight auenturous
And in his right was curyous
To wit what was best to do
And as he rode alone so
And came nyghe there he would be
In a forest there under a tree
He saw where sat a creature
A lothly womannyssh figure
That for to speak of flessh and bone
So foul yet saw he never none
This knight byheld her redely
And as he would have passed by
She cleped him and bad him abide
And he his horse head a side
Tho turned and to her he rode
And there he houed and abode
To wit what she would mean
And she bygan him to be mean
And said Florent by thy name
Thou have on hand such a game
That if thou be not better auysed
Thy death shapen is and devised
That all the world ne may the save
But if that thou my counceyl have
Florent when he this tale herd
Unto this old wight ansuerd
And of her counseyl he her prayed
And she ayene to him thus said
Florent if I for the so shape
That thou thorugh me thy death escape
And take worship of thy deed
What shall I have to my mede
What thing quoth he yt thou would axe
I bid never a better tax
Quod she but first or thou be sped
Thou shall me leave such a wed
That I wol have thy troth on hand
That thou shall be mine husbonde
Nay said Florent that may not be
Ride then forth thy wey quod she
And if thou go forth without read
Thou shall be sekerlyche deed
Florent behyght good enough
Of land of rent of park of plough
But all that she compteth naught
Tho fell this knyt in mochel thout
Now goth he^ forth / now comes ayene
He not what is best to seyne
And thought as he rode to and fro
That chose he mote one of the two
Or for to take her to his wife
Or else to lose his life
And than he cast his advantage
That she was of so great an age
That she may live but a while
And thought to put her in an I Will
Where that noman her should know
Till she with death were overthrow
And thus this young lusty* knight
Unto this old lothely wight
Tho said if that none other chance
May make my delyueraunce
But only thylke same speech
Which as thou ^eyst thou shall me
teache / Have here mine ho^d I shall ye
Wedde / And thus his troth he leid to
Wedde^ With yt she frou^ceth up yt browe
This covenant wol I allow
She says if any other thing
But that thou have of my techyng
Fro death thy body may respyte
I wol the of thy truth acquyte
And else by none other weye
Now harken me what I shall seye
When thou art come in to the place
Where now they maken great manace
And upon thy coming abide
They wol anon the same tide
Oppose the of thine ansuere
I wot thou wolt no thing forbere
Of that thou wenest be thy best
And if thou might so find rest
Well is for than is there more
And else this shall be my lore
That thou shall say upon this molde
That al women leuest would
Be sovereign of man's love
For what woman is so above
She says as who says al her will
And else may she naught fulfylle
What thing were here leuest have
With this ansuer thou shall save
Thy self and otherwise naught
And when thou have thy end wrout
Come here ayene thou shall me find
And let nothing out of thy mind
He goth him forth with heavy chere
As ^e that not in what manner
He may this, worlds Joy atteyne
For if he dye he has a pain
And if he live he mote him bind
To such a wytche of old kind
Of women the vnsemelyest
Thus wot he not what is the best
But be him lyef or be him *loath
Unto the Castle forth he goth
His full ansuere for to give
Or for to dye or for to live
Forth with his counseyll came the lord
The things stonden of record
He send up for the lady sone
And forth she came that old moan
In presence of the remenaunt
The strength of all the covenant
Tho was reherced openly
And to Florent she bad par die
That shall tellen his auys
As he that wot what is the prys
Florent says all that ever he couthe
But such word came none to mouth
That he for yefte or for byheste
Might any wise his death areste
And thus he taryeth long and late
Till this lady bad algate
That shall for the dome fynal
Give his ansuere in specyal
Of that she had first opposed
And than he has truly supposed
That he him may of nothing yelpe
But if so be tho words help
Which as the woman has him taut
Whereof he has an hope caught
That he shall be excused so
And told out pleyne his will tho
And when this matrone herd
The manner how this knight ansuerd
She said treson woe the be
That have thus told the pryuyte
Which al women most desire
I would that thou were on fire
But netheles in such a plyght
Florent of his ausuer is quyt
And tho bygan his soro we new
For he mote gone or be untrue
To her which his truth had
But he which al shame drad
Goth forth instead of his penance
And takes the fortune of his chance
As he that was with troth affayted
This old wight him has awayted
In place where* as he her in* left
Florent his woeful head up lift
And saw this where that she sytte
Which was the lothest wyghte
That ever man cast on his eye
Here nose^baas *her brows high
Her eyes small and deep set
Her chekes ben with teres weet
And ryuelyn as in an empty skyn
Hangyng down unto the chyn
Her lyppes ben shronken for age
There* was no grace in her vysage
Her front was narwe her locks hoar
She looks forth as does a more
Her neck is short her shulders courbe
That might a man's lust distourbe
Here body great and no thing small
And shortly for to descryue her all
She has no lyth without a lak
But lyche unto the wolle sak
She profereth her unto this knight
And bad him as he behyght
So as she bath by his warrant
That he her held covenant
And by the brydel she him seseth

Of such words as she speaks
Him thinks well nyghe his heart bre
keth / *For sorrow that he may fle
But if he would untrue be

Takes baldemony with canele
And with the myrre the sucre
Right on such manner lucre
Stant Florent in this dyete
He drynketh the bitter with the sweet
He medleth sorrow with lykyng
And lives as who says deyng
His thought shall be cast awey
Upon such one as that the wey
Is old and lothly oueralle
But need he mote that need shall
He would algate his truth hold
As every knight thereto is hold
What hap so ever to him is fall
Though she be foulest of all
The honor of womanhede
Him thought he should take heed
So that for pure gentilnesse
As he couthe her best adresse
In rags as she was to tore
He set her on his horse to fore
And forth he takes his weye soft
No wonder though he sygheth often
But as an oule flees by night
Out of al other birds sight
Right so this knight on days broad
In close him held and shope his rode
On nyghtes time till the tide
That he come there he would abide
And pryuely without noise
He brings this foul great coyse
To his Castle in such a wise
That noman might her shap auyse

And told hem that he needs must
This best wedde unto his wife
For else he had lost his life
The pryue women were assent
That should be of his assent
Her rags they anon of draw
And as it was that time law
She had bath she had rest
And was arrayed to the best
But with no craft of combs broad
They might d^esse her locks shode
And she ne would not be shore
For no counseyl and therefore
With such attire as tho was used
Ordeynen that it was excused
And had so craft lyche about
That noman might seen hem out
But when she was fully arrayed
And her attire was al assayed
Tho she was fouler unto se
But yet it may none other be
They were wedded by night
So woe begone was never knight
As he was than of Marriage
And she bygan to play and rage
As who says I am well enough
But he thereof nothing ne lough
For she took than chere on hand
And clepeth him her husbonde
And said my lord go we to bed
For I to that intent wedde
For thou shall be my worlds bliss
And profereth him with that to kiss
As she a lusty lady were
His body might well be there
But as of thought and memory
His heart was in purgatory
But the strength of matrimonye
Who might make none essonye
That he mote algate plye
To gone to bed of company
And when they were abed naked
Without sleep he was awaked
He torneth on that other side
For that he would his eyes hyde
For lokyng on the foul wight
The chamber was full of light
The curteyne were of sendal thynne
This new bryd which lay withynne
Though it be naught with his acord

When that he took her by the hand
hE herd and understood the bond
How he was set to his penance

He torneth him al suddenly
And saw a lady lay him by
Of eyghtene winter age
Which was the fairest of vysage
That ever m all this world he syghe
And as he would have take her nyghe
She put her hand and by his love
Besought him that he would love
And says for to win or lose
He mote one of two things chese
Where he wol have such on night
Or else upon the days light
For ye shall not have both two
And he bygan to sorrow tho
In many a wise and cast his thought
But for all that yet could he naught
Deuyse him self which was the best
And she that would his heart rest
Prayth that he should chese algate
Till at the last long and late
He said O ye my lines hele
Say what ye list in my quarele
I not what ansuer I shall yiue
But ever while that I live
I wol that ye be my Maystresse
For I can not my self guess
Which is the best unto my choys
Thus grant I you mine hole voys
Chese for us both I you pray
And what as ever that ye say
Right as ye wol so wol I
mY lord she said grant mercy
For of this word yt ye now sayn
That ye have made me souerayn
My destyne is ouerpassed
That never here after shall be lassed
My beauty which I now have
Till I be take in to my grave
Both Night and day as I am now
I shall alwey be such to you
The kings daughter of Cecyle
I am / and fell but sith a while
As I was with my fader late
That my stepmoder for an hate
Which to ward me she has bygonne
Forshope me tylle I had won
The love and the soueraynte
Of what knight that in his degree
Al other passes of good name
As men seyn ye be the same
The deed proves it is so
Thus am I your for euermo
Tho was plesaunce and joy Enough
Echone with other played and lough
They live long and well they ferde
And Clerks that this chance herd
They written it in euydence
To teache how that obedyence
May well fortune a man to love
And set him in his lust above
As it byfelle unto this knight
fOr thy my sone if you do right
Thou shall unto thy love obey
And follow her will by all weye
Amans
Mine holy fader so I will
For ye have told me such a skylle
Of this ensample now to fore
That I shall euermo therefore
Here after mine obseruaunce
To love and his obeysaunce
The better keep and over this
Of pride if there ought else is
Whereof that I me shryue shall
What thing it is m specyal
My fadre axeth I you pray

nOw lest my sone and I shall say

s Vrquedrye is thylk vice
Of pride which ye third office
Has in his court and will not know /
The truth til he be outhrowe
Upon his fortune and his grace
Comes had I wist full often a place
For he does al his thing by guess
And voydeth al sykernesse
None other counsel good him seems
But such as he him self demeth
For m such wise as he compasses
His wit al other passes
And is with pride so through sought
That he al three set at naught
And weneth of him seluen so
That such as he there be nomo
And thus he would bear a price
So fair so semely nor so wise
Abouen al other and naught for thy
He says not ones grant mercy
To god / which al grace sends
So that his wits he dispendeth
Upon him self as though there were
No god which might avail there
But al upon his own wit
He stant till he fall in the pytte
So far that he may not arise

a Nd right thus in the same wise
The vice upon the cause of love
So proudely set the heart above
And does him pleynly for to wene
That he to louen any queen
Has worthynes and suffysaunce
And so without purueannce
Full often he heueth up so high
That Chyppes fallen in his eye
And eke fulofte he weneth this
There as he naught byloued is
To be loved al there best
Now sone tells what so the lest
Of this that I have told the here

hA fader be naught in a were
I trow there be noman less
Of any manner worthynesse
That halt him less worthy than I
To be byloued and not for thy

To al men that love is fre
And certes that may noman werne
For love of him self so derne
It luteth in a man's heart

To wene for to be worthy
To louen but in her mercy
But sire of that ye would mean

Amans
Now lest and I wol tell you
My good fadre how it is
Full often it has byfalle or this
Thorugh hope and was not certain
My wenyng has be set in vein
To trust in thing that help me nout
But onlyche of mine own thought
For as seems that a belle
Like to the words that men tell
Ansueryth right so no more ne less
To you my fadre I confess
Such will my wit has ever set
That what so hope me behet
Full many a time I wene it sothe
But finally no speed it does
Thus may I tell as I can
Wenyng begyleth many a man
So has it me right well I wot
For if a man wol in a boat
Which is without botome to we
He must needs onerthrowe
Right so wenyng has ferde by me
For when I wend next have be
As I by my wenyng cast
Than was I forthest at last
And as a fool my bow vnbende

That my wenyng has gone amys

mY sone in all manner wise
Surquedrye is to despise
Whereof I find write thus
The proud knight Capaneus /
He was of such Surquedrye
That he thorugh his chyualrye
Upon him self so mochel trust
That to the gods him ne lust
In no quarelle to beseech
But said it was an ydel speech
Which cause was of pure dread
For lak of heart and for need
And upon such presumpcion
He held this proud oppynyon
Till at the last*vpon a day
About Thebes where he lay
When it of syege was beleyne
This knight as the Cromyque seyne
In all man's sight there
When he was proudest in his gere
And how nothing might him dear
Full armed with his sheld and spear
As he the Cite would assaylle
God took him self the bataylle
Ayene his pride and fro the sky
A fyry thonder suddenly
He send and to poudre him smote
And thus the pride which was hot
When he most in his strength wend
Was brent and lost withouten end
So that it proves well therefore
The strength of man is sone lore
But if that he it well govern
And over this a man may learn
That eke full oftyme it greueth
What that a man him self believes
As though it should him well beseme
That he al other men can deem
And has foryete his own vice
A tale of hem that be so nyce
And feynen hem self to be wise
I shall tell the in such a wise
Whereof thou shall ensample take
That thou no such thing undertake

I Find upon Surquedrye
How yt whilom of hu^garye
By old days was a king
Wise and honest in all thing
And so byfel upon a day
And that was m the month of May
As thylk time it was vsance
This king with noble purueannce
Has for him self his chaar arrayed
Wheryn he would ride amayed
Out of the Cite for to play
With lords and great arraye
Of lusty folk that were young
Where sum pleyd and sum song
And sum gone and some ride
And sum pryke her horse a side
And brydlen hem now in now out
The king his eye cast about
Till he at last was ware
And saw comend again his chare
Two pylgryms of so great age
That lyche unto a dry image
That weren pale and fade hewed
And as a busshe which is besnewed
Here berdes be hoore and white
There was of kind but a lyte
That they ne semen fully deed
They come to the king and bid
Sum of his good pur charity
And with great humylyte
Out of his chare to ground he lepe
And hem m both his arms keep
And kyst hem both foot and hand
Before the lords of his land
And yaf hem of his good thereto
And when he has this deed do
He goth in to his chare again
Tho was murmour tho was dysdeyne
Tho was compleynt on every side
They sayden of her own pride
Echone to other what is this
Our king has do this thing amys
So to abesse his Royalte
That every man it might se
And humbled him in such a wise
To hem that were of none empryse
Thus was it spoken to and fro
Of hem that were with him tho
Al pryuely behind his bak
But to him self noman spak
The kings brother in presence
Was thylk time and great offense
He took thereof and was the same
Abouen al other which most to blame
Upon his lyege lord has leyd
And has unto the lords said
Anon as he can time find
There shall nothing be left behind
That he wol speak unto the king
Now what fell upon this thing
They were merry and fair ynongh
Echone with other played and lough
And fellen in to tales new
How that the fresshe flowers grew
And how the grene leaves spronge
And how that love among the young
Bygan the hertes than to wake
And every byrd has chose his make
And thus the may day to the end
They lad and home aye ne they wend
The king was not so sone come
That when he had his chamber nome
His brother ne was ready there
And brought a tale unto his ere
Of that he had such a shame
In hyndeyng of his own name
When he him self would dretche
That to so vile a pouer wretch
Him deyneth show such symplesse
Against the state of his noblesse
And says he shall no more use
And that he mote him self excuse
Toward his lords euerychone
The king stood stylle as onystone
And to his tale an ere he leyde
And thought more than he seyde
But netheles to that he herd
Well curtoysly he ansuerde
And told it should be amended
And thus when yt here tale was ended
Al ready was the board and cloth
The king unto his souper goth
Among the lords to the halle
And when they had souped all
They when leave and forth they go
The king bythought him seluen tho
Hou he his brother may chastye
That he thought his surquedrye
Took upon hond to dispreyse
Humylyte which is to preyse
And thereupon yaf such counseylle
Toward his king that was vnheyle
Whereof to be the better lered
Him thinks to make him afered
It fell so that in thylke dawe
There was ordained by the law
A Trompe with a stern breath
Which was cleped the Trompe of death
And in the Court where ye king was
A certain man a Trompe of bras
Has in keeping and thereof serves
That when a lord his death deserves
He shall this dredefull Trompe blow
To fore his gate and make it know
How that the jugement is give
Of death which shall not be foryeue
The king when it was night anon
This man assent and bad him gone
To trompen at his broders gate
And he which mote done algate
Goth forth and does the kings heste
This lord which herd this tempeste
That he to fore his gate blewe
Tho wist he by the law and knew
That he was sekerlyche deed
And as of help he wist no read
But send for his friends all
And told hem how it is byfalle
And they him axe cause why
But he the soth not for thy
Ne wist and there was sow we tho
For it stood thylk time so
This Trompe was of such sentence
That there ayene no resystence
They could ordeyne by no weye
That he ne mote algate deye
But if so be he may purchase
To get his lyege lords grace
Here wits thereupon cast
And len appointed at last
This lord a worthy lady had
Unto his wife which also drad
Her lords death and children five
Between hem two they had on line
That weren young and tender of age
And of stature and of vysage
Right fair and lusty to see
Tho casten they that he and she
Forth with her children on the morrow
As they that were full of sorrow
Al naked but of smok and shyrte
To tender with the kings heart
His grace should go to seche
And pardon of death biseche
Thus passen they that woeful night
And erly when it was light
They gone hem forth in such a wise
As thou to fore have herd deuyse
All naked but her shyrtes one
They wept and made mochel moan
Her here hanged about her eres
With sobbyng and with sorry terys
This lord goth then an humble pas
That whylome proud and noble was
Whereof the Cite sore a flight
Of hem that sawen that ylke sight
And netheles al openly
With such weeping and such cry
Forth with his children and his wife
He goth to pray for his life
Unto the court when thry be come
And men therein has hyed nome
There was no wight if he hem syghe
From water might keep his eye
For sow we they maden tho
The king supposyth of this woe
And feyneth as he naught ne wist
But netheles at his vpryst
Men told him how it ferde
And when that he this wonder herd
In have he goth in to the halle
And al attones down they fall
If any pity may be found
The king which seth hem fell to ground
Has axed hem what is the fere
Why be ye so dispoylled there
His brother said A lord mercy
I wot none other cause why
But only that this night full late
The Trompe of death was at my gate
In tokene that I should dye
Thus we be come for to preye
That ye my worlds death respyte
Ha fool thou thou art for to wit
The king unto his brother seyde
That thou art of so little freyd
That only for a Trompes soune
Has gone dispoilled thorugh ye town
Thou and thy wife in such manner
Forth with thy children that been here
In sight of all men about
For that thou say thou art in doubt
Of death which stant under the law
Of man and man may it withdraw
So that it may per chance faylle
Now shall thou not for thy meruaylle
That I down from my chare alyght
When I beheld to fore my sight
In hem that were of so great age
Mine own death thorugh her image
Which god has set by law of kind
Whereof I may no bote find
For well I wot such as they be
Right such am I in my degree
Of flesh and blood and so shall deye
And thus though I that law obey
Of which that kings be put under
It ought be well the less wonder
Then thou which art without need
For law of land in such a dread
Which for to account is but a iape
As thing which thou myt ouerscape
For thy my brother after this
I read that sethyn that so is

Uncoupled and the horns blow

But that the rote shall stand,
Thou shall well understand
There shall abide of thy regne
A time again where thou shall regne
And eke of that thou herdest say^
To take a man's heart away^
And set there a bestyal
So that like an ox shall
Pasture and that he be reyned
By times seven and sore peyned
Till that he kno we his gods mytes
Than shall he stand again vprightes
All this bytokeneth thine estate
Which now with god is in debate
Thy man's form shall be lassed
Till seven year be over passed
And in the lykenes of a best
Of gras shall be thy Royal ^^ste
The wether shall upon the rain
And understand that all this pain
Which thou shall suffer thylk tide
Is shape al only for thy pride
Of vein glory and of the ^ynne
Which thou have long stand ynne
So upon this condycyon*
Thy sweuene has exposicyon
But or this thing befalle in deed
Amend the this would I read
Give and depart thyn alms
Do mercy forth with ryghtwysenes
Beseech and pray the high grace
For so thou might thy pees purcha^^
With god and stonden in good acord
But pride is loath to lose his lord
And wol not suffer humylyte
With him to stand in no deg^e
And when a ship has lost his stere
Is none so wise that may him stere
Again the wawes in a rage
This proud king in his courage
Humylyte has so forlore
That for no sweuene he saw to fore
Ne yet for all that Danyel
Him has counseylled every del
He let it pass out of his mind
Thorugh vein glory and as the blind
He sees no weye or him be woe
And fell within a time so
As he in Babyloyne went
The vanyte of pride him hente
His heart aroos of vein glory
So that he drough in to memory
His lordship and his Regalye
With words of surquedrye
When that he him most auaunteth
That lord which glory daunteth
Al suddenly as who says treys
Where that he stood in his paleys
He took him from the men's sight
Was none of hem so war that might
Set eye where he bycome
And thus was he from his kingdom
In to the wyld for^st draw
Where that the mighty gods law
Thorugh his power did transform
Fro man in to a bestes form
And like an ox under the foot
He graseth as he needs mote
To geten his lives fode
Tho thought him cold gras good
That whilome ete the hot^ spyces
Thus was he turned from delyces
The wyn was wont to drink
He took then of the wells brynke
Or of the pyt or of the slough
It thought him then good enough
Instead of chambres well arrayed
He was than of a busshe well paid
The hard ground he lay upon
For other pylowes had he non
The storms and the raynes fall
The wyndes blow upon him all
He tormented day and night
Such was the high gods might
Till seven year an end took
Upon him self tho began he look
Instead of mete gr^s and treys
Instead of hands long cleys
Instead of man a best like
He saw and than he began to syke
For cloth of gold and of perrye
Which him was wont to magny^ye
When he byheld his cote of here is
He wept and with woeful teres
Up to the heaven he cast his chere
Wepend and thought in this manner
Though he no words may win
Thus said his heart and spak withynne
O mighty god that al have wrought
And al myt bring again to nout
Now know I but al of the
This world has no prosperyte
In thyn aspect ben al alyche
The pour man and eke the rich
Without the there may no wight
And thou above al other might
O mighty lord to ward my vice
Thy mercy meddle with Justice
And I wol make a covenant
That of my life the remenaunt
I shall it by the grace amend
And in thy law so dispende
That veyn glory I shall eschew
And bow unto thyn heste and sewe
Humylyte and that I vow
And so thenkend he began down bow
And though him lack boys and speehe
He began with his fete areche
And wenend in his beestly steuene
He made his pleynt unto the heuene
He kneleth in his wise and brayeth
To seche mercy and assayeth
His god which made him nothing
strange. When yt he saw his pride change
Anon as he was humble and tame
He fond toward his god the same
And in a twynkelyng of a look
His man's form again he took
And was reformed to the Reygne
In which that he was wont to reygne
So that the pride of veyn glory
Ever afterward out of memory
He let it pass and thus it showed
What is to ben of pride vnthe wed
Again the high gods law
To whom no man may be felawe
For thy my sone take good head
So for to lead thy manhede
That thou be not like a best
But if thy life shall be honest
Thou must humblesse take on hand
For than might thou syker stand
And for to speak in other wise
A proud man can not assise
For thou a woman would him please
His pride can not ben at ease
There may noman to mochel blame
A vice which is for to blame
For thy men shulden nothing hyde
That might fall in blame of pride
Which is the worst vice of all
Whereof so as it was byfalle
The tale I think of a Cronyque
To tell if it may the like
So that thou might humblesse sewe
And eke the vice of pride eschew
Whereof the glory is false and vein
Which god him self has in dysdeyne
That though it mount for athrowe
It shall fall down and overthrow

hIc narrat Confessor Exe^plum contra superbiam / Et dicit quod nuper quidam
Rex famous prudencie cuidam Militi suo super questionibus vt inde certitudinis
responsione^ daret subpena capitalis seutencie terminum pre fixit / Primo quid
minoris indigencie ab inhabitantibus orbem auxilium maius obtinuit / Secundo
quid maioris valencie meritum continens minoris expense reprisas exigu^t.
Tercio qid oi^a bona diminuens ex sui proprietate nichil penitus valuit /

nullius indiget qua^ tn^ adiuuare cotidianis laboribus omnes intendunt / Ad

prodegalitatis expensis me^suram excedit / Ad terciam dixit quod superbia omnia
