Aching was whilom yo^g and wise
The which of his wit set great price
Of deep ymagynacyo^s
And strange Interpretacions
Problemes and demau^des eke
His wysedom was to find and seek
Whereof he would in sundry wise
Opposen hem that were wise
But none of hem it might vere
Upon his word to give ansuere
Out taken one which was a knight
To him was every thing so light
That also sone as he hem herd
The kings words ansuerde
What thing the king axe would
There anon the truth he told
The king somdele had an envy
And thout he would his wits plye
To set some conclusyon
Which should be confusyon
Unto this knight so that the name
And of wisdom the high fame
To ward him self he would win
And thus of al his wit to win
The king bygan to study and muse
What strange matter be might use
The knights wits to confound
And at last he has it found
And for the knight anon he sent
That he shall tell what he meant
Upon the points of the matter
Of questions as thou shall here
The first point of al three
Was this What thing in all degree
Of all this World has need lest
And yet men help it alther mest
The second What most is worth
And of costage is lest put forth
The third is which is of most cost
And lest is worth and goth to lost
The king these three demau^des axeth
To the knight this law he taxes
That he shall gone and come again
The third weke and tell him pleyne
To every point what it amounts
And if so be that he myscounteth
To make in his ansuere a faylle
There shall none other thing faylle
The king says that he shall be deed
And lose his goods and his head
The knight was sorry of this thing
And would excuse him to the king
But he ne would him not forbere
And thus this knight of his ansuere
Goth home to take auyfement
But after his entendement
The more he cast his wit about
Thereof he stant the more in doubt
Tho wist he well the kings heart
That he the death ne should astert
And such a sow we has to him take
That gladship he has forsake
He thought first upon his life
And after that upon his wife
Upon his childee eke also
Of which he had daughters two
The youngest of hem had in age
Fourtene year and of vysage
She was right fair and of stature
Lyche to an heuenlyche figure
And of manner and of goodly speech
Though men would al lands seche
They should not have founden her like
She saw her fadre sorrow and syke
And wist not the cause why
So came she to him pryuely
And yt was where he made his moan
Within a gardyn al him one
Upon her knees she began down fall
With humble heart and to him call
And said O good fadre dear
Why make ye thus heavy chere
And I wot nothing how it is
And well ye know fadre this
What adventure that you fell
Ye might it saufly to me tell
For I have often herd you said
That ye such trust have on me laid
That to my suster ne to my brother
In all this world ne to none other
Ye durst have told a pryuete
So well my fadre as to me
For thy my fadre I you pray
Ne casts naught that heart away
For I am she that would keep
Your honor and with that weep
Her eye may not be forbore
She wyssheth for to ben vnbore
Er that her fadre so mystryst
To tellen her of that he wist
And ever among mercy she cryede
That he ne should his counseylle hyde
From her that so would him good
And was so nyghe flesh and blood
So that weeping at the last
His chere upon his child he cast
And sorowfully to that she prayde
He told his tale and thus he said
The sorrow daughter which I make
Is not al only for my sake
But for the both and for you all
For such a chance is me befalle
That I shall or this third day
Lose all that ever I lose may
My life and al my good thereto
Therefore it is I sorrow so
What is the cause alas quod she
My fadre that ye sholden be
Deed and destroyed in such a wise
And he bygan the points deuyse
Which as ye king told him by mouth
And said her pleynly that he couth
Ansuere to no point of this
And she that hereth how it is
Her counseyl yafe and said tho
My fadre syn it is so
That ye can none other weye
But that ye must needs deye
I would pray of you a thing
Late me go with you to the king
And ye shall make him understand
Hou ye my wits for to fond
Have leyd ansuere upon me
And tell him in such degree
Upon my word ye wol abide
Tho to live or deye what so betyde
For yet per chance I may purchase
With some good word ye kings grace
Your life and eke your good to save
For often shall a woman have
Thing which yt a man may not areche
The fadre herd the daughters speech
And thought there was reason ynne
And saw his own life to win
He reuthe done him self no cure
So better him thought in adventure
To put him and al his good
Than in the manner as it stood
His life in certain for to lose
And thus thynkend he bygan to chese
To do the counseyll of this maid
And eke the purpoos which she said
The day was come and forth they gone
Unto the Court they come anon
Where as the king in his Judgment
Was set and has this knight asent
Arrayed in the best wise
This maiden with her words wise
Her fadre led by the hand
In to the place where he fond
The king with other which he would
And to the king knelend he told
As he informed was to fore
And prayth the king that he therefore
His daughters words wol take
And says that he wol undertake
Upon her words for to stand
Tho was there great meritayl on hand
That he which was so wise a knyt
His life upon so young a wight
Be set would in Ieopardye
And many it held for folly
But at the last nevertheless
The king commanded to be in pees
And to this maid he cast his chere
And said he would her tale here
And bad her speak and she bygan
My lyege lord so as I can
Quod she the points which I herd
They shall of reason be ansuerde
The first I understand is this
What thing of all the world it is
Which men most help and lest need
My lyege lord this would I read
The earth it is which euermo
With mannys labor is vego
As well in winter as in may
The man's hand what he may
To help it forth and make it rich
And for thy men it delue and dyche
And eren it with strength of plough
Where it has of him self enough
So his need is at the lest
For every man byrd and best
And flour and gras and rote and rynde
And every thing by wey af kind
Shall sterue and earth it shall bycome
As it was out of the earth nome
It shall to earth torn again
And thus I may by reason seyne
That therthe is most nedeles
And most men help it netheles
So that my lord touchand of this
I have ansuerd how it is
That other point I understood
Which most is worth and most is good
And costeth a man lest to keep
My lord if ye wol take keep
I say it is Humylyte
Thorugh which the high Trynyte
As for deserte of true love
Unto Mary from above
Of that he knew her humble intent
His own sone a down he sent
Above al other / and her he chese
For that virtue which that bedeth pees
So that I may by reason call
Humylyte is most worthyest of all
And lest it costeth to mayntene
In all the word as it is seen
For who that has humblesse un hende
He brings no wer^e in to land
For he desires for the best
To set every man in rest
Thus with your high reverence
Me thinks, that this euydence
As to this point is suffysaunt
And touchend of the remenaunt
Which is the third of your askynges
What lest is worth of al things
And ^osteth most I tell it pride
Which may not in the heuene abide
For Luafer with him it fell
Bar Pride with him in to hell
There was pride of to great a cost
When he for pride has heaven lost
And after that in Paradyse
Adam for pride he lost his price
In myddel earth and eke also
Pride is the cause of al We
That all the world it may suffyse
So stant of pride the repryse
Pride is the heed of al sin
Which wastes all and may not win
Pride is of every mys the pryk
Pride is the worst of al wyck
And costeth most and lest is worth
In place where he has his forth
Thus have I said that I wol sey
Of mine ansuere and to you prey
Mine lyege lord of your office
That ye shall grace and such Justice
Ordeyne for my fadre here
That after this men it here
The world thereof may say good
The king / which reason understood
And has al herd which she has said
Was inly glad and so well paid
That al his wrath is over go
And he bygan to look tho
Upon this maid in the face
In which he found so mochel grace
That al his price on her he ^eyde
In audyence and thus he seyde
My fair maid well ye be
Of thine ansuere and eke of the
Me lyketh and as thou wylt
Foryeue be thy fadre gylt
And if thou were of such lygnage
That thou to me were of parage
And that thy fadre were a pere
As he is now a bachylere
Thou sholdest then be my wife
So syker as I have life
But this I say netheles
That I wol shape thyn encrees
What worlds good that thou wolt
baue / Axe of my yeft and you shall have
And she the kings words wise
Knelyng thanked in this wise
My lyege lord god mote you quyte
My fader here has but a lyte
Of waryson and that he wend
Had al be lost but now amend
Ye may well thorugh your noble grace
With yt the king right in his place
A none forth in the fressh hete
An Erldom which than was eschete
Was late fall in to his hand
Unto the knight with rent and land
Has you and with his chartre sesed
And thus was all the noise appesed
This maid which sat upon her knees
Before the kings charytees
Comen death and says evermore
My lyege lord right now to fore
Ye said as it is of record
That if my fadre were a lord
And pere unto these other great
Ye wolden not else let
That I ne should be your wife
And thus wot enery worthy life
A kings word mote be holden
For thy my lord if that ye wolden
So great a charity fulfylle
God wot it were well my will
For he which was a bachilere
My fadre is now made a pere
So when as ever that I came
An earls daughter now I am
This young king which plesyd all
Her beauty and her wit with all
As he that wae with love hente
A none thereto yaf his assente
He might not the maid asterte
That she nys lady of his heart
So that he took her to his wife
To hold while that he has life
And thus ye king toward this knyt
Acordeth to him as it is right
And over this good is to wit
In the Cronyes as it is write
This noble king of whom I told
Of Spain by tho days old
The kingdom had in governance
And as the book makes remembrance
Alphons was his propre name
The knight also if I shall name
Dom Petro hight / and as men tell
His daughter wise Petronelle
Was cleped which was full of grace
And that was seen in thylk place
Where she her fadre out of tene
Has breut and made her self a queen
Of that she has so well disclosed
The points whereof she was opposed
Confessor
Lo now my sone as thou might here
Of all this thing to my matere
But one I take and that is pride
To whom no grace may betyde
In heuene he fell out of his stead
And paradys him was forbede
The good men in earth him hate
So that to hell he mote algate
Where every virtue shall be weyued
And every vice be received
But Humblesse is al other wise
Which most is worthy and no repryse
It takes again both soft and fair
If any thing stant in contrayre
With humble speech it is redressed
Thus was this young maid blessed
The which I spak of now to fore
Her fadre life she gat therefore
And wanne with all the kings love
For thy my sone if thou wolt love
It sytt the well to love pride
And take Humblesse on thy side
The more of grace thou shall get
Amans
My fadre I wol not foryete
Of this yt ye have told me here
And if that any such manner
Of humble port may love appaye
Here afterward I thenke assaye
But now over I beseech
That ye more of my shryfte seche
Confessor
My good sone it shall be do
Now herkne and lay an ere to
For as tonchand of pride fair
Als ferforth as I can declare
In cause of vice in cause of love
That thou have pleyne herd above
So that there is no more to seye
Touchend of that but other weye
Touchend envy I thynk to tell
Which has by propre kind of hell
Without cause to mysdo
Toward him self and other mo
Here afterward as I understand
Thou shall the spyces as they stand

hOw after pride the second
There is which many a woe full stou^d
To wards other beryth a^boute
Within him self and not without
For in his thought he brenneth ever
When that he wot another lever
Or more virtuous than he
Which passes him in his degree
Whereof he takes his maladye
That vice is cleped hoote envy
For thy my sone if it be so
That ye art or have ben one of tho
As for to speak in loves cas
If ever yet thyn heart was
Seek of other men's hele
So god auannce my quarele
My fadre ye a thousand sithe
When I have seen another blythe
Of love and a goodly chere
Ethna which brenneth year byyere
Was than not so hoote as I
Of thylk for which pryuely
Mine hertes thought within brenneth
The ship which on the wawe renneth
And is forstormed and for blow
Is not more payned for athrowe
Than I am than when I se
Another which that passes me
In that fortune of loves yefte
But fadre this I tell in shryfte
That now here but in a place
For who that seche and find grace
In other stead it may naught grieve
But this ye may right well believe
Toward my lady that I serve
Though that I wist for to sterue
Mine heart is full of such folly
That I my self may not chastye
When I the court see of Cupyde
Approach unto my lady side
Of hem that lusty ben and fresshe
Though it avail hem not a resshe
But only that they ben of speech
My sorrow is than not to seche
But when they rownen in her ere
Then grows al my most fere
And namely when they talen long
My sorrows be than so strong
Of that I se hem well at ease
I can not tell my disease
But sire as of my lady selue
Though she have wowers x or twelve
For no mystrust I have of hire
Me greueth nonght for certes sire
I trow in all this world to seche
Nys woman that in deed and speech
Wol better auyse her what she does
Ne better for to sey a soth
Keep her honor at al tide
And yet get her a thank beside
But netheles I am be know
That when I see any throw
Or else if it I may here
That she make any man good chere
Though I thereof have not to done
My thought wol entermete sone
For though I be my self strange
Envy makes mine heart change
That I am sorowfully be stad
Of that I se another glad
With her but of other all
Of love what so may byfalle
Or that he fail or that he speed
Thereof take I but little head
Now have I said my fader all
And of this point in specyal
As ferforthly as I have wist
Now axe fadre what you list
Confessor
My sone or I axe any more
I think somdele for thy lore
Tell an example of this matter
Touchend envy as thou shall here
Though it be not the hounds kind
Write in Cyuyle this I find
To ete chaf yet wol I werne
An ox which comes to the herne
Thereof to take any fode
And thus who that it understood
It stant of love many a place
Who that is out of loves grace
He would another should faylle
And may him self not auaylle
And if he may put any lettr
He death all that he may to let
Whereof I find as thou shall wit
To this purpoos a tale write
hIc ponit Confessor Exemplum contra istos saltem qui in amoris causa aliorum
gaudijs inuidentes ne^uaquam per hoc sibi ipsis proficiunt / Et narrat qualiter
Mundus Miles noi^e Acis quem Galathea Numpha pulcherrima toto cord peramauit
cum ipsi sub quadam rupe Iuxta litus maris colloquium ad inuicem habuerunt /
Polophemus gigas concussa rupe mag nam inde partem super caput Acis ab alto
percipiens Ipsum per inuidiam in terfecit / Et cum ipse super hoc dictam
Galatheam rapere voluisset Neptunus gigantem obsistens Ipsam inuolutum salua
custodia preseruauit / Sed et dij miserti corpus Acis defuncti in fonte^ aque
dulcissime subito transmutarant

There ben of such mo than xij
That be not able of hem selue
To get love and for envy
Upon al other they aspye
And for hem lacks that they would
They keep that none other should
Touchend of love his cause speed
Whereof a great ensample I read
Which unto this matter acordeth
As Ouyde in his book records
How Polyphemus whilome wrout
When that he Galathe bysought
Of love which he may not latche
That made him for to wait and watch
By all weyes how it ferde
Till at the last he knew and herd
How that another had leave
To love there as he mote leave
As for to speak of any speed
So that he knew none other read
But for to wayten upon all
Till he may see the chance fall
That he her might grieve
Which by him self may not acheue
This Galathe seyth the poet
Above al other was unmeet
Of beauty that men than knew
And had a lusty love and true
A bachyleer in his degree
Right such another as was he
On whom she has her heart set
So that it might naught be let
For yefte ne for no byhest
That she ne was al at his hest
This young knight Acis was hot
Which her ageynward also hot
Al only loves and no mo
Hereof was polyphemus woe
Thorugh pure envy and ever aspyede
And wayteth upon every side
When he to geder might se
This young Acis with / galathe
So long he wayteth to and fro
Till at the last he found hem two
In pryue place where they stood
To speak and have here words good
The place where as he hem syghe
It was under a bank nyghe
The great see and he above
Stood and byhelde the lusty love
Which each of hem to other made
With goodly there and words glade
That al his heart has set a fire
Of pure envy and as a fire
Which flies out of a mighty bow
Awey he fled for a throw
As he that was for love wood
When that he saw how it stood
This Polypheme a geaunt was
And when he saw the soth cas
How Galathe him has forsaken
And Acis to here love taken
His heart may it not forbere
That he ne roreth as a bear
And as it were a wild best
In whom no reason might areste
He ran Ethna the hell about
Where never yet the fire was out
Fulfilled of sorrow and great disease
That he saw Acis well at ease
Till at the last he him bythought
As he which al envy sought
And torneth to the bank again
Where he with Galathe has seyne
Acis whom he thought to grieve
Though he him self may not releue
This Geaunt with his rude might
Part of the bank he shoof down right
The which even upon Acis fylle
So that with falling of this hylle
This Polyphemus Acys slough
Whereof she made sorrow enough
And as she fled from the land
Neptunus took her by the hond
And kept her in so fast a plac
Fro Polypheme and his manace
That he with his false envy
Ne might atteyne her company
This Galathe of whom I speak
That of her self may not be wreke
Withouten any semblaunt feyned
She has her loves death compleyned
And with her sorrow and with her woe
She has the goddis moved so
That they of pity and of grace
Have Acis in the same place
There he lay deed unto a well
Transformed as the books tell
With fressh stremes and with clear
As he whilome with lusty chere
Was fresshe his lust for to queme
And with his rude Polypheme
For his envy and for his hate
They were wroth and thus algate
Confessor
My sone thou might understand
That if thou wolt in grace stand
With love thou must leave envy
And as thou wylt for thy party
Toward thy love stand fre
So must thou suffer another be
What so byfalle upon thy chance
For it is a unwise vengeance
Which to none other man's lefe
And is unto him self grefe
Amans
My fader this ensample is good
But how so ever that it stood
With Polyphemus lone as tho
It shall not stand with me so
To worchen any felonye

I wot not one of al good
But netheles such as they be /

Which ^l^ped is detractyon
And to conferme his actyon

O where behind a man's bak

As he yt was which has yt herauldye
Of hem that vsen for to lie
For as the nettle which up renneth

Of whose nature that I find
That in the hotest of the day

To wards other such as they find
That set hem often fer behind
When that they wenen be before
My good sone and thou therefore
Be ware and leave thy wicked speech
Whereof has fallen often wreche
To many a man before this time
For who so wol his hands time
They must be the more vncleue
For many a mote shall be seen
That wol not else eleue there
And that should every wise man fere
For who so wol another blame
He sekyth often his own shame
Which else might be right stylle
For thy if that it be thy will
To stand upon amendment
A tale of great entendemet
A think to tell for thy sake
Whereof thou might ensample take

mortaliter accusauit dicens quod ipse non solum patrem sed and totum Macedonij
regnu^ Romany hostibus proditurie vendidisset. quem super hoc in iudicinm
producens testibus que judicibns auro subornatis quamuis falsissime morte
condempnatum e^^cit / quo defuncto eciam et pater infea breue postea mortuus
est / Et Persio successiue regnante deus huius detractionis iuuidiam abhorrens
Ipsum cum bniuersa suorum pugnatorum multitudine extra Dauubij fluuium ab
emilio tunc Romanorum Consule even tu bellico interfeci fortunauit / ita quod
ab illo die Macedonij potestas penitus des tructa Romano Imperio subiugata de
seruiuit / and eius detractio quam contra a^^um conspirauerat in sui ipsius
diffamacionem pro perpetuo diuulgata consistit

IN'a Cronyque as thou shall wit
A great ensample I find write
Which I shall tell upon this thing
Phelyp of Macedonye the king
Two sons had he by his wife
Whose fame is yet in greece ryf
Demetrius the first brother
Was hot and Perseus that other
Demetrius they sayden tho
The better knight was of tho
To whom the land was attendanut
As he which heir was apparaunt
To regne after his fadre day
But that / thing which no water may
Quench in this world but ever brenneth.
In to his brother heart renneth
The proud envy of that he sygh^
His brother should clynne on hyg^^
And he to him than mote obey
That may he suffer by no wey^
With strength durst he no thing sto^^
So took he lesyng upon hand
When he sygh time and spak thereto
For it byfelle that time so
His fadre great werres had
With Rome which he streyt lad
Thorugh myty strength of his ma^hod
As he which has yuough knygthod
And often him had sore grieved
But or the werre were acheued
As he was upon ordinance
At home in greece it fell par chance
Demetaus which often about
Rydend was stood that time out
So that this Perse in his absence
Which bare the tongue of pestylence
With falls words which he feyneth
Upen his own brother pleyneth
In pryuete behind his bak
And to his fadre thus he spak
My dear fadre I am hold
By wey of kind as reason would
That I fro you shall no thing hyde
Which might torn in any side
In your estate to greuaunce
For thy mine hertes obeysaunce
Toward you I thenke to keep
For it is good ye take keep
Upon a thing which is me told
My brother has us al sold
To hem of Rome and you also
For then they behote him tho
That he with them shall regne in pees
Thus has he cast for his encres
That your estate shall go to naught
And thus to prove shall be brought
So ferforth that I undertake
It shall not well mow be forsake
The king upon his tale ansuerd
And said if this thing which he herd
Be soth and may be brought to prove
It shall not be to his behoue
Which us has shapen so the werst
For he him self shall be the ferst
That shall be deed if / that I may
Thus afterward upon a day
When that Demetrius was come
Anon his fadre has him nome
And bad to his brother Perse
That he his tale shall reherce
Of thylk treson which he told
And which al untruth would
Counseylleth that so high a need
Be treted where as it may speed
In common place of jugement
The king thereto yafe his assent
Demetrius was put in hold
Whereof that Perseus was bold
Thus stood the troth under ye charge
And the falshede goth at large
Which thou^gh byhest has overcome
The grettest of the lords some
That preuelyche of his acord
They stond as witness of record
The Judge was made favorable
Thus was the law deceyuable
So ferforth that the fronth fond
Rescouse none and thus the land
Forth with the king deceived were
The gyliles was dampened there
And deyde upon acusement
But such a falls conspyrement
Though it be preuy for a throw
God would not it were unknow
And yt was after ward well proved
In him which has yt death co^troued
Of that his brother was so slain
This Perseus was wondre fayn
As he that*tho was apparau^t
Upon the regne and expectau^t
Whereof he wax so proud and beyn
That he his fadre in dysdeyn
Has take and set at none acompte
As he which thout him to surmou^te
That where he was first de bonayr^
He was tho rebelle and contrayre
And not as heyr but as a king
He took upon him in all thing
Of malice and of tyranny
In contempt of Regalye
Lived his fadre and so wrought
That when the fadre him bethought
And saw to whedyr side it droughe
Anon he wist well enough
How Perse his false tongue
Has so thenuyous belle ronge
That he has slain his own brother
Whereof as then he knew none other
But suddenly the Judge he nome
Which corrupt sat upon the dome
In such a wise and has him pressed
That he the soth him has confessed
Of all that he has spoke and do
More sorry than the king was tho
Was never man upon this molde
And thought in certain that he would
^engeaunce take upon this wrong
But the other party was so strongr
That for the law of no statute
There may no right be execute
And upon this dyuysyon
The land was turned up so down
Whereof his herb is so distraught
That he for pure sorrow has caught
The maladye of which nature
Is queynt in every creature
And when this king is passed thus
This false tonged Perseus
The regyment has vnderfonge
But there may no thing stond long
Which is not upon truth grounded
For god which has al thing bou^ded
And saw the falshede of his gyle
Has set him but a little while
That he shall regne upon depose
For suddenly as the rose
So suddenly down he fell
In thylk time it so byfelle
This new king of new pride
With strength shope him for to ride
And said he would Rome waste
Whereof he made a besy haste
And has assembled him an host
In all that ever he might most
What man that might wepen be re
Of al he would none forbe re
So that it might not be nombred
The folk which was encombred
Thorugh him yt god would overthrow
Anon it was at Rome know
The pomp which that Perse lad
And the Romans that time had
A consul which cleped was thus
The name Panle Emilius
A noble and a worthy knight with all
And he which cheef was of all
This werre on hond has undertake
And when he should his leave take
Of a young daughter which was his
She wept and what cause it is
He axeth and she him ansuereth
That Perseus is deed and he it hereth
And wondreth what she mean would
And upon childehode him told
That Perse his little hound is deed
Withethat he pulls up his head
And made right a glad vysage
And said how that was a presage
Touchend unto that other Perse
How that fortune him shald adverse
He seyth for such a prenostyke
Most of an hound was to him like
For as it is an hounds kind
To berke upon a man behind
Right so behind his broders bak
With falls words which he spak
He has do slain and that is routhe
But he which hates al untruth
The high god it shall redress
For so my daughter prophetess
Forth with her little hounds death
Betokens and thus forth he geth
Conforted of this euydeuc^
With the Romans in his defense
Again the greeks that be comende
This Perseus as naught semende
This meschyef which that him abode
With all his multitude rode
And prayed him upon the thing
Of that he was bycomen a king
And how he had his Royalme get
That he has all the right foryete
Which longs unto governance
Whereof thorugh good ordinance
It fell upon the winter tide
That with his host he should ride
Oner Dauubye thylke flood
Which al be frorn than stood
So hard that he wend well
To pass but the blind wheel
Which torneth often or men beware
Thylk ye which horse men bare
To brak so that a great party
Was dreynt of the chyualrye
The rereward it took awey
Came none of hem to land drey
Paulus the worthy knyt romeyn
By his aspye it herd seyn
And hastes all that he may
So that upon that other day
He came where he this host byheld
And that was in a large feld
Where the baners ben displayed
He has anon his men arrayed
And when that he was enbataylled
He goth and has the feld assaylled
And slough and took all that he fond
Whereof the Macedonye land
Which through king alisa^der is honored /
Long time stood was than devoured /
To Perse and al infortune
^^^y wit so that the comune
Of all the land his heir exyle
And he dyspeyred for the while
Desguysed in a power wede
To Rome goth and there for need
The ^^aft which thylk time was
To worken in lawn^ and in bras
He lerneth for his sustenaunce
Such was the sons purueaunce
And of his fadre it is said
In strong prison that he was laid
In Albe where that he was deed
For honger and for defaulte of bread
The hounde was token of prophecye
That lyche an hound he should dye
Which lyche was of condycyon
When he with detractyon
Bark on his brother so behind
Coufessor
Lo what proufyde a man may find
Which hyndre wol another wight
For thy with all thyn hool might
My sone eschew thylk vice.
Amans
My fadre else were I nyce
For ye thereof so well have spoke
That it is in mine heart look
And ever shall but of envy
If there be more in his baylye
Toward love say me what
My sone as gyle under the hat
With sleyghtes of a Tregetour
Is hyd envy of such color
Has yet the fourth deceyuaunt
The which is cleped falls semblaunt
Whereof the matter and the form
Now herkne and I the shall inform

hIc tractat Confessor super quarta specie Inuidie que dissimulacio dicitur

oF falls se^blau^t if I shall tell
Above al other it is ye well
Out of yt which deceyt flows
There is no man so wise that knows
Of thylkf lood which is the tide
Ne how he should him self guide
To take sauf passage there
And yet the wynd to man's ere
Is soft and as it seems out
It makes clear weder al about
But though it seem it is not so
For falls semblaunt has ever moo
Of his counseyl in company
The derke untrue Ipocrysye
Whoos word destroys in his thout
For thy they be to gyder brought
Of one couyne of one household
As it shall after ward thus be told
Of falls semblaunt it needs naught
To tell of old ensamples ought
For all day in experyence
A man may see thylk euydence
Of fair words which he hereth
But yet the barge of envy stereth
And halt it ever from the land
Which falls se^blau^t with oore in hond
It roweth and wol not arryue
But let it on the wawes drive
In great tempest and great debate
Whereof that love and his estate
Empeyreth and therefore I read
My sone that thou flee and dread
This vice and what that other seyn
Let thy semblaunt be true and pleyn
For falls semblaunt is thylk vice
Which never was without office
Where that envy thinks to gyle
He shall before that ylke while
Of pryue counseylle be messagere
For when his semblaunt is most clear
Than is he most derke in his thought
Though man him se they know him
nout / But as it shows in the glass
Thing which theryn never was
So shows it in his vysage
That never was in his courage
Thus does al his thing with sleyght
Now lay thy conscience in weight
My good soue and shryue the here
If thou were ever customere
To falls semblaunt in any wise
For ought I can me yet auyse
My good fadre certes no
For I for love have do so
Now axe I would pray you
For else I wot never bow
Of falls semblau^t how yt I have gy^t
My sone and sethyn that thou wylt
That I shall axe gabbe naught
But tell if ever was thy thought
With falls semblaunt and couerture
To wit of any creature
How that he was with love stad
So weary or sorry or he were glad
When thou wystyst how it were
All that he rouneth in thyn ere
Thou toldest forth in other place
To setten him fro loves grace
Of that woman that him best list
Theryn no man his counseyll wist
But thou by whom he was deceive*
Of love and from his purpoos weyued
And thoughtest at his dysturbaunce
Thyn own cause should auaunce
As who seyth I am so secret
There may no man's pryuete
Beh^led halue so well as mine
Art thou my sone of such engyn
Tell on / My good fadre nay
As for the more party I say
But of somdele I am byknowe
That*I may stand in thylk row
Among hem that saundres use
I wol me not thereof excuse
That I with such color ne steyne
When I my best semblaunt feyne
Tell my fela we of that I wot
Al his counseylle both cold and hot
For by that cause I make him chere
Till I his love know and here
And if so be mine heart soucheth
That ought unto my lady touches
Of love that he would me tell
Anon I run unto the well
And cast water in to the fire
So that his carte amyd the fire
By that I have his counseyll know
Full often sith I overthrow
When that he weneth best to stand
But this I do you to understand
If that a man love else where
So that my lady be naught there
And he me tell he wol it hyde
There shall no word escape aside
Forth with deceypt of no semblaunt
To him break I none covenant
Me lyketh not in other place
To let no man of his grace
Ne for to be Inquesyty^
To know another man's life
Where that he love or love naught
That toncheth no thing to my thout
But al it passes thorugh mine ere
Right as a thing that never were
And is foryete and laid aside
But if it touches any side
My lady as I have er spoken
Mine eres be than naught loken
For certes when that by tyt
My will mine heart and al my wit
Ben fully set to harken and spear
What any man wol say of here
Thus have I feyned company
Full often for I would aspye
What thing it is that any man
Tell of my worthy lady can
And for two causes I do this
The first cause whereof is
At that I might harken and seek
That any man of her myspeke
I wol excuse her so fully
That when she wist it verily
Mine hope should be the more
To hane her thank for evermore
That other cause I you assure
Is why that I see couerture
Have feyned semblaunt oftyme
To them that passen al day byme
And ben^ lovers as well as I
For this I wene truly
That there is of hem al none
That they ne louen euerychone
My lady sothelyche I leave
And durst sytten it in preue
Is none so wise that should asterte
But he were lustles in his heart
For why and he my lady syghe
Her vysage and her goodly eye
But he her loved or he went
And for that such is mine intent
That is the cause of mine aspye
Why that I feyne company
And make follow over al
For gladly would I known al
And hold me covert always
That I fulofte ye or nay
Ne list ansuere in any wise
But feynyng semblaunt as the wise
And harken tales till I know
My lady lovers al on row
And when I here how they have wrought /
I fare as though I herd it nout.
And as I no word understood
But that is no thing for her good
For leueth well soth it is
That when I know it so is
I wol but fordren hem a lyte
But all the werst I can endyte
I tell it to my lady plat
For forthryng of mine own estat
And hyndre them all that I may
But for all that yet dar I say
I find unto my self no bote
Al though mine heart needs mote
Though of love all that I here
Dyscouer unto my lady dear
For in good feyth I have no might
To hele fro that sweet wight
If that it touches her any thing
But this wot well the heaven king
That sythen first this world bygan
Unto none other strannge man
Ne feyned I semblannt ne chere
To wit or axe of this matere
Though yt he loves x or twelve
When it was naught my lady selue
But if he would axe any read
Al onlyche of his own head
How he with other love ferde
His tales with mine eres I herd
But to mine heart came it naught
Ne sanke no depper in my thought
Bnt held counseylle as I was bid
And told it never m other stead
But let it pass^as it come
Now fadre say what is thy dome
And how thou wolt yt I be peyned
For falls semblan^t as I have feyned
My sone if reason be well peised
There may no virtue be up raised
Ne vice none be set in pryse
For thy my sone if thou be wise
Do no vyser upon my face
Which wol not thyn heart embrace
For if thou do within a throw
To another man it shall be know
So myt thou lightely fall in blame
And lose a great part of thy name
And netheles in this degree
Full oftyme thou might se
Of such men as now a day
This vice set in assay
I speak for no man's blame
But for to warn the thy shame
My sone as I may here talk
In every place where I walk
I not if it be so or none
But it is many days gone
That I first herd tell this
How falls semblau^t has be and is
Most commonly from year to year
With hem that duelle among us here
Of such as we Lumbardes call
For they be the slyest of all
So as men seyn in Town about
To feyne and show thing without
Which is reuers to that within
Whereof that they often wyn
When they by reason should lose
They ben the last and yet they chief
And we first and yet behind
We gone where as we should find
The proufyte of our own land
Thus gone they fre without bond
To done her proufyte al at large
And other men bear all the charge
Of Lumbardes unto this couyne
Which al lands conne engyne
May falls semblaunt in especyal
Br lykened for they ever al
Where that they thynken for to duelle
Among them self so as they tell
First ben informed for to lere
A craft which cleped is faucrere
For if faucrere come about
Than afterward stant no doubt
To void with a subtyle hand
The best goods of the land
And bring chaf and take corn
Where as faucrere goth to forn
In all his wey he fynt no let
That do^e can none vssher shet
In which him list to take enter
And thus the counseyll most secre
Of every thing faucrere knows
Which in to strange place he blows
Which he wot it may most grieve
And thus faucrere makes believe
So that full often he has deceived
Er that he may ben apperceyued
Thus is his vice for to dread
For who these old books read
Of such ensamples as were ar
Him ought be the more war
Of al tho that feynen chere
Whereof thou shall a tale here

oF falls semblaunt which is believed /
Full many a worthy
wight is grieved.
And was long time or he was bore
To the my sone I will therefore
A tale tell of falls semblaunt
Which falseth many a covenant
And many a fraud of falls cou^seylle
There be honged upon his seylle
And that abouten gylteles
Both Deyanyre and hercules
The which in great dysese fell
Thorugh falls semblau^t as I shall tell
When hercules within a throw
Al only has his heart throw
Upon the fair Deyanyre
It fell him on a day desire
Upon a river as he stood
That pass he would over the flood
Without bote and with him led
His love but he was in dread
For tendrenesse of that sweet wight
For he knew not the forth aryght
There was a geaunt than nyghe
Which Nessus hight and when he syghe
This hercules and Deianyre
Within his heart he began conspyre
As he which thought his trecherye
Has Hercules in great envy
Which he bare in his heart look
And than he thought it shall be wroke
But he ne durst netheles
Ayene this worthy Hercules
Fall in debate as for to fight
But feyned semblaunt al by sleyght
Of friendship and of al good
And comes where as they both stood
And makes hem all the chere he can
And says that here own man
He is / al ready for to do
What thing he may and it fell so
That than upon his semblaunt tryst
And axeth hem if that they wist
What thing were best to done
So that they myghten sauf and sont
The water pass he and she
And when Nessus the pryuete
Knew we of heart what it meant
As he that was double of intent
He made hem right a glad vysage
And when he herd of the passage
On him and her he thought gyle
And feyneth semblaunt for a while
But he thought al another wise
To done hem plesaunce and service
This Nessus with his words slyghe
Yaf counseylle to fore her eye
Which seemed outward prouffytable
And was within deceyuable
He bad hem of the stremes deep
That they beware and take keep
So as they know not the compass
But for to help in such a cas
He says him self that for his ease
He would if yt it might hem please
The passage of the water take
And for this lady undertake
To bear her to that other stronde
And sauf to set her upon the land
And Hercules may then also
The weye know how he should go
And they thereto acorden all
But what as after shall byfalle
Well paid was hercules of this
And this Geaunt also glad is
And took his lady upon lofte
And set her on his shulder soft
And in the flood bygan to wade
And he which no grutchyng made
And bare her oner sauf and sou^de
But when he stood on dry gronnd
And Hercules was far behind
He set his truth al out of mind
Who so there be lefe or loath
With Deianyre and forth he goth
As he thought to dysseuer
The company of hem for ever
When Hercules thereof took head
As fast as ever he might him speed
He hyeth after in a throw
And happens that he had a bow
The which in all have he bend
As he that would an arowe send
Which he to fore had venymed
He has so well his shot tymed
That him thorugh the body smet
And thus the false wight he let
But lest now such a felonye
When Nessus wist he should dye
He took to Deianyre his shert
Which with the blood was of his heart
Thorugh out desteyned over al
Told how she so^t keep shall
And pryuely to her intent
That if her lord his heart went
To love in any other place
This shyrt he says has such a grace
That if she may so mochel make
That he the shyrte upon him take
He shall al other let in veyn
And torn m to her love ageyn
Who was so glad but Deianyre
Her heart her thought was on a fire
Till it was in her Cofer look
So that thereof no word was spoke
The days gone the years pass
The hertes waxen less and less
Of hem that be to love untrue
This Hercules with heart new
His heart has set on Eolen
And thereof speken al men
This Eolen this fair maid
Was as men thylk time said
The kings daughter of Euryce
And she made Hercules so nyce
Upon her love and so assote
That he him clotheth in her cote
And she in his was clothed often
And thus feblesse is set alofte
And strength was put under foot
There can no man thereof do bo^e
When Deianyre has herd this speech
There was no sorrow for to seche
Of other help wot she none
But goth unto her coufer anon
With wepeud eye and woeful heart
She took out thylk unhappy sherte
And as she wend well to do
And brought her work about so
That Hercules this shert on deed
Of such intent and as she was bid
Of Nessus and as I said er
But that therefore was she not ye ner
And no fortune may be weyued
With falls semblaunt she was deceived
Then when she wend best have won
She lost all that she has bygonne
For thylk shert unto the bone
His body set a fire anon
And cleueth so it may not twynne
For the venym that was therynne
And he than as a wyld man
Unto the high wode ran
And as the clerk Ouyde tells
The great trees to the ground he felleth
With strength of his own might
And made an hughe fire vpryght
And lept him self therein at ones
And burnt him both flesh and bones
Which thing came thorugh falls se^bla^t
That falls Nessus the Geant
Made unto him and to his wife
Whereof that he has lost his life
And she also for euermo
For thy my sone or thou be woe
I read be well ware therefore
For when so great a man was lore
It ought to give a great conceypt
To warn al other of such deceypt
Grant mercy fader I am ware
So fer that I no more dare
Of falls semblaunt take acqueyntau^ce
But rather I wol do penance
That I have feyned chere or this
Now axe forth what so there ^s
Of that bylongeth to my shryfte
My sone yet there is the fyfte
Which is conceived of envy
And clepend is supplantarye
Thorugh whose compassement and gyle
Full many has lost his while
In love as well as other wise
Here after as I shall deuyse

tHe vice of Supplantacyon
With many a falls collacyon
Which he co^spireth'al unknow.
Full oftyme has overthrow
The worship of another man
So well no life awayte can
Ayene his sleyght for to cast
That he his purpoos at the last
Ne has or that it withset
But most of al his heart is set
In court upon these great offices
Of dygnytees and benefyces
Thus goth he with his sleyghte about
To hyndre and shoue another out
And stonden with his slyghe compass
In seed there another was
And so to set him self ynne
He r^ebeth not be so he win
Of that another man shall l^se
And thus full often chalk for chief
He changes with full little cost
Whereof another has the lost
And he the proufyt shall receive
For his fortune is to receive
And for to change upon the whele
His woo with other men's well
Of that another man avails
His astate thus up he hayleth
And takes the byrd to his beyete
Where other men the busshes beat
My sone and in the same wise
There be lovers of such empryse
That shapen hem to be relyeued
Where it is wrong to be achyeued
For it is an other man's right
Which he has take day and night
Ty keep for his own store
Toward him self for evermore
And is his propre by the law
Which thing that axeth no felawe
But they that worchen by supplauut
And take a part of thylk plant
Which he has for him self set
And so fulofte is al vnknet
That some man weneth be right fast
For supplaunt with his sly cast
Full often happens for to mow
Thing which another man has ^owe
And makes common of propyrte
With sleyghte and with subtylte
As men may seen from year to year
Thus cleymeth he the boot to stere
Of which another master is
For thy my sone if thou or this
Have ben of such professyon
Dyscouer thy Confession
Have thou supplanted any man
For ought that I you tell can
Mine holy fadre as of the deed
I am withouten any dread
And gilteles but of my thought
My censcyence excuse I naught
For were it wrong or were it right
Me lacks no thing but might
That I ne would long or this

By wey of Supplantacyon

Though it another man forthought

Of other wise I wol not say

My sone as of supplant
The dar not dread tant ne quant
As for no thing that I have herd
But only that thou have mysferd
Thynkend and me lyketh naught
For god beholt a man's thought
And if thou understood in soth
In loves cause what it does
A man to be a supplantour
Thou would for thyn honor
By double way take keep
First for thyn own estate keep
To be thy self so well be thought

That in wait at al assayes
Supplant of love in other ways
The leef full often for the lever
Forsakes and it has done ever

^F thylk cite cheef of all
Which men ye noble rome call
Er it was set to crystes feith
There was as the Cronyque seyth
An Emperor which it ladde
In pees that he no werres had
There was no thing dysobeysaunt

Of worlds fame and desirous

aT Rome as it has often fall
The vyker general of all

fOr Ioachym thylk abbot told
How such days sholden fall
That comonlyche in places all
The chapmen of such mercery
With fraud and with supplantary
So many sholden bye and selle
That he ne may for shame test
So foul a sin in man's ^re
But god forbede that it so were

For if the clerk be ware his feyth
In chapmanhode in such a feyre
The remenaunt mote needs empeyre
Of all that to the world bylongeth
For when that holy church wrongeth
I not what other thing shall be
And netheles at man's own eye
Envy for to be preferred
Has conscience so dyfferred
That no man looks to the vice
Which is the modre of malice
And that is thylk falls envy
Which causes many a trecherye
For where he may another see
That is more gracious than he /

But if he hinder such a wight
And that is well nyghe oueral
This vice is now so general

Envy if that I shall deseryue
He is not shapely for to wyue
In earth among the women here
For there is in him no matere
Whereof he might do plesaunce
First for his heavy contenaunce
Of that he seems ever vnglad
He is not able to be had
And eke he brenneth withynne
That kind may no proufyte win
Whereof he should his love please
For thylk blood which should have ease
To regne among the moist veins
Is dry of thylk unkindly peynes
Thorugh which envy is fyred ay
And thus by reason prove I may
That toward love envy is naught
And other wise if he besought
Upon what side as ever it fall
It is the werst vice of all
Which of him self has most malice
For understand that every vice
Some cause it has whereof it grows
But of envy no man knows
Fro whens he came but out of hell
For thus the wise clerks tell
That no spyryt but of malice
By wey of kind but on a vice
Is tempted and by such a way
Envy has kind put a way
And of malice has his sturyng
Whereof he makes his bakbytyng
And is him self thereof dyseased
So may there be no kind pleased
For ay the more that he enuyeth
The more ayene him self he plenyeth
Thus stant enuyt in good espeyr
To ben him self the deuels heyr
As he which is the next lyche
And forthest from the heaven rich
For there he may never wone
For thy my good dear sone
If thou would find a syker weye
To lone put envy aweye
Mine holy fadre reason would
That I this vice esche we should
But yet to strength my courage
If that ye would in advantage
Thereof set a recouere
It were to me a great desire
That I this vice might flee
Now understand my sone and see
There is physyk for the seek
And virtues for the vices eke
Who that the vices would esche we
He mote by reason than sewe
The virtues for by thylk weye
He may the vices done aweye
For they to gydre may not duelle
For as the water of a well
Of fire abateth the malice
Right so virtue fordoth the vice
Ayene envy is charity
Which i^ the modre of pity
That makes a man's heart tender
That it may no malice engendre
In him that is incline therein
For his courage is tempred so
That though he might him self releue
Yet would he not another grieve
But rather for to do plesaunce
He bears him self the greuaunce
So feign he would another case
Whereof my sone for thyn ease
Now ^ t^ne a tale which I read
And understand it well I read

IMong the books of latin
I find it write of Co^sta^tyn
The worthy emperor of rome
Such infortunes to him come
When he was in his lusty age
The lepre caught in his vysage
And so forth over al about
That he might not ryden out
So left he both shield and spear
As he that might him not bestere
And hold him in his chamber close
Thorugh all the world the fame arose
The great clerks ben assent
And come at his commaaundement
To trete upon this lords hele
So long they to geder dele
That they upon this medycyne
Appoynten hem and determyne
That in the manner as it stood
They would him bathe in childs blood
Within seven year age
For as they sayen that should a suage
The lepre and all the vyolence
Which that they knew of accidence
And not by wey of kind is fall
And thereto they acorden all
As for fynal conclusyon
And tolden her oppynyon
To the emperor and he anon
His counseyl took and therupone
With letters and with seals out
They send in every land about
The young children for to seche
Whoos blood they said should be leche
For themperours maladye
There was enough to weep and cry
Among the modres when they herd
How woefully this cause ferd
But netheles they mote bow
And thus women there come ynowe
With children soukend on their tete
There were many teres let
But were hem lyef or were hem loathe
The women and the children both
In to the paleys forth be brought
With many a sorry hertes thought
Of hem which of her body bore
The children had and so forlore
Within a while should see
The modres weep in her degree
And many of hem a swoune fall
The young babyes cryeden all
This noise arose this lord it herd
And looked out and how it ferde
He saw and as who said abrayd
Out of his sleep and thus he said
O thou dyuyne purueaunce
Which every man in the balaunce
Of kind have formed to be lyche
The pore is bore as is the rich
And dies in the same wise
Upon the fool upon the wise
Seken esse and hele enter comune
May not eschew that fortune
Which kind has in her law set
Her strength and beauty ben set
To every man a lyche fre
That she profereth no degree
As in the dysposycyon
Of bodily complexyon
And eke of soul reasonable
The pore child is bore as able
To virtue as the kings sone
For every man his own wone
After the lust of his assaye
The vice or / virtue chief may
Thus stand al men fraunchysed
But in estate they be devised
To sum worship and richesse
To some pouerte and dystresse
One lordeth another serves
But yet as every man deserves
The world yeueth not his yeftes here
But certes he has great matere
To be of good condycyon
Which has in his subiectyon
The men that been of his semblaunce
And eke he took a remembrance
How that he made law of kind
Would every man to law bind
And bad a man such as he would
Toward him self right such he should
Toward another done also
And thus this worthy lord al tho
Set in balaunce his own estate
And with him self stood in debate
And thought how it was not good
To see so mochel man's blood
Be spylt by cause of him alone
He saw also the great moan
Of that the moders were vnglade
And of the woe the children made
Whereof that his heart tendreth
And such pity within engenders
And that him was lever for to chese
His own body for to lose
Than see so great a mordre wrought
Upon the blood which gylteth naught
Thus for the pity which he took
Al other leches he forsook
And put him out of adventure
Al only in to gods cure
And says who that wol master be
He mote be servant to pity
So ferforth he was overcome
With charity that he has nome
His counseyll and his officers
And bad unto his tresorers
That they his tresour al about
Depart among the pouer route
And of wymmen and of children both
Whereof they might hem feed and clothe
And sothly borne home again
Without loss of any greyne
Thorugh charity thus he dyspendeth
His / good whereof he amendeth
The pouer people and countreuayleth
The harm that he hem so trauayleth
And thus the woeful nyghtes sorrow
To joy is turned on the morrow
Al was thankyng a^l was blyssyng
Which erst was weeping and cursyng
These women gone home glad enough
Echone of joy on other lough
And preyd for this lords hele
Which has relesed the quarele
And has his own will forsake
In charity for gods sake
But now here after thou shall here
What god has wrout in this matere
As he that does al equity
To him that wrought charity
He was ayeneward charytous
And to pity he was pytous
For it was never know yet
That charity geth vnaquit
The night when he was leyd to sleep
The high god which would him keep
Saint peter and saint Poule him send
By whom he would his lepre amend
They two to him slepend appear
Fro god and said in this manner
O Constantyn for thou have served
Pity thou have pity deserved
For thy thou shall such pity have
That god thorugh pity wol the sane
Thou shall so double hele find
For the first bodelyche kind
and for thy woeful soul also
Thou shall be hole of both two
And for thou shall not the despeyre
Thy lepre shall no more empeyre
Till thou wylt send thereupon
Unto the mount of Celyon
Where Syluestre and his clergy
To gyder duellen in company
For dread of the which many a day
Have ben a foo to Crystes lay
And have destroyed to mochel shame
The prechours of his holy name
But now thou have somdele appesed
Thy god and with good deed plesed
That thou thy pity have bywaryd
Upon the blood which you have spared
For thy to thy salvation
Thou shall have Informacyon
Such as Syluestre shall the teache
The needs of none other leche
This Emperor which all this herd
Grant mercy lord he ansuerd
I wol do as ye me say
But of one thing I would pray
What shall I tell unto Syluestre
Of your name or of your estre
And they him told what they hight
And forth with all out offhis sight
They passen up in to the heaven
And he awoke out of his sweuen
And clepeth and men come anon

In such a wise as hem tells

They have in all have sought

First how mankind was for^ore

Ayene the kind of man's wone

With flesh and blood in to the heuene

In flesh and blood he shall reform
When time comes the quyk and deed
At thylk woeful day of dread
Where every man shall take his dome
As well the master as the groom
The mighty kings retenue
That day may stand of no value

To stand upon his own deeds
And leave as other men's needs

The pledour and the ple shall fail

There may no gold the Judge plye

IF thou the vices lest know /
My sone it has not be unknow
Fro first that men their swerdes ground
That there is none upon ye ground.
A vice foreyn fro ye law
Whereof that many a good felawe
Has be dystraught by sodeyn chau^^^
And yet to kind no plesaunce
It does but where he most acheueth
His pur^^os most to kind he greueth

And is by name one of the seuene
Which often has set the world vneuent
And cleped is the cruel Ire
Whoos heart is evermore on fire
To speak amys and to do both
For his servants ben ever wroth
My good fadre tell me this
What thing is Ire. Sone it is
That in our English wrath is hot
Which has his words ay so hot
That al a man's pacyence
Is fyred of the vyolence
For he with him has ever five
Servants that helpen him to seryue
The first of hem Melancolye
Is cleped which m company
An honderd times in an our
Wol as an angry best loure
And no man wot the cause why
My sone shryue the now for thy

My fadre ye by saint Iulyen
But I untrue words use
I may me not thereof excuse
And al makes love well I wot
Of which mine heart is ever hot
So that I brenne as does a glede
For wrath that I may not speed
And thus full often a day for naught
Sauf onlyche of mine own thought
I am so with my seluen wroth
That how so that the game gothe
With other men I can not glade
But I am well the more vnglade
For that is other men's game
It torneth me to pure grame
Thus am I with my self oppressed
Of thought which I have impressed
That al wakyng I dreme and mete
That I with her alone mete
And prayed* her of some good ansuere
But the wol not gladly swear
She seyth me nay withouten oath
And thus wax I within wroth
That outward I am al affrayed
And so dystempered and so es^^ayed
A thousand times on a day

The which she said me to fore
Thus be my wits as forlore

How many years ben agone
Sith I have truly loved one
And never took of her head
And ever a lyche for to speed
I am the more fool with her dele
So that my hap and al my hele
Me thinks is ay the longer the far
That brings my gladship out of err
Whereof my wits ben empryred
And I as who says al dispeyred
For finally when that I muse
And thynk how she wol me refuse
I a^ with anger so bestad
For all this world might I be glad
And for the while that it lasts
Al up so down my joy it casts
And ^y the forther that I be
When I ne may my lady se
The more I am ready to wrath
That fo: the touching of a lathe
Or for the tornyng of a sere
I wode as does the wild see
And am so melancolyous
That there nys servant in mine house
Ne none of tho that be about
That each of hem ne stant in doubt
And wene that I would rave
For anger that they see me have
And so they wondre more and less
That they seen it ouerpasse*
But fadre if it so betyde

And than her lyketh I wys
To speak a goodly word vntome
For all the gold that is in Rome
Ne couth I after that be wroth
But al mine anger over goth
So glad I am of the presence
Of her that I al offense
Foryete as though it were naught
So over glad is my thought
And* netheles the soth to tell
A ^ene word if it so byfelle

I torn and am with that also mate

^Her was a king which Eolus
Was hot and it befell him thus
That he two children had fair
The sone cheped was Machayre
The daughter Canace hight
By day both and este by night
While they be young of common wone

oF wrath. the second is cheste
Which has the wyndes of tempest
To keep and many a sodeyne blast
He blows whereof ben aghast

sOne after the destructyon
When troy was al beat down
And slain was ^amus ye king
The gregoys which of all this thing
Ben cause tornen home ageyn
There may no man his hop wythseyn
It has been seen and felt full often
The hard time after the soft
By see forth as they homeward went
A rage of great tempest hem hent
Juno let bend her party bow
The s^y was derk ye wynd began blow
The fyry welken bygan to thonder
As though ye world should al a sonder
From heaven out of the water gates
The reyny storm fell down algates
And al her tacle made vnwelde
That noman might him selfbyheld^
There may men here shipmen cry
That stood in aunter for to dye
He that behind sat to stere
May not the for stern here
The ship arose again the wawes
The lodesman has lost his laws
The sea on beat on every side
They nysten what fortune abide
But setten hem al at gods will
Where he would hem self save or spylle
And thylk time fell thus
There was a king which Namplus
Was hot and he a sone had
At Troy which the gregoys ^ad
As he that was made prince of all
Till that fortune let him fall
His name was palamydes
But thorugh an hate netheles
Of sum of hem his death was cast
And he by treson over cast
His fadee when he herd it tell
He swore if ever his time fell
He would him venge if that he might
And thereto his auowe he hight
And thus this king through preuy
hate / Abode upon a wait algate
For he was not of such empryse
To auengyn him in open wise
The fame which goth wide where
Makes know how yt ye gregois were
Home with all her felaushyp
Fro Troy upon the sea by ship
Namplus when he this understood
And knew the tides of the flood
And saw the wynd blow to the land
A great deceypt anon he fond
Of preuy hate as thou shall here
Whereof I tell all this matere
This king the weder he began behold
And wist well that they moten hold
Her course endelong the march right
And made upon the derk night
Of great shydes and of blokkes
Gre^^ fire again the great rokkes
To show upon the hills high
So that the flete of greece it syghe
So it fell right as he thought
This flete which an haven sought
Tho bright fyres saw a far
And they hem drawn ner and nerre
And wyste well and understood
How all that fire was made for good
To show where men should aryue
And thyderward they hasten blyue
And in semblau^t as men seyn is gyle
And that was proved thylk while
The ship which we^d him self accroche
Droof al to pyeces on the roche
And so deden ten or twelve
There might no man help him selue
For there they wenden death escape
Withouten help her death was shape
Thus they that comen first to fore
Upon the Rokkes ben forlore
But through noise and their cry
The other were al ware thereby
And when they began to row
Tho might they the soth kuowe
That where they wend friends find
They fond friendship al behind
The land was than sone weyued
Where that they hadden be de^eyued
And took hem to the high see
Thereto they sayden all ye
Fro that day forth where they were
Of that they have assayed there
My sone whereof thou might auyse
How fraud stant in many wise
Among hem that gyle think
There is no s^ryueyne with his ynke
Which half the fraud write can
That stant in such a manner man
For thy the wise men ne demen
That things after that they semen
But after that they know and find
The myrrour shows in his kind
As has all the word withynne
And is in sothe no thing withynne
And so fares hate for a throw
Till a man has overthrow
Shall no man know by his chere
Which is auaunt and which is ar^re
For thy my sone think on this
Confessor
My fadre so I wol Iwys
And if there more of wrath be
Now axe for charity
As y^ by your books know
And I the soth shall be know

mY sone thou shall understand
That yet to ward wrath stand
Of dedely vices other two
And for to tell her names so
It is conte^^ and homicide
That be to geder on every side
Contake so as the books seyn
Foolhast has to his chamberleyn
Whoos counseyl al unadvised
Is pacyence most despised
Till homycyde with him mete
Fro mercy they be al unmeet
And thus be they the worst of all
Of hem which unto wrath fall
In deed both and eke in thought
For they acompten their wrath nout
But if there be shedyng of blood
And thus lyche a best wode
They known not the good of life
Be so they have other swerd or knyf
Her dedely wrath for to wreke
Of pity list hem not to speak
None other reason they ne song
But that they have mygh^^o strong
But ware him well in other place
Where every man behooves grace
But there I trow it shall him fail
To whom no mercy might avail
But wron ^hten upon Tyranny
That no pity might hem plye
Now tell my sone / my fader what
If thou have be culpable of that
My fadre nay christ me forbede
I speak only for the deed
Of which I was never culpable
With no cause reasonable
But this is not to my matere
Of shryfte why we sytten here
For we be set to shryue of love
As we begone first above
And netheles I am beknowe
That as touchend of loves throw
When my wits over wend
Mine hertes contek has none end
But ever stant upon debate
To great dysese of mine estate
As for the time that it lasts
For when my fortune ouercasteth
Her whele and is to me so strange
And I see she wol not change
Than cast I all the world about
And think how I at home in doubt
Have al my time in vein fpended
And see not how to be amended
But rather for to be empeyred
As he that is well nyhe despeyred
For I ne may no thank deserve
And ever I love and ever I serve
And ever I am a lyche nere
Thus for I stand in such a were
I am as who says out of herre
And thus upon my self I werre
I bring and put out al pees
That I fulofte in such a rees
Am weary of mine own life
So that of contek and of stryf
I am byknowe and have ansuerd
As ye my fadre now have herd
Mine heart is wonderly begone
Which counseyl whereof wyt^e is one
Which has reason in company
I again which stand party
Will which has hope at acord
And thus these bryngen up dyscord
Wit and reason counseylen often
That mine heart should soft
And that I should well renew
And put out of retenue
Or ^lles hold him under foot
For as they seyne if that he mote
His own reule have upon hand
There shall no wit be understand
Of hope and so they tellen this
That over al where that he is
He set the heart in champartye
With wysshyng and with fantasye
And is not tr^we of that he seyth
So that in him there is no feyth
Thus with reason and wit auysed
Is wit and hope al day despised
Reason says that I should leave
To love where there is no leave
To speed and will says ag^yn
That such an heart is to vyleyn
Which dar not leave till that he speed
Lat hope serve at such a need
He seyth eke where an heart sit
Al governed after wit
He has his lives lust for lore
And thus mine heart is al to ^^re
Of such a con^^ck as they make
But yet I may not well forsake
That he nys master of my thought
Or that I speed or speak naught
Thou do my sone against the right
But love is of so great might
His law may no man refuse
So might thou the better excuse
And netheles thou shall be learned
That will should be governed
Of reason more than of kind
Whereof a tale write I find
hIc ponit Co^sessoz Exe^plu^ quod oi^s Impetuosa volu^tas sit discrecionis

a Philosopher whylome men told
That whylome by days old
And Dyogenes than he hight
So old he was that he ne might
The worlds trauayll and for the best
He shope for to take his rest
And duellyth at home in such a wise
That nyhe his house he let deuyse
Endelong up an extre
To set a Tonne in such degree
He it might torn about
Whereof an end was taken out
For therein sytte he should
And torn him self as he would
And take the eyer and see the heuene
And deem of the planetes seuene
As he which couthe much what
And thus full often there he sat
To muse in his philosophye
Sool without company
So that upon a morrow tide
A thing which should so betyde
When he was set where him list
To look upon the son vpryst
Whereof the propyrtees he syghe
It fell there came riding nyghe
King Alysander with a route
And as he cast his eye about
He saw this Tonne and what it meant
He would wit and thither sent
A knight by whom he might know
And he him self that ylke throw
Abode and houeth there stylle
This knight after the kings will
With spore made his horse to gone
And to the Tonne he came anon
Where that he fond a man of age
And to him told the message
Such as ye king him had bid
And axeth within thylk stead
The Tonne stood and what it was
And he which understood the cas
Sat stylle and spak no word again
The knight bad speak and said vyleyne
Thou shall me tell or that I goo
It is thy king which axeth so
My king quod he that were unright
What is he than said the knight
Is he thy man that say I naught
Quod he but as I am bythought
My man's man how that he is
Thou lie falls chorl Iwys
The knyt him said and was ryt wroth
And to the king ayene he goth
And told him how this man ansuerd
The king when he this tale herd
Bad that they should all abide
For he him self would thither ride
And when he came to fore the Tonne
He has this tale thus bygonne
Al heyl he seyth what man art thou
Quod he such one as thou see now
The king which had words wise
His age would not despise
But says fadre I the pray
That thou wolt me the cause say
How that I am thy man's man
Sire king quod he that I can
If thou wylt / yes seyth the king
Quod he this is the soth thing
Sith I first reason understood
And knew that was evil and good
The will which of my body moves
Whose works that the god reproves
I have restreyned ever more
As him that stant under the lore
Of reason whose subject he is
So that he may not do amys
And thus by weye of covenant
Will is my man and my servant
And ever has be and ever shall
And will is thy pryncipal
And the lordship of thy wit
So that thou couthest never yet
Take a day rest of thy labor
But for to be a Conqueroure
Of worlds good which may not last
Thou highest ever a lyche fast
Where thou no reason have to win
Thus thy will is cause of sin
And is thy lord to whom thou seruest
Whereof thou little thank deseruest
The king of yt he thus ansuerd
Was no thing wroth but when he herd
The high words which he said
With gooodly words thus he prayde
That he him would tell his name
I am quod be thylk same
Which men Dyogenes call
Tho was ye king right glad with all
For he had herd often to fore
What man he was so that therefore
He said O wise Dyogene
Now shall thy great wit be seen
For thou shall of my yefte have
What worlds good that you wolt crave
Quod he than houe out of my son
And let it shine in to my Tonne
For thou bynemest me thylk yifte
Which lies not in thy myt to shyfte
None other good of the me needs
The king whom every country dredeth
Lo thus he was informed there
Whereof my sone thou might lere
How that thy will shall not believed
Where it is of no wit releued
And thou have said thy self or this
How there thy will thy master is
Thorugh which thyn hertes thought
within / Is ever of contak to begin
So that it is gretely to dread
That it no homycyde bread
For love is of a wondre kind
And has his wits often blind
That they fro man's reason fall
But when that it is so byfalle
That will shall the courage led
In loves cause it is to dread
Whereof I find ensample write
Which is behouely for to wit
