I Read a tale and tell this
The Cite which Semeramis
Enclosed has with wall about
Of worthy folk with many a route
Was inbabyted here and there
Among the which two there were
Abouen al other noble and great
Duellyug tho within a street
So nyghe / to gedre as it was seen
There was no thing hem between
But wow to wow and wall to wall
This one lord has in specyal
A sone a lusty bachyler
In all the Town was none his pyer
That other bad a daughter eke
In all the Town that for to seek
Men wysten none so fair as she
And fell so that it should be
This fair daughter nigh this sone
As they to geder than wone
Cupyde has so the things shape
That they ne might the hand escape
That his fire on hem ne cast
And so it fell at the last
To follow his lore and sewe
Which never man might eschew
And that was love as it is shaped
Which has her hertes ouerthraped
That they by all weyes seche
How that they might win a speech
Her woeful pain for to lysse
Who loves well it may not mysse
And namely when there be two
Of one accord how so it goo
But if that they some weye find
For love is ever of such a kind
And has his folk so well affayted
That how so that it be awayted
There may no man the purpoos let
And thus between hem two set
An hoole upon the wall to make
Thorugh which they have her cou^seil take
/ At al time when they might
This fair Maid Tysbe hight
And he whom she loved hot
Was Piramus by name hot
So long her lesson they recorden
Till at the last they acorden
By nyghtes time for to wend
Alone out from the Towns end
Where was a well under a tree
And who so came first be or she
He should there stylle abide
So it fell by nyghtes tide
This maid which desguysed was
Al pryue^y the soft paas
Goth thurugh ye large town unknow
Till that she came within a throw
Where that she lyked for to duelle
And thylk unhappy fresshe well
Which was also the forest nyghe
Where she cemyng a lion syghe
In the field to take his pray
In have and flees so away
So as fortune should fall
For feer and let her wympyl fall
Nyhe to the well upon therbage
This wild be in his rage
A best which he found there out
Has slain and his blody snowte
When he has eten what he would
To drink of the stremes cold
Come unto the well where he fond
The wympel which out of her hond
Was fall and he has to draw
Be bled about and al for gnawe
And he straught him for to drink
Upon the fresshe wells brynke
And after that out of the plain
He torneth to the wode again
And Tysbe durst not remewe
But as a byrd which were in mewe
Which in a busshe she kept her close
So still that she not arose
Unto her self and playneth ay
And fell while that she there lay
This Pyramus came after sone
Unto the well and by the moon
He fond her wympyl blody there
^am never yet to man's ere
Tydyng ne to man's sight
Meruaylle which so sore a fryght
At man's heart as it tho deed
To him which in the same stead
With many a woeful compleynyng
Bygan his hands for to wring
As he which demeth sykerly
That she be deed and suddenly
His swerd al naked out he breyde
In his fool have and thus he seyde
I am cause of thy felonye
So it is reason that I dye
And she is deed by cause of me
And with that word upon his kne
He fell and / to the gods all
Unto the heuene he began to call
And prayed syn it was done so
That he may not his love as tho
Have in this world that of her grace
He myght^ her have in other place
For here would he not abide
He says as it shall betyde
The pomel of his swerd to ground
He set and to his heart a wound
He made up to the hard hylte
And this wise he him self spylte
With his fool have and death he nam
For she within a while came
Where he lay deed upon a knyf
So woeful yet was never life
As Tysbe was when she him syghe
She might not one word on high
Speak for her heart shette
That of her life no prys she set
But deed swownyng deed there she fell
Till afterward it so byfel
That she out of her trauns awoke
With many a woeful pytous look
Her eye alweye among^ she cast
Upon her love and at the last
She caught breath and said thus
O thou which cleped art venus
Goddess of love and thou Cupyde
Which loves cause haste for to guide
I wot now well that ye be blind
Of thylk unhappy that now I find
Only bitwene my love and me
This Piramus which I here se
Bledyng what has he deserved
For he thyn hest has kept and served
And was young and I both also
Allas why do ye with us so
Yet set our hertes both on fire
And made us such thing desire
Whereof that we no skyl couthe
But thus our fresshe lusty youth
Without joy is al dispended
Which thing may never be amended
For as for me this wol I seye
That me is lever for to deye
Then have after this sorrowful day
And with this word there as he lay
Her love in arms embraseth
Her own death and she purchases
That now she wept and now she kyst
Till at the last or she it wist
So great a sorrow is to her fall
Which ouergoth her wits all
And she which might not asterte
The swerdes point against her heart
She set and fell down thereupon
Whereof that she was deed anon
And thus on a swerd bledende
They were found deed lyggende
Now yt my sone have herd this tale
Beware of thyn own bale
Thou be not cause in thy foolhast
And keep that thou thy wit ne cast
Upon thy thought in adventure
Whereof thy lives forfeture
May fall and if thou have so thought
Tell thy tale and hyde it naught
My fad^e upon loves side
My conscience I wol not hyde
How that for love of pure woe
I have full often be moved so
That my wysshes if I might
A thousand times I you plyght
I had storuen in a day
And thereof I me shryue may
Though love fully me ne slow
My will to deye was ynow
So am I of my will culpable
And if she be not mercyable
Which may me give life and hele
But that her list not with me dele
I wot by whose counseyl it is
And him would I long time or this
And yet I would and ever shall
Sleen and destroy in especyal
The gold of nine kings lands
Ne should him save fro mine hondes
In my power if that he were
But yet him stant at no fere
For naught yt ever I couthe manace
He is the hynderer of my grace
Till he be deed I may not speed
So mote I need taken head
And shape how that he were aweye
If I thereto may find a weye
My sone tell me for thy
Which is that mortal enemy
That thou manacest to be deed
My fadre it is such a quede
That where I come he is to fore
And does so that my cause is lore
What is his name he is danger
Which is my lady counseyler
For I was never yet so slyghe
To come in a place nyghe
Where as she was by night or day
That danger ne was ready ay
With whom for speech ne for mede
Yet might I never of love speed
For ever this find I soth
All that my lady says or does
To me danger shall make an end
And yt makes al my world myswe^de
And ever I ask help but he
May be well cleped Sauns pity
For ay the more I to him bow
The less he wol my tale allow
He has my lady so englewed
She wol not that he be remewed
For ever he hongeth on her seyl
And is so preuy of counseyl
That ever when I have ought bid
I find danger in her stead
And mine ansuere of him I have
But for no mercy that I crave
Of mercy never a point I had
And thus danger my fortune lad
That worse might I never be
And thus between danger and me
I ever werre till he dye
But might I be of such maystrye
That I danger might overcome
With that were al my joy come
Thus would I fond for no sin
Ne yet for all the world to win
If that I might find a sleyght
To lay al my state in weight
I would him for the country deseuer
So that he come ayene ward never
Therefore I wysshe and would fayn
That he were on some wise slain
For while he stant in thyl^ place
Ne get I not my lady grace
Thus hate I dedely thylk vyde
And would he stood in none office
In place where my lady is
For if he do I wol well this
That outher he shall dye or I
Within a while and not for thy
On my lady full of^e I muse
How that she may her self exa^se
For if that I dye in such ^ plyght
Me thinks she might not be quyt
That she ne were an homycyde
And if it should so betyde
As god forbede it should be
By double wey it is pity
For I with all my will and wit
Have give and ever served yet
For when I should in such a wise
In towardyng of my seruyse
Be deed me thinks it were routhe
And ferthermore I tell the truth
She that ever has be well named
Were worthy than to be blamed
And of reason to be appeled
When with one word she myt an heled
A man and suffers him for to deye
A who saw ever such a weye
A who saw ever such a dystresse
Without pity or gentylnesse
Without mercy or womanh^de
That wol so quyte a man his mede
Which has ever be to love true
My good fadre if ye ^^we
Upon my tale tell me now
And I wol stynte and herkne you
My sone attempre thy courage
Fro wrath and let thyn heart assuage
For who so wol him vnderfonge
He may his grace abide long
Or he of love be received
And eke also but if it be weyued
There might mochel thing byfalle
That should make a man to fall
Fro love that ever afterward
Ne durst he soke thyderward
In hard weyes men gone soft
And er they clymbe auyse them often
And men seen al day that rape reweth
And who so wykked ale breweth
Full often he mote the werse drynk
Bettyr it is to flede than synke
Better it is upon the brydel chewe
Than if he fell and ouerthrewe
The horse and stykked in the mire
To cast water in the fire
Better is than brenne up all the hows
The man which is malycyous
And foolhasty full often he falls
And seldom is when love him calls
For thy better is to suffer a throw
Than to be wild and over throw
Suffraunce has ever be the best
To wysen him that secheth rest
And thus if thou wylt love speed
My sone suffer as I the read
What may the mous ayene the ca^
And for thylk cause I ask that
Who may to love make a werre
That he ne has him self the werre
Love axeth pe^s and ever shall
And who that fyghteth most of all
Shall lest conquer of his empryse
For this they tellen that been wise
Wicke is to seryue and have the werse
To hasten / is naught / worth a kerse
Thing that a man may not acheue
That may not well be done at eve
It mote abide till the morrow
Ne have not thine own soro we
My sone and take this in thy wit
He has not lost that well abitte
Ensample that it falls thus
Thou might well take of Piramu^
When he in have his swerd out drough
And on the point him self slough
For love of Tysbe pytously
For he hye wymple fond blody
And wend a best had her slain
Where as him ought be right fayn
For she was sauf right beside
But for he would not abide
This meschyef fell for thy be ware
My sone as I the warn dare
Do now no thing in such a rees
For sufferaunce is the well of pees
Though thou to loves court pursewe
Yet sit it well that thou esche we
That thou the court not ouerhas^
For so thou might thy time wast
But if thine hap thereto shape
It may not help for to rape
Therefore attempt thy courage
Foolhast does none advantage
But if it set a man behind
In cause of love and that I find
By old ensamples thou shall here
Touchend of love in this ma^^re

aMayden whysom there was one
Which daphne hit and such was none.
Of beauty than as it was said /
Phoebus hio love has on her laid
And thereupon to her he sought
In his foolhast and so besought

For ever upon her love he grad

So it byfelle upon a day
Cupyde which has every chance
Of love under his governance

And for him should haste the more
And yet not sp^den at the last

That made him many fold desire

A dart of leed he cast and smote
Which was al cold and no thing hot
And thus Phoebus in lou^ brenneth
And in have about renneth
To book if that be might win
Thus was he ever to begin

So that he never his love sped
And for to make him full believe
That no foolhase might acheue
To get love in such degree

Was torued which is ever grene
In tokne as yet it may be seen
That she shall duelle a maiden stylle
And phoebus faylen of his will
By such eusamples as they stand
My sone thou might understand
To basten love is thing in veyn
When that fortune is there ageyn
To take where a man may leave
Good is and else he mote leave
For when a man's happes faylen
There is no have may auaylen
My fadre grant mercy of this
But while I see my lady is
No tree but hold her own form
There may no man so on form
To w^edyr part fortune wend
That I unto my lives end

My sone sith it is so
I / say no more but in this ^^s

Naught only upon loves chance
But upon every governance
Which falls unto man's deed
Foolhast is ever for to dread
And that a man good counseyl take

For counseyl put foolhast awey

That for to wysse the more

wHen noble Troy was byleyn
And overcome and home ageyn
The gregoys turned from ye siege
The kings fond her own lyege
In many places as men seyde
That hem forsook and dysobeyde
Among the which fell this cas
To Demephon and Athemas
That were kings both two
And both were served so
Here syeges would not hem receive
So that they more algates weyue
To seche land in other place
For there fond they no grace
Whereof they token hem to read
And sough^^n friends at need
And each of hem assures other
To help as to his own brother
To vengen hem of thylk oultrage
And win oyene her heritage
And thus they ride about fast
To geten hem help and at the last
They hadden power suffysaunt
And maden than a covenant
That they should no life save
Ne pressed ne clerk ne lord ne knave
Ne wife ne child of / that they find
Which bears vysage of mankind
So that no life shall be socoured
But with the dedely sword devoured
In such a foolhast here ordinance
They shape for to do vengeance
When this purpos was wist and know
Among their host tho was there blow
Of words many a speech about
Of young men the lusty route
Were of this tale glad enough
There was no care for the plough
As they that were foolhastyf
They ben acorded to the s^ryf

Was none but Nestor ansuerde
He bad hem if they would win
They sholden see or they begin
Here end and set her first intent
That they hem after ne repent
And axeth hem this questyon
To what fynal conclusyon
They wolden ^egne kings there
If that no people in ^onde were
And seyth it were a wonder wyerd
To seen a king bycomen an hyerd
Where no life is but only best
^onder the lygeaunce of his heste
For who that is of man no king
The remenauut is as no thing
He seyth eke if he the purpoos hold
To slay the people as they two would
When they it might not restore
Al greece it should abye full sore
To see the wild lestes wone
Where whylome duellyd a man's sone
And for that cause he had hem trete
And stynte of the manaces great
Better is to win by fair speech
He seyth than such a vengeance seche
For when a man is most above

Of him that reason understood

Thyn heart and let no will dystempre
Thy wytee and do no thing by might

Foolhast is cause of mochel woe
For thy my sone do not so
And as touchend of Homycyde
Which touches unto loves side
Fulofte it falls unadvised
Through will which is not well assised
When wit and reason ben awey
And that foolhast is in the wey
Whereof has fall great vengeance
For thy take in to remembrance
To love in such a manner wise
That thou dese^^e no iuyse

To love where thou wolt or none

So that it torn in to malice
There wot noman of thylk vice
What peril that there may byfalle
Whereof a tale among all
Which is great pity for to here

Such Capytayne such retenue

Where no be^^^e may be Inn

Is not more set upon rauyne
Than ylk man which his couyne
Has set in such manner wise
For all the world ne may suffyse
To will which is not reasonable
Whereof ensample concordable
Lyche to this point of which I mean
Was upon Alysander seen
Which had set al his intent
So as fortune with him went
That the reason myt him not govern
But of his will he was so stern
That all the world he ouer^an
And what him list he took and wan
In inde the superyour
When that he was full conqueror
And had his wylful purpoos won

This day / to morrow had naught
And in such wise as he was wrout
In dysturbaunce of worlds pees

In which for ever dyscomfyte
He was* lo now for what proufyte
Of werre it helps for to ride

As bestes which gone there out
For any life which reason can
Ought well* to know that a man
Ne should thorugh no tyranny

Till kind would for him send

Which takes awey for evermore

For what man the Cronykes read

Of Crystes feyth stant now myswent
God do thereof amendment
So as he wot what is the best

Of conscience well assysed

For man as tellen us the clerks

So sit it well to taken head
And for to look on every side

In thylk time how peleus

But he had gold enough

Al were there no repentance
And as the books make remembrance
It tellyth of Med^e also
Of that she slough her sons two

Has made her of her sin quyte

Whose right name Almeus was
His mother slough Eryphele
But Achylo the pressed and he
So as the books it recorden
For certain sum of gold acorden
That thylk horrible synful deed
Assoylled was and thus for mede
Of worlds good it fallyth often
That homycyde is set alofte
Here in this life but after this
There shall be know how that it is
Of hem that such things wyrche
And how also that holy church
Let such sins pass quyte
How they wol hem acquyte
Of dedely werres that they make
For who that would ensample take
The law which is naturel
By weye of kind the weth well
That homycyde in no degree
Which werreth ayene charity
Among men should not duelle
For a foer that the books tell
To s^che in all the world rich
Men shall not find one his lyche
No best that will take his preye
And sith kind has such a weye
Than it is wondre of a man
Which kind has and reason can
That he wol either more or less
His kind and reason ouerpasse
And slay that is to him semblable
So is the man not reasonable
He kind and that is not honest
When he is worse than a best

aT Twye when king Vlyxes
Upon the sege among ye pres
Of hem ye worthy knites were
Abode long time stylle there
In thylke time a man may see
Hou goodly that Penolope
Which was to him his true wife
Of his lachesse wa^ pleyntyf
Whereof to Troy she him send
Her will by letter thus spekende
My worthy love and lord alsso
It is and has be ever so
That where a woman is alone
At makes a man in his persoue
The more hardy for to wowe
In hope that she would bow
To such thyuge as his will werr
While that here lord were else where
And of my self I tell this
For it so long passed is
Sith first that ye from home went
That well nyhe every man is went
To come there I am while ye be out
And besyly each of hem about
Which love can / my love secheth
With great prayer and me bysecheth
And sum maken great manace
That if they might come in place
Where that they might here will have
There is no thing me should save
That they ne would worche things
And sum tell me tidings
That ye he deed and sum seyn
That certeynly ye be beseyn
To love a new and leave me
But holle as ever that it be
I thank unto the gods all
As yet for ought that is byfalle
May no man do my chekes read
But netheles it is to dread
That lachesse in contynuaunce
Fortune might work such a^chaunce
Which noman^ after shall amend

And prayed him that he would wit

And that he tarry not in this
But that he would his love acquyte
To her ayeneward and not write
But come him self in all have
That he none other paper wast
So that he keep and hold his truth
Without let of any slouthe
Unto her lord and love lyege
To Troy where the great syege
Was leyd / this letter was conveyed
And he which wysedom has purueyd
Of all that to reason belongs
With gentyl heart it vnderfongeth
And when he has it over rad
In part he was right Inly glad
And eke in part he was dysesed
But love his heart has thorugh sesed
With pure ymagynacyon
That for none occupacyon
Which he began take on other side
He may not flyt his heart aside
For that his wife him had informed
Whereof he has him self conformed
With all the will of his courage
To shape and take the ^yage
Homeward what time that he may
So that him thinks one day
A thousand year till he may see
The ^ysage of Penolope
Which he desires most of all
And when the time was so byfalle
That Troy was destroyed and brent
He made no delayment
But goth him home in all high
Where that he fond to fore his eye
His worthy wife in good estate
And thus was seced the debate
Of love and slouthe was excused
Which does great harm where it is bsed
And hyndreth many a cause honest

Ouchend of sloth in his degree t
There is yet pusillanymyte
Which is to say in this langage
He that has little of courage
And dare not man's work legynne
So may he not by reason win
For who that dare naught undertake
By right he shall no profit take
But of this vice the nature
Dare no thyug set in adventure
Him lacks both worth and deed
Whereof he should his cause speed
He wol no manhood understand
For ever he has dread upon hand
Al his peril that he shall say
Him thinks the wolf is in the way
And of ymagynacyon
He makes his excusacyon
And feyneth cause of pure dread
And ever he fails at need
Till al be spylt that he with deleth
He has the sore which no man heleth
The which is cleped lak of heart
Though every grace about him sterte
He wol not ones stew his foot
So that by reason lose he mote
That wol not aunter for to win
And so forth sone if we begin
To speak of love and his service
There ben truantes in such a wise
That lakken heart vhan best were
They speken of love and right for fere
They wexen dombe and dare not tell
Without soune as does the belle
Which has no claper for to chyme
And right so they as for the time

Whose Iname was Pygmalyone

King demophon when he by ship
To Troy ward with felauship
Seylend goth upon his weye
It happens him at Rodepeyr
As Eolus him had blow
To l^nd and rested for a throw
And feste that ylke time thus
That the daughter of Lygurgius
Which queen was of the country

Which was an enchauntement

So as she might and ever in one

There was never such a knight

Anon as Demephon it herd

Phoebus which is ye son hot

And hates al besynes
T^^re is yet one which Idelnes
Is cleped and is the noryoe
In man's kind of every vice
Which secheth cases many fold
In winter does he naught for cold
In somer may he naught for hete
So whether that he feese or sweet
Or be he in or be he out
He wol ben ydel al about
But if he pley ought at the dies
For who that ever takes fees
And thinks worship to deserve

My fadre god I give a yift
That toward love as he may wytt
Al ydel was I never yett
Ne never shall while I may goo
Now sone tell me than so
What have thou done of besyshyp
To love and to the ladyshyp
Of her which thy lady is
My fadre ever yet or this
In every place in every stead
What so my lady has me bid
With all mine heart obedyent
I have thereto be dylygent
And if so be that she bid naught
What thing in to my thought
Comes first of that I may suffyse
I bow and profre my service
Sometime in chamber sometime in halle
Right so as I see the times fall
And when she goth to here mass
That time shall not me ouerpasse
That I ne approach her ladyhede
In aunter if I may her led
Unto the chapel and again
Than is not al my wey in vein
Somdele I may the better fare
When I that may not feel her bare
May led her clothed in mine arm
But afterward it does me harm
Of pure Imagynacyon
For than there a collacyon
I make unto my seluen often
And say O lord how she is soft
How she is round. how she is small
Now would god / I had her al
Without danger at my will
And than I syke and sit full stylle
Of that I see my besy thought
Is turned Idel in to naught
But for all that let I ne may
When I see time another day
That I ne do my besynes
Unto my ladies worthynes
For I thereto my wit affayte
To see the time and awayte
What is to done and what is to leave
And so when time is by her leave
What thing she bydde me do I do
And where she bydde me go ^ goo
And when her list to clepe I come
Thus has she fullyche overcome
Mine Idelnesse till that I sterue
So that I mote her needs serve
For as men seyn need has no law
Thus mote I nedely to her deawe
I serve I bow I lofte I lowte
Mine eye follows her about
What so she wol so wol I
When she wol sit I knele her by
And when she sto^deth than wol I sto^d
But when she takes her werk on ho^d
Of weuyng or of brouderye
Than can I not but muse and prye
Upon her fyngers long and small
And now I think and now I tale
And now I sing and now I syke
And now my contenaunce I pyke
And if it fall as for a time
Her lyketh naught abide byme
But occupyeth her on other things
Than make I other taryenges
To drive forth the long day
For me is loath to depart a way
And than I am so simple of port
That for to feyne sum dysport
I play with her little hounde
Now on the bed now on the ground
Now with the birds in the cage
For there is none so little page
Ne yet so simple a Chamberere
That I ne make hem all chere
And al for they should speak well
Thus may ye see my besy whele
That goth not ydelyche about
A(...) her list to ryden out
(...) or other stead
I come thus though I be not bid

For that I would not ben ydel

And that I may thereof be ware
A none I shape me for to ride
Right even by the chares side
And as I may I speak among
And otherwhyle I sing a song
Which Ouyde in his book made
And said O what sorrows glade
O what woeful prosperyte
Belongs to the propyrte
Of love who so wol him serve
And yet there fro may no man swerue
That he ne mote his law obey
And thus I ride forth my weye
And am right besy oueral
With heart and with my body al
As I baue said you here to fore
My good fadre tell me therefore
Of ydelnes if I have gylt
My sone but if thou all wylt
Ought else than I may now here
Thou shall have no penance here
And netheles a man may see
How now a days that there be
Full many of such hertes slow
That wol not besyen hem to be know

That he with strength hem ouercast
That maulgre hem they mote obey

oF armenye I read thus
There was a king which herupus /
Was hot and he a lusty maid.
To daughter had and as men said
Her name was Rosiphele
Which tho was of great renome
For she was both wise and feyre
And should be her fadre heir
But she had one defaulte of slouthe
Toward love and that was routhe
For so well couthe noman seye
Which might her set in the weye
Of loves occupacyon
Thorugh none Imagynacyon
That seole would she not know
And thus she was one of the slow
As of such hertes business
Till when Venus the goddess
Which loves court has for to reule
Has brought her in to better reule
Forth with Cupyde and his might
For they marvel how such a wight
Which tho was in her lusty age
Desires nouther marriage
Ne yet the love of peramours
Which ever has been the common course
Among hem that lusty were
So was it showed after there
For he that hye hertes loweth
With fyry dart which he throws
Cupyde which of love is god
In chastysynge has made a rod
To drive awey her wantonness
So that within a while I guess
She had on such a chance sporned
That al her moo^ was ouertorned
Which first she had of slow manner
For this it fell as thou shall here
When come was the month of may
She would walk upon a day
And that was or the son aryst
Of women but a few it wist

Unto the park was fast by All soft walkend upon the gras

She herd glad fowls sing
She saw bestes in her kind
The buk the do the heart the hynde
The male go with the femele
And so bygan there a quarele
Between love and her own heart
For which she couthe not astert
And as she cast her eye about
She saw clad in one suit a route
Of ladies where they come ride
A long under the wode side
On fair ambulend horse they sete
That were al white fat and great
And they echone ride on side
The sadeles were of such a pride
With perles and gold so well begone,
So rich saw she never none
In kyrtels and in copes rich
They were clothed al alyche
Departed even of white and blewe
With all lusts that she knew
They were embroudred oueral
Here bodies were long and small
The beauty fair upon her face
None erthely thing it may deface

That all the gold of Cresus halle
The lest coronal of hem all
Myt not have bought after the worth

She was not worthy to axe there
Fro when they come and what they were
Bnt lever than this worlds good

That to my fadre had a king

For I why lome no love had

And smelle and taste in his degree
And for to feel and for to go
It helps a man of both two
The wits frue he under fongeth
To keep as it to him belongs
The third stone in fpecyal
By name is cleped myneral
Which the metals of every mine
Attempreth till that they be fine
And puts hem by such a weye
That all the vice goth aweye
Of rust of stynk and of hardness
And when they ben of such clennesse
This mynetal so as I find
Transformeth all the first kind
And makes hem able to conceive
Thorugh his virtue and to receive
Both in substance and in figure
Of gold and silver the nature
For they two ben thextremytees
The which after the propyrtees
Has every metal his desire
With help and comfort of the fire
And with this stone / as it is said
Which to the son and moan is laid
For to the read and to the white
This stone has power for to profit
It makes multyplycacyon
Of gold and the fyxacyon
It causes and of his habyte
He does the work to be^parfyte
Of thylk Elyxer which men call
Alconomye as it is byfalle
To hem that whylome were wise
But now it stant al other wise
They speken fast of thylk stone
But hou to make it know none
After the soth experyence
And netheles great dylygence
They setten upon thylk deed
And spyllen more than they speed
For alwey they find a let
Which brings in pouerte and debt
To hem that rich were to fore
The loss is had the lucre is lore
To get a pound they spend fyu^
I not hou such a craft shall thryue
In the manner as it is used
It were better be refused
Than for to worchen upon wene
In thing Which sta^t not as they went
But not for thy who that knew
The science of him self is true
Upon the form as it was founded
Whereof the names yet be grounded
Of hem that first it founded out
And thus the fame goth at about
To such as soughten business
To virtue and of worthynesse
Of whom if I the names call
Hermes was one of the first of all
To whom this art is most applied
Geber thereof was magnyfyed
And Ortolan and Maryen
Among the which is Auycen
Which fond and wrote a great party
The practyke of Alconomye
Whose books pleynly as they stand
Upon this craft few understand
But yet to putten in assay
There ben full many now a day
That known little what they mean
It is not one to wit and wene
In form of words they it trete
But yet they faylen of beyete
For of to much or of to lyte
There is algate found a wit
So that they follow not the line
Of the parfyte medycyne
Which grounded is upon nature
But they that written the scripture
Of Greek Arabe and Caldee
They were of such auctoryte
That they first founden out the weye
Of all that thou have herd me seye
Whereof the Cronyke of her lore
Shall stand in price for evermore
But toward our marches here
Of the latyns if thou wolt here
Of hem that whylome virtuous
Were and thereto laboryous
Carment made of here engyne
The first lettres of latyne
Of which the tongue Romayne came
Whereof that Arystarchus nam
Forth with Donat and Dyndymus
The first reule of scole and thus
How that latin shall be compowued
And what wise it shall be souned
That every word in his degree
Shall stand upon congruyte
And thylk time of Rome also
Was Tullyus with Cythero
That written upon Rethoryke
How that men shall the words pyke
After the form of eloquence
Which is men seyn a great prudence
And after that out of he bre^^e
Jerome Which the langage knew
The bible in which the law is closed
In to latin he has transposed
And many another writer eke
Out of Caldee Arabe and Greek
With great labor the books wise
Ttanslateden and another wise
The latyns of hem self also
Here study at thylk time so
With great trauayl of scole took
In sundry form for to look
That we may take here euydence
Upon the lore of the science
Of crafts both and of clergy
Among the which in poesye
To the lovers Ouyde wrote
And taught of love to be hot
In what manner it should akele
Confessor
For thy my sone if that thou feel
That love bring the tofore
Behold Ouyde and take his lore
My fadre if they might speed
My love I would his books read
And if they techen to restreyne
My love it were an ydel pain
To learn a thing which may not be
For lyche unto a grene tree
If that men took his rote aweye
Right so my heart should deye
If that my love be withdraw
Whereof touchend unto this saw
There is but only to pursewe
My love and ydelshyp to esche we
My good son soth to seye
If there be syker any weye
To love thou have said the best

It is no reason that he speed
In loves cause for to win
For he Which dare no thing begin
I not what thing he should ^cheue
But over this thou shall believe
So as it sit the well to know
That there ben other vices slow
Which unto love done great let
Is thou thyn heart upon hem set

And than it fallyth other gate
So that her lyketh not to dance

Or axe of love sum demand
Or else that her list command
To read and here of Troylus
Right as she wol or so or thus
I am already to consent
And if so is that I may hente
Sometime among a good leyser
So as I dar of my desire
I tell a part but when I preye
Anon she byddeth me go my weye
And seyth it is far in the night
And I swear it is even light
But as it falls at the last
There may no worlds joy last
So mote I needs fro her wend
And of my watch make an end
And if she than head took
How pytously on her I look
When that I shall my leave take
Her ought of mercy for to slake
Her danger which says ever nay
But he seyth often have good day
That loath is for to take his leave
Therefore while I may believe
I tarry forth the night a long
For it is naught on me along
To sleep that I so sone go
Till I mote need algate so
And that I bid god her see
And so down knelend on my knee

And otherwhyle if that I door
Er I come fully to the door
I torn ayene and feyne a thing
As though I had lost a ryng
Or somewhat else for I would
Kiss her eftsoon if I should
But seldom is that I so speed
And when I see that I mote need
Depart I depart and thanne
With all my heart I curse and banne
That ever sleep was made for eye
For as me thinks I mote dry
Without sleep to Waken ever
So that I should not dysseuer
Fro her in whom is al my light
And than I curse also the night
With all the will of my courage
And say awey thou black image
Which of thy derck cloudy face
Makes all the worlds light deface
And causes unto sleep awey
By which I mote now gone aweye
Out of my lady company
O slepy night I the defye
And would that thou lay in press
With Proserpyne the goddess
And with Pluto the hell king
For till I see the day spryng
I set by sleep not a rysshe
And with that word I syghe and wysshe
And sey why ne were it day
For yet my lady than I may
Behold though I do no more
And efte I think forthermore
To sum man hou the night does ease
When he has thing yt may him please
The long nyghtes by his side
Where as I fail and goo beside
But sleep whereof I not it serves
Of which noman his thank deserves
To get hem love in any place
But it is an hynderer of his grace
And makes hem deed as for a throw
Right as a stok were overthrow
And so my fadre in this wise
The slepy nyghtes I despise
And ever a mids of my tale

Which slepeth not by wey of kind
For love in books as I find
Thus at the last I goo to bed
And yet mine heart lies to wedde

And feleth hou that she is warm

Tho to feel that he felyth there
And thus my self I tormente
Till that the deed sleep me hente
But than by a thousand score
Well more than I was to fore
I am tormented in my sleep
But what I dreme is not on sheep
For I ne thynk on no wulle
But I am dretched to the fulle
Of love that I have take to keep
That now I laugh and now I weep
And now I lose and now I win
And now I end and now begin

And that danger is left behind

Than is al turned in to sorrow
Naught for the cause I shall arise

That al is wine and helps naught

tHis find I written in poesy
Ceyx the king of Trocenye
Had Alceon to his wife
Which as her own hertes life
Him loves and he has also
A brother which was cleped tho
Dedalyon and he par caas
Fro kind of man forshape was
In to a goshauk of likeness.
Whereof the king great heaviness
Has take and ^thought in his courage
To gone upon a pylgremage
In a strange Regyon
Where he has his devotion
To done his sacryfyce and preye
If that he might in any weye
To wards the gods find grace
His broders hele to purchase
So that he might be reformed
Of that he has been transformed
To this purpos and to this end
This king is ready for to wend
As he which would go to ship
And for to done him felaushyp
His wife unto the sea him brought
With all her heart and him besought
That he the time her would seyn
When that he thought come again
Within he says two monethis day
And thus in all the have he may
He took his leave and forth he sayleth
Wepend / and she her self bewayleth
And torneth there she came fro
For when the months were ago
The which he set of his coming
And that she herd no tydyng
There was no care for to seche
Whereof the gods to byseche
Tho she bygan in many wise
And to Juno her sacryfyce
Above al other most she deed
And for her lord she has so bid
To wit and know hou that he ferd
That Juno the gods herd
Anon and upon this matere
She Irys bad her messagyer
To slepes house that she should wend
And bid him that he make an end
By sweuene and shown all the caas
To this lady hou it was
This Irys fro the high stage
Which undertake has the message
His reyny cope deed upon
The which was wonderly begone
With colors of dyners hew
An honderd mo than men knew
The heuene lyche unto a bow
She bend / and she came done low
The god of sleep where that she fond
And that was in a strange land
Which marches upon Chymery^
For there as seyth the poesye
The god of sleep has made his house
Which of entaylle is meruaylous
Under an hylle there is a cave
Which of the son may not have
So yt no man may not know ary^t
The point between day and night
There is no fire there is no spark
There is no door which may chark
Whereof an eye should vnshet
So that inward there is no let
And for to speak of that without
There stant no great tree nyhe about
Whereon there might crow or pie
A light for to clepe or cry
There is no cost to crow day
Ne best none which noise may
The hylle / but al about round
There is growend upon the ground
Popy. which bears the seed of sleep
With other herbs such an hepe
A stylle water for the nones
Rennend upon the small stones
Which hight of ^ethes the River
Under the hylle in such manner
There is which yeueth great appetyte
To sleep and thus full of delight
Sleep has his house and of his couche
Within his chamber if I shall touch
Of Hebenus that slepy tree
The boordes al about be
And for he should sleep soft
Upon a fether bed alofte
He lies with many a pylwe of down
The chamber is strowed up and down
With sweuenes many a thousand fold
Thus come Irys in to this hold
And to the bed which is blak
She goth and therewith sleep she spak
And in this wise as she was bid
The message of Juno she deed
Full o^^ her words she reherseth
Er she his slepy eres perseth
With much woo. but at the last
His slomerend eyes he vpcast
And said her that it shall bedoo
Whereof among a thousand tho
Within his house that slepy were
In specyal he chese out there
Three which should do this deed
The first of hem so as I read
Was Morpheus the whose nature
Is for to take the figure
Of what person that him lyketh
Whereof that he thereof entryketh
The life which sleep shall by night
And Ithecus that other hight
Which has the voys of every soune
Their chere and their condycyoun
Of every life what so is
The third / sewend after this
Is Pantafas which may transform
Of every thing the right form
And change it in another kind

Of sweuenes stant al thapparence
Which otherwhyle is euydence
And other while but a iape
But netheles it is so shape
That Morpheus by night allone
A wereth unto Alceone
In likeness of her husbond
Al naked deed upon the stronde
And hou he dreynt in specyal
These other two it she wen shall
The tempest of the blak cloud
The wode see the wyndes loud
All this met she and saw him dyen
Whereof that she bygan to cryen
Slepend a bed there she lay
And with that noise of her affraye
Her women stert up about
Which of her were in doubt

And she right as she saw and herd
Her sweuen has told hem every dele
And they it halsen al well
And seyn it is a tokne of good
But till she wist hou it stood
She has no comfort in her heart

Whereof her wits be withdraw

For though she had her power lore

This Alceon the true queen
Her birds as it is seen
Of Alceon the name bear
Lo thus it may the stere

For oftyme a man a sleep

For thy it helps at some tide

That al my life in to now

And thus as tymelyche as I may
Full often when it is brood day

But upon your conscience

For love upon his lust wakend
Is ever and would that none end
Thereof the long night is set
Whereof that thou be ware the bett

How love and sleep acorden naught

Sometime in Physyk as I find
When it is take by mesure
But he which can no sleep mesure
Upon the reule as it belongs
Full often of sodeyne chance he fongeth
Such infortune that him greueth
But who these old books leueth
Of Sompnolence hou it is write
There may a man the sothe wit
If that he would ensample take
That other while is good to wake

oVyde thus tells in his sawes
Hou Jupiter by old days
Lay by a maid which is
Was cleped whereof that Juno
His wife was wroth and the goddess
Of yo turned the likeness
In to a Cow to goo there out
The large feldes al about
And get her mete upon the grene
And thereupon this high queen
Betook her Argus for to keep
For he was seldon wont to sleep
And yet he had an honderd eyes
And al alyche well they sym
Now herkne hou he was begyled
Mercurye which was al affyled
This Cow to stele he came desguysed
And had a pype well devised
Upon the notes of musyke
Whereof he might his eres like
And over that he had affayted
His lusty tales and awayted
His time and thus in to the field
He came where Argus he beheld
With yo which beside him went
With that his pype anon he hent
And began to pype in his manner
Thing which was slepy for to here
And in his pypyng ever among
He told him such a lusty song
That he the fool has brought a sleep
There was none eye that might keep
His head which mercurye of smote
And forth with all anon foot hot
He stal the Cow which Argus kept
And all this fell for that he slept
Ensample it was to many mo
That mochel sleep does often woe
When it is time for to wake
For if a man this vice take
In sompnolonce and him delight
Men should upon his door write
His Epytaphe as upon his grave
For he to spylle and naught to save
Is shaped / and though he were deed
For thymy sone hold up thyn heds
And let no sleep thine eye englue
But when it is to reason due
My fader as touchend of this
Right so as I you told it is
That often a bed when I should
I may not sleep though I would
For love is ever fast byme
Which takes none head of due* time
For when I shall mine eye close
A none my heart he wol oppose
And hold his scole in such a wise
Till it be day that I arise
That selde it is when that I sleep
And thus fro sompnolence I keep
Mine eye / and for thy if there be
Ought else more in this degree
Now axe forth my sone yis
For slouthe which as mother is
The forth drawer* and the Noryce
To man to many a dredeful vice
Has yet another last of all
Which many a man has made to fall
Where that he might never arise
Whereof thou the shall auyse
Er thou so with thy self mysfare
What vice it is I wol declare

When slouthe does al yt he may
To drive forth the long day
Till he bycome to the need
Then at last upon the deed
He laketh hou his time is lore
And is so woo begone therefore
That he within his thought conceyueth
Trystesse and so him self deceyueth
That he wanhope brings Inn
Where is no comfort to begin
But every joy him is dylayed
So that within his heart affrayeth
A thousand time with one breath
Wepend he wyssheth after death
When he fortune fynt adverse
For than he wol his hap reheree
As though the world were al forlore
And says Allas that I was lore
How I shall live how shall I do
For now fortune is my foo
I wot well god me wol not help
What should I than of joy yelpe
When there no bote is of my care
So over cast is al my welfare
That I am shapen al to stryf
Allas that I never of this life
Or I be fullyche overtake
And thus he wol his sorrow make
As god him might not avail
But yet ne wol he not travail
To help him at such a need
But slouteth under such a dread
Which is affermed in his heart
Right as he might naught asterte
The worlds woo which he is Inn
Also when he is fall in sin
Him thinks he is so fer culpable
That god wol not be mercyable
So great a sin to foryeue
And thus he leueth to be shryue
And if a man in thylk throw
Would him counsel, he wol not know
The soth though a^man it find
For trystesse is of such a kind
That for to mayntene his fely
He has with him obstynacy
Which is within of such a slouthe
That he forslaketh al truth
And wol not to no reason bo we
And yet he can not allow
His own skylle / but of head
Thus dwyneth he till he be deed
In hyndryng of his own estate
For where a man is obstynate
When hope follows at the last
Which may not long after last
Till slouthe make of him an end
But god wot whether he shall wend
My sone and right in such manner
There be lovers of heavy chere
That sorowen more than it is need
When they be turned of their speed
And can not them self read
But lesen hope for to speed
And stynten love to pursewe
And thus they faden hyde and hew
And lustles in her hertes wax
Hereof it is that I would axe
If thou my sone art one of tho
A good fadre it is so
Out take a point I am be know
For else I am overthrow
In all that ever ye have said
My sorrow is evermore vnteyd
And secheth oueral my veins
But for to counseylle of my peynes
I can no bote do thereto
And thus withouten hope I goo
So that ^y wits ben empeyred
And I am as who said despeyred
To win love of thylke sweet
Without whom I you behete
Mine heart that is so bestad
Right only may never be glad
For by my truth I shall not lie
Of pure sorrow which I dry
For that she says / she wol me naught
With dretchyng of mine own though
In such a wanhope I am fall
That I ne can uneaths call
As for to speak of any grace
My lady grace to purchase
But yet I say naught for this
That al in mine defaulte it is
For I am never yet instead
When time was that I me bid
Ne said and as I dorst told
But never fond I that she would
For ought she knew mine intent
To speak a goodly word assent
And netheles this dar I seys
That if a synful would preys
To god for his foryeuenesse
With half so great a business
As I have do to my lady
In lak of axyng of mercy
He should never come in hell
And thus I may you sothly tell
Sauf only that I ceye and bid
I am in trystesse al amydde
And fulfilled of dysperaunce
And therefore give me my penance
Mine holy fader as you lyketh
My sone of that thy heart syketh
With sorrow might thou not amend
Till love his grace wol the send
For thou thine own cause empeyrese
What time yt thou thy self dyspeyrest
I uot what other thing avails
Of hope when the heart fails
For such a soor is Ina^rable
And eke the gods ben vengeable
And that a man may right well feed
These old books who so read
Of thing which has byfalle or this
Now here of what ensample it is

wHylome by old days fer
Of mese was ye king theucer
Which had a knyt to son iphis
Of love and ^e so mastred is
That he has set al his courage
As to regard of his lygnage
Upon a maid of low astate
But though he were a potestate
Of worlds good he was subgett
To love and put in such a plyte
That excedeth the mesure
Of reason that him self assure
He can naught / for the more he prayed
The less love on him she laid
He was with love un wise co^streyned
And she with reason was with streyned
The lusts of his heart he seweth
And she for dread shame esche weth
And as she should took head
To save and keep her womanhede
And the thing stood in debate
Between his lust and here estate
He yaue / he send / he spak by mouth
But yet for ought that ever he couth
Unto his speed he fond no weye
So that he cast his hope aweye
Within his heart he began dyspeyre
Fro day to day and so^ empeyre
That he has lost al his delight
Of lust of sleep of appetyte
That he through strength of sone lasseth
His wit and reason over passes
As he which of his life ne tought
His death upon him self he sought
So that by night his weye he nam
That wist none where he bycam
The night was derk the moon shone
To fore the gates he came sone
Where that this young maid was
And with this woeful word allas
His dedely pleyntes he bygan
So stylle that there was noman
It herd and than he said thus
O thou Cupyde / O thou Venus
Fortuned by whoos ordenaunce
Of love is every man's chance
Ye known al mine hole heart
That I ne may your hondes asterte
On you is ever that I cry
And yet you deyneth not to plye
Ne toward me your ere enclyne
Thus for I see no medycyne
To make an end of my quarele
My death shall be instead of hele
Ha thou my woeful lady dear
Which duellest with thy fadre here
And slepest in thy bed at ese
Thou wotest no thing of my dysese
How thou and I be now unmeet
A lord what sweuene shall thou mete
What dremes have thou now on hond
Thou slepest there and here I stond
Though I no death to the deserve
Here shall I for thy love sterue
Here shall I a kings sone* deye
For love and for no felonye
Whether thou thereof have joy or sorrow
Here shall thou me see deed to morrow
O hard heart abouen all
This death which shall to me fall
For that thou wolt not do me grace
It shall be told in many place
That I am deed for love and truth
In thy defaulte and in thy slouthe
Thy danger shall to many mo
Ensample be for euermo
When they the woeful death record
And with that word he took a cord
With which upon the gate tree
He henge him self that was pity
The morrow came the night is gone
Men come out and syghe anon
Where that this young lord was deed
There was an house without deed
For noman knew the cause why
There was weeping there was cry
This maiden when she it herd
And saw this thing hou it mysferd
Auone she wist what it mente
And all the cause hou it went
To all the world she told it out
And preyth hem that were about
To take of her the wngeaunce
For she was cause of thylk chance
Why that this kings sone is spy^t
She takes upon her self the gylt
And is al ready to the pain
Which any man her wol ordeyne
But if any other would
She says that her self she should
Do wreche with her own hond
Thorugh out the world in* every lo^d
That every life thereof shall speak
Hou she her self it should wreke
She wepeth she cries she swouneth often
She cast her eyes up alofte
And said among full pytously
A god thou wost well it am I
For Iphis is thus byseyn
Ordeyne so that many may seyn
A thousand winter after this
Hou such a maiden did amys
And so as I did do to me
For I ne did no pity
To him which for my love is lore
Do no pity to me therefore
And with this word she fell to grosid
A swoune and there she lay astound
The gods which her pleyntes herd
And saw hou woefully she ferde
Here life awey they took anon
And shopen here in to a stone
After the form of her image
Of body both and of vysage
And for the meruaylle of this thing
Unto the place came the king
And eke the queen and many mo
And when they wysten it was foo
As I have told it here above
Hou that Iphys was deed for love
Of that he had be refused
They helden al men excused
And wondren upon the vengeance
And for to keep remembrance
This fair image maiden lyche
With company noble and rich
With torches and with great solempnyte
To Salamyne the Cite
They led and carye forth with all
This deed corpse and seyn it shall
Beside thylk Image have
His sepulture and be begraue
This corpse and this Image thus
In to the Cite to Venus
Where that goddess her Temple had
To geder both forth they lad
Thylke Image as for miracle
Was set upon an high pynacle
That al it might know
And under that they maden low
A tomb rich for the nones
Of marble and eke of Iaspre stones
Wheryn this Iphys was byloken
That evermore it shall be spoken
And for men shall the sothe wit
They have here Epytaphe write
As thing which should abide stable
The lettres granen in a Table
Of marble were and said this
Here lies which slou him self Iphis
For love of Araxarathen
And in eusample of tho women
That suffren men to dyen so
His form a man may seen also
Hou it is turned flesh and bone
In the figure of a stone
He was to nesshe and she hard
Beware for thy here afterward
Ye men and women both two
Ensampleth you of that was tho
Loo thus my sone as I the seye
It greueth by diverse weye
In despeyr a man to fall
Which is the last branch of all
Of slouthe as thou have herd deuyse
Whereof that thou thy self auyse
Good is or that thou be deceived
Whereof the hope of grace is weyued
My fadre hou so that it stand
Nou have I pleynly understand
Of slouthes court the propyrte
Whereof touchend in my degree
For ever I thynk to be ware
But over this so as I dare
With all mine heart I you byseche
That ye me would inform and teache
What there is more of your apryse
In love als well as other wise
So that I may me clean shryue
Confessor
My son while thou art alive
And have also thy full mind
Among the vices which I find
There is yet one such of the seuene
Which all this world has set vneuene
And causes many times wrong
Where he the cause has vnderfong
Whereof here after thou shall here
The form both and the matere

fIrst when the high god began /
This world and that the kind of man /
Was fall in to no great encrees /
For worlds good was tho no prees /
But al was set to the comune /
They speken than of no fortune
Or for to lose or for to win
Till Auaryce brought Inn
And yt was when ye world was woye
Of man of hoar of sheep of Ox
And that men knewen the money
Tho went pees out of the weye
And werre came on every side
Which al love leyd aside
And of common his propre made
So that instead of shouel and spade
The sharp was take on hand
And in this wise it came to land
Whereof that men made dyches deep
And high walls for to keep
The gold which auaryce encloseth
But al to little him supposes
Though he myt all the world purchase
For that thing that may embrace
Of gold of catel or of land
Let it never out of his hond
But get him more and halt it fast
As though the world should ever last
So is he lyche unto the hell
For as these books tell
What comes there in less or more
It shall depart neuermore
Thus when he has his Cofer loken
It shall not after ben vnstoken
But when him list to have a sight
Of gold hou it shyneth bright
That he thereon may look and muse
For other wise he dare not use
To take his part or less or more
So is the power for evermore
Him lakketh that he has Enough
An ox draws in the plough
Of that him self has no profit
A sheep right in the same plyte
His wulle bears upon a day
Another takes the flees aweye
Thus has he yt he naught ne has
For he thereof his part ne tath
To seye hou such a man has good
Who so that reason understood
It is inproperlyche said
That good has him and halt him taid
That he ne gladeth naught with all
But is unto his good a thralle
And as a subget thus serves he
Where that he should Master be
Such is the king of Thauarous
My sone as thou art amerous
Tell if thou farest of love so
My fadre as it seems no
That auarous yet never I was
So as ye setten me the caas
For as ye tolden here above
In full possessyon of love
Yet was I never here to fore
So that me thinks well therefore
I may excuse well my deed
But of my will without dread
If I that tresour might get
It should never be foryete
That I ne would fast hold
Till god of love him selue would
That death us should depart a two
For leueth well I love her so
That even with mine own life
If I that sweet lusty wife
Might ones welden at my will
For I would hold her stylle
And in this wise takes keep
If I her had I would her keep
And yet no frydaye would I fast
Though I her kept and hold fast
Fie on the bags in the kyst
I had enough if I her kyst
For certes if she were mine
I had her lever than a mine
Of gold for all this world rich
Ne me might make so rich
As she that is so Inly good
I set naught of other good
For might I get such a thing
I had Tresour for a king
And though I would it fast hold
I were thereto mochel byholde
But I myt pype now with less
And suffer that it ouerpasse
Not with my will / for thus I would
Ben auarous if that I should
But fadre I you herd sey
Hou the auarous has yet sum wey
Whereof he may be glad for be
May when him list his tresour se
And grope and feel it al about
But I full often am shet there out
There as my worthy Tresour is
So is my life lyche unto this
That me tolden here to fore
Hou that an Ox his yok has bore
For thing that should him not avail
And in this wise I me travail
For who that ever has the welfare
I wot well that I have the care
And I am as who says loves knave
For I am had and naught ne have
Now deem in your own thought
If this be auaryce or naught
My sone I have of the no wonder
Thongh thou to serve be put under
With love which to kind acordeth
But so as every book records
At is to kind no plesaunce
That man above his sustenaunce
Unto the gold shall serve and bow
For that may no reason auowe
But Auaryce netheles
If he may geten his encrees
Of gold that would he serve and keep
For he takes of naught else keep
But for to fylle of his bags large
And al is to him but a charge
For he ne parts naught with all
But keeps as a servant shall
And thus though that he multyplye
His gold without Tresorye

With gold but if it be dyspended

Unto this king this god appears

He should it have of worldly good
This king was glad and stylle stood
And was of his axyng in doubt
And all the world he casts about
What thing was best for his ^state
And with him self stood at debate
Upon three points which I find
Ben leuest unto man's kind
The first of hem it is delight
The two ben worship and profit
And than he thought if that I crave
Delight though I delight may have
Delight shall passen in my age
That is no syker advantage
For every joy bodily
Shall end in woo / delight for thy
Wol I not chese / and if I worship
Axe and of the world lordshyp
That is an occupacyon
Of proud Imagynacyon
Which makes an heart veyn within
There is no certain for to win
For lord and knave is al one weye
When they be bore and when they deye
And if I profit axe would
I not in what manner I should
Of worlds good have sykernesse
For every thief upon richesse
A wayteth for to rob and stele
Such ^^ood is cause of harms feel
And also though a man at ones
Of all the world within his wones
The Tresour might have every deele
Yet had he but one man's dele
Toward him self so as I think
Of clothing of mete of drink
For more out take vanyte
There has no lord in his degree
And thus upon the points diverse
Dyuersly he began reherce
What point him thought for the best
But pleynly for to get him rest
He can no syker weye cast
And netheles yet at the last
He fell upon the couetyse
Of gold / and than in sundry wise
He thought as I have said to fore
How Tresour may be sone forlore
And had an Inly great desire
Touchend of such recover
Hou that he might his cause avail
To get him gold without fail
Within his heart and thus he preyseth
The gold and says hou that he peyseth
Above al other metal most
The gold he says may led an host
To make werre ayene a king
The gold put under al thing
And set whom him list above
The gold can make of hate love
And werre of pees. and right of wrong
And long to short and short to long
Without gold may be no fest
Gold is the lord of man and best
And may hem both bye and selle
So that a man may sothely tell
That all the world to gold obeys
For thy this king to bachus preyth
To grant him gold / but he excedeth
Mesure more than him needs
Men tellen that the maladye
Which called is Ioropesy^
Resembled is to this vice
By weye of kind and Auaryce
The more Idropesye drynketh
The more thyrsteth for him thinks
That he may not drink his fylle
So that there may no thing fulfylle
The lusts of his appetyte
And right in such manner plyte
Stant ever Auaryce and ever stood
The more he has of worsdes good
The more he would keep streyte
And ever more and more coueyte
And right in such condicyon
Without good discrecyon
This king with auaryce is smete
That all the world it might wete
For he to Bachus then preyd
That whereupon his hand he leid
It should thorugh his touch anon
Become gold / and thereupon
This god him grants as he bad
Tho was this king of Fryge glad
And for to put it in assaye
With / all the have that he may
He touches that he touches this
And in his hond al gold it is
The stone / the tree / the leef / the gras
The Flower the fruit al gold it was
Thus touches he while he may last
But hongre at the last
Him took so that he mote need
By wey of kind his hongre feed
The clothe was leyd / the board was set
And all was forth before him set
His dissh / his drink / his cup his meet
But when he would drynk or ete
As to his mouth anon came nyghe
It was al gold and then he syghe
Of Auayrce the folly
And he with that bygnne to cry
And preyde Bachus to foryeue
His gylt and suffer him for to live
And be such as he was to fore
So that he were naught forlore
This god which of this greuaunce
Herd / took routhe upon his repentance
And bad him goo forth redyly
Unto a flood was fast by
Which paceole than hight
In which as soon as ever he might
He should him wasshe oueral
And said him than he shall
Recouere his first astate ageyn
This king right as he herd seyn
In to the flood goth fro the land
And wesshe him both foot and hond
And so forth all the remenaunt
As him was set in ^^uendunt
And than he saw meruayles strange
The flood his color began to change
The grauel with the small stones
To gold they torn al attones
And he was quyte of that he had
And thus fortune his change lad
And when he saw his touch gone
He goth him home right forth soon
And lives forth as he did er
And put al Auaryce a fer
And the riches of gold despyseth
And seyth that mete and clothe suffyseth
Thus has this king experyence
Hou fools done the reverence
To gold which of his own kind
Is less worth than is the rynde
To sustenaunce of man's fode
Then he made laws good
And al his thing set upon skylle
He led his people for to tylle
Her l^nd and live under the law
And they also should forth draw
Bestayl and seche none encrees
^f gold which is the breche of pees
For this a man may find write
To fere the time that gold was smite
In coygne that men the floren knew
There was well nyhe noman untrue
There was another shield ne spear
Ne dedely wepen for to be bear
T^o was the town without wall
The which now is closed over all

Was mother first of malengyn

Which of his own propre vice
Which as the hell wonderful
For it may neuermore be full
That what as ever comes therynne
Awey it ne may never win
But sone mine do thou not so
Late al such auaryce go
And take thy part of that thou have
I bid not that thou do wast
But hold largess in mesure
And if thou see a creature
Which thorugh pouert is fall in need
Give him sum good for this I read
To him that wol not yeuen here
What pain he shall have else where
There is a pain among al
Bynethe in hell which men call
The woeful pain of Tantaly
Of which I shall the redely
Deuyse hou theryn men stond
In hell thou shall vnderst^nd
There is a flood of thylk office
Which serves al for auaryce
What man that stand shall therein
He stant up even to the chynne
Above his head also there hougeth
A fruit which to that pain longs
And that fruit touches ever in one
His ouerlyppe / and thereupon
Such thyrst and honger him assayleth
That never his appetyte ne fails
But when he wend his hongar feed
The fruit withdraws him at need
And though he have his head on high
The fruit is ever alyche nyghe
So is the honger well the more
And also though him thurst sore
And to the water bow adoune
The flood in such condycyon
Aualeth that his drink areche
He may not / loo now which a wreche
That mete and drynk is him so couthe
And yet there comth none in his mouth
Lyche to the peynes of this flood
Stant Auaryce in worlds good
He has Enough and yet him needs
For his scarcenes it him forbedeth
And ever his honger after / more
Trauayleth him alyche sore
So is he peyned oueral
For thy thy goods oueral
My sone look that thou dyspende
Whereof thou might thy self amend
Both here and eke in other place
And also if thou wolt purchase
To be loved thou must use
Largess for if thou refuse
To give for thy loves sake
It is no reason that thou take
Of love that thou would crave
For thy if thou wolt, grace have
Be gracyous and do largess
Of Auaryce and the sickness
Esche we above al other thing
And take ensample of Myde the king
And of the flood of hell also
Where is Enough of al woe
And though there were no matere
But only that we fynden here
Men ought Auaryce esche we
For what man thylk vice sewe
He get him self but little rest
For though so that the body rest
The heart upon the gold trauayleth
Whom many a nyt^s dread assaileth
For though he lygge a bed naked
His heart is evermore awaked
And dremeth as he lies to sleep
Hon besy that he is to keep
His Tresour that no thief it stele
Thus has he but a woeful well
And right so in the same wise
If thou thy self wolt well auyse
There be lovers of such Enough
That wol unto reason bough
If so ^e they come above
When they be maystres of her love
And that they sholden be most glad
With love they ben most bestad
So fayn they wolden it holden all
That her heart / her eye is ouerall
And wenen every man be a thief
To stele awey that hem is leef
Thus thorugh her own fantasye
They fallen in to Ielousye
Than has the ship to broke his cable
With every wind and is meuable

aMong the men lak of manhod
In marriage upon wyshode
Makes that a man him self deceyueth
Whereof it is yt he conceyueth
That ylke vnesy maladye
The which is cleped Ielousye
Of which if I the propyrte
Shall tell after the nyorte
So as it worcheth on a man
A fever it is cotydyan
Which every day wol come about
Where so a a man be in or out
At home if that a man wol wone
This fever is than of common wone
Most grievous in a man's eye
For than he makes him tote and prye
Where so his love ever go
She shall not with her little too
Mysteppe but he sees al
His eye is walkend oueral
Where that she sing or that she dau^ce
He sees the lest countenance
If she look on a man a side
Or with him rowne at any tide
Or that she laugh or that she ^oure
His eye is there at every hour
And when it draws to the night
If she so than be without light
Anon is all the game shente
For than he set his parliament
To speak it when he comes to bed
And says if I were now to wedde
I would neuermore have wife
And so he torneth in to stryf
The lust of loves dute
And al upon dyuersyte
If she be fresshe and well arrayed
He says her baner is dysplayed
To cle^e in gestes fro the weye
And if she be not well beseye
And that her list not to be glad
He beryth on hond that she is mad
And loves not her husbond
And says he may well understand
That if she would his company
She should than before his eye
She we all the plesaunce that she myt
So that by day ne by night
She not what thing is best
But lives well out of al rest
For what as ever him list seyn
She dare not speak one word ageyn
But wepeth and hold her lyppes cloos
She may well write Saunce ^^poos
The wife which is to such one married
Of al women be he waryed
For with his fever of jelousye
His each days fantasye
Of soro we is ever alyche grene
So that there is no love seen
While that him list at home abide
And when so as he wol out ride
T^^^ has he ready his ^spye
Abydyng in her company
A jangler an evil mouthed one
That she ne may no^^he there gone
Ne speak one word ne ones look
But he ne wol it wend and croke
And torn after his own intent
Though she no thing but honor meant
When that the lord comth home ageyn
The jangler must somewhat seyn
So what without and what withynne
This fever is ever to begin
For where he comes he can not end
Till death of him has made an end
For though so be that he ne here
Ne see nor wit in no manner
But al honor and womanhede
Thereof the Ielous takes none ^ede
But as a man to love unkind
He cast his staf as does the blind
And fynt defaulte where is none
As who so dremeth on a stone
Hou he is leyd and groneth often
When he lies on his pylowe soft
So is there naught but stryf and chest
Where love should make his rest
It is great thing if he her kiss
Thuo has she lost the nyghtes bliss
For at such time he grutcheth ever
And beryth on hond there is a lever
That she would another were
Instead of him abedde there
And with tho words and with mo
Of jelousye he torneth her fro
And lies upon his other side
And she with that draws her aside
And there she wepeth all the night
A to what pain she is dyght*
That in her thought has so beset
The bond which may not be vnknet
I wot the time is often cursed
That ever was the gold vnpursed
The which was leyd upon the book
When that al other she forsook
For love of him but al to late
She pleyneth for as than algate
She mo^e forbere and to him / ^owe
Though he ne would it allow
For man is lord of thylk feyre
So may the woman but empeyre
If she speak ought again thy will
And thus she beryth her pain stylle
But if this Fever a woman t^ke
She shall be well the more hard sha^^
But if she both see and here
And find that there is matere
She dare but to her self pleyne
And thus she suffers double pain
Loo thus my sone as I have ^ryt^
Thou might of jelousye wit
His fever and his condycyon
Which is fall of suspectyon
But whereof that this fever grows
Who so these old books too weth
There may he find hou it is
For they us teache and tell this
Hou that this Fever of jelousye
Somdele it grows of sotye
Of love and somdele of untrust
For as sekeman left his lust
And when he may no sauoure get
He hates than his own mete
Right so this feuerous maladye
Which caused is of fantasye
Makes the jelous in feeble plyght
To leave of love his appetyt
Thorugh feyned Informacyon
Of his Imagynacyon
But finally to taken heed
Men may well make a lykelyhede
Between him which is auarou^
Of gold and him that is Ir^^us
Of love for in one degree
They stand both as seems me
That one would have his bags still
And naught departen with his will
And dare not for the thieves sleep
So feign he would his tresour keep
That other may not well be glad
For evermore he is adrad
Of these lovers that gone about
In aunter if they put him out
So have they both little Joy
As well of love as of money
Now have thou sone at my techyng
Of Ielousye a knowlechyng
That thou might understand this
Fro when he comes and what he is
And eke to whom that he is like
Beware for thy thou be not syke
Of thylk fever as I have spoke
For it wol in him self be wroke
For love hates no thing more
As men may find by the lore
Of hem that whylome were wy^^
Hou they speak in many wise
My fader sothe is that ye seyn
But for to look there ageyn
Before this time hou it is fall
Whereof there might ensample fall
To such men as ben Ielous
In what manner it is grievous
Right fayn I would ensample here
My good sone at thy prayere
Of such ensamples I find
So as they comen now to mind
Upon this point of time gone
I think for to tellen one

These elements ben creatures
So ben these heavenly fygures
Whereof may well be iustyfyed
That they may not be deifyed
And what takes awey the honor
Which due is to the creator

Saturnus hight and king of Crete
He had be put out of his sete
He was put down as he which stood
In frenesye and was so wood
That fro his wife which Rea hight

De Hebreorum seu Iudeorum secta quorum Sinagoga coclesia Cristi superueniente

aFter the flood fro which Noe
Was sauf ye world in his degree
Was made as who seyth new agein
Of flour of fruit of gras of grein
Of be of bird and of mankind
Which ever has be to god unkind
For not with stondynge all the fare
Of that this world was made so bare
And afterward it was restored
Among the men was nothing mored
Toward god of good living
But al was turned to lykyng
After the flesh so that foryete
Was he which yafe hem life and mete
Of heuene and earth creator
And thus came forth the great error
That they the high god ne knew
But maden other gods new
As thou have herd me said to fore
There was no man that time bore
That be ne bad after his choys
A god / to whom he yafe his voys
whereof the mysbyleue came
In to the time of Abraham
But he fond out the right weye
How only men should obey
The high god which weldeth al
And ever has done and ever shall
In heaven / in earth / and eke in hell
There is no thing his might may tell
This Patryarche to his lygnage
Forbad that they to none Image
Enclyne should in no wise
But her offrend and sacryfyse
With all the hoole hertes love
Unto the mighty god above
And they should him and no mo
And thus in thylk time tho
Bygan the feyth upon the earth
Which of byleues was the ferthe
Of ryghtwysenes it was conceived
So must it needs be received
Of him that al right is Inn
The high god which would win
A people unto his own feyth
On Abraham the ground he leyth
And made him for to multyplye
In to so great a progenye
That they Egypt al over sprad
But Pharao with wrong hem lad
In seruytude ayene the pees
Till god let send Moses
To make the delyueraunce
And for his people great vengeannce
He took / which to here a wonder
The king was slain ye lo^d put under
God bad the reed see deuyde
Which stood vpryght on every side
And yafe unto his people a weye
That they on foot it passed dreye
And gone so forth in to desert
Where for to keep hem in covert
The days when the son brent
A large cloud hem over went
And for to wyssen hem by night
A fyry pyler hem alyght
And when that they for hongre pleyn
The mighty god began to reyne
Manna fro heaven down to ground
Whereof that each of hem has fonnde
His fode such right as him list
And for they should upon him tryst
Right as who set a tonne a broche
And perced the hard roche
And spronge out water al at will
That man and best has bronke at will
And afterward he yafe the law
To moses that hem withdraw
They should not fro that he bad
And in this wise they be lad
Till they took in possessyon

Where that Caleph and Iosue
The marches upon such degree
Departen after the lygnage
That each of hem as heritage
His pourpartye has vnderfonge
And thus stood this believe long
Which of prophets was governed
And they had eke the people learned
Of great honor that should hem fall
But at most need of all
They fayleden when Christ was bore
But hou that they her feyth have lore
It needs naught to tellen all The matter is so general
When Luafer was best in heuene
And ought most have stond in euene
Toward god he took debate
And for that he was obstynate
And would naught to truth enclyne
He fell for ever in to ruin
And Adam eke in paradys
When he stood most in all his prys^
After the state of Innocence
Ayene the god brake his defense
And fell out from his hye place a wey
And right by such manner weye
The Jews in her best plyght
When they should most parfyght
Have stand upon the prophecye
Tho fellen they to most folly
And him which was from heaven come
And of a maid his flesh has nome
And was among hem born and fed
As men that would naught be sped
Of gods sone with one voys
They henge and slough upon the croys
Whereof the parfyte of her law
Fro then forth was forth draw
So that they stand of no merit
Bnt in truage as folk subgect
Without propyrte of place
They lyuen out of gods grace
Dyspers in all lands out
And thus the feyth is come about^
That whylome in the Jews stood
Which is nonght parfytely good
To speak as it is now be fall
There is a feyth abouen all
In which the truth is comprehended
Whereof that we ben al amended
De fide Cristiana in qua perfect le gis complementum summi ^isterij
sacramentum nostreque saluacionis fundamentum infallibiliter consistere credimus

tHe high Almighty mageste
Of right wysenes and of pity
The sin / which that Adam wrout
When he saw time than he sout
And send his sone fro ye heuene
To set man's soul in euene
Which than was so forfalle
Upon the point which was so byfalle
That he ne might him self arise
Gregorye says in his apryse
It helps naught a man be bore
If gods sone were vnbore
For than through the first sin
Which whilom Adam brout us Inn
There sholden al men be lost
But Christ restores thylk lost
And bought it with his flesh and blood
And if we thynken hou it stood
Of thylk raunson which he paid
As saint gregorye it wrote and said
Al was behouely to the man
For that whereof his woo bygan
Was after cause of al his welthe
When he which is the well of health
The high creator of life
Upon the need of such a stryf
So would for his creature
Take on him self the forfeture
And suffer for the man's sake
Thus may no reason well forsake
That Ilke sin orygynal
Ne was the cause in specyal
Of man's worship at the last
Which shall withouten end last
For by that cause the godhede
Assembled was to the manhede
In the vyrgyne where he nome
Our flesh and very man become
Of bodily fraternity
Whereof the man in his degree
Stondeth more worthy as I have told
Then he did erst a thousand fold
Thorugh baptysme of the new law
Of the which Crist is lord and felawe
And thus the high gods might
Which was in the vyrgyne alyght
The man's soul has reconsyled
Which had long ben exyled
So stant the feyth upon the believe
Without which may no man acheue
To get him paradys ageyn
But this believe is so certain
So full of grace and of virtue
That what man that clepeth to Ihesu
In clean life forth with good deed
He may not faylen of heaven mede
So that it stand upon believe
That every man may well acheue
The which taken has the right feyth
For else as the gospel seyth
Salvation there may be none
And for to preche therupone
Thus Christ bad to his Apostles all
Whose power as now is fall
On us that be of holy church
If we the good deeds do wirche
For feyth only suffyseth naught
But good deed also be wrought
Now were it good that thou for thy
Which thorugh baptysme propyrly
Art unto Crystes feyth professed
Be wa^e that thou be not oppressed
With Antecrystes lollardye
For as the Jews prophecye
Was set of god for advantage
Right so this new tapynage
Of lollardye goth about
To set Crystes feyth in doubt
The saints that were us to fore
By whom the feyth was first up bore
That holy church stood releued
They oughten better be byleued
Than these which men know
Not holy though they feyne and blow
Here lollardye in man's ere
But if thou wylt live out of fere
Such new lore I read eschew
And hold forth the right weye and sewe
As thyn Auncestres did or this
So that thou believe naught amys
Christ wrought first / and after taught
So that the deed his word araught
He yafe ensample in his person
And we the words have alone
Like to the tree with leaves grene
Upon the which no fruit is seen

dAme Avarice is nout soleyn
Which is of gold the capiteyn

She has of servants many one
Whereof that couetyse is one

Where that he may profit win

wHen Rome stood ^ noble plite
Virgile which was tho parfite
A myrrour made of his cler^^ /
And set it in the To wnes eye

That they by thyrty mile about

^yr enemies if any* were

So that while thylk myrrour last

With werre Rome for to grieve*
Whereof was great envy tho
And fell thylk time so
That Rome had werres strong
Again Cartage and stand long
The two cytees upon debate
Cartage saw the strong astate
Of Rome in thylk myrroure stand
And thought al pryuely to fond
To overthrow it by sum wyle
And hanybal was thylk while
The prince and leder of Cartage
Which had set al his courage
Upon knyghthode in such a wise
That he be worthy and be wise
And by none other was counseyled
Whereof the world is yet merueyled
Of the maystryes that he wrought
Upon the marches which he sought
And fell in thylke time also
The king of puyle which was tho
Thought ayene Rome to rebelle
And thus was take the quarelle
Hou to destroy this Emperor
Of Rome that tho was governor
Crassus which was so covetous
That he was ever desirous
Of gold to get the pyllage
Whereof that puyle and eke Cartage
With philosophres wise and great
Begynne*of this matter trete
And at last in this degree
There were Philosophres three
To do this thing which undertake
And thereupon they * with hem took

To gedre in company went
But noman wise what they meant
When they to Rome come were
