As they that thoughten to deceyne
Was none that myt of hem perceive
Till they in sundry stedes have
Her gold under the earth begraue
In tresours that to be hold
They sheld seem as they were gold
And so forth then upon a day
Al openly in good array*
To the emperor they then present
And tolden it was her entente
To duelle under his seruyse
And he hem axeth in what wise
And they him told in such a plyte
That each of hem had a spyryt
The which sle^end a night appears
And hem by sundry dremes lereth
After the world that has betyd
Under the ground if ought be hyd
Of old tresour at any throw
They shall it in sweuene know
And upon this condycyon
They*seyn what gold under the town
Is hyd of Rome they wol it find
There shall naught be left behind
Be so that he haluen dele
Hem grants and he assenteth well
And thus came sleyghte for to duelle
With couetyse as I the tell
This emperor bad redyly
That they be lodged fast by
Where he his own body lay
And when it was at morrow day

Whereof this Emperor was glad

His ^^nours for to goo and mine

Goth forth with all and at his hond

Where as they said it should be
And who was than glad but he

Now herkne the subtylyte

Which as they saiden should mete

And he without noise or bost
Al pryuelycho so as he would
Upon the morrow his sweuene told
To the emperor right in his ere
And said him that he wist where

Of gold and eke so precious
Of Iewelles and rich stones
That unto al his horse at ones
It were a charge suffisaunt
This lord upon this covenant
Was glade and axeth where it was
The master said under the glass
He told him eke as for the mine

That they the werk should vndersett
With timbre and without let
Men may the Tresour sauely delue

And thus the master upon hand
Has undertake in all weye

And set her Emperor therein
And sayden for he would win

Of gold he should plente

And thus ye thirst of / gold was queint

When couetyse has lost the stere
Of reasonable governance
There falls often great greuaunce
For there may be no werse thing
Then couetyse about a king
If it in his person be
It does the more aduersyte
And if it in*his counseyl stond
It brings al day meschyef to hond
Of common harm and yf*it grow
Within his court it wol be know
For than shall the king be*pyled
The man which has his land tyled
Awayteth naught more redyly
The heruest than they gredely
Ne maken then ward and watch
Where they the profit myten catch
And yett full often it falls so
As men may seen among hem tho
That he which most coueyteth fast
Has lest advantage at last
For when fortune is there again
Though he coueyte it is in vein
The happes ben naught al alyche
One is made pouer another rich
The court to some it does profit
And some ben ever in one plyte
And yet they both alyche sore
Coueyte but fortune is more
Unto that one part favorable
And though it be naught reasonable
This thing may a man seen al day

After ensample in remembrance

IN a Cronyke this I read
About a king as must need
Thereof was knights and squyers
Great route and eke officers
Some of long time him had served
Ano thouten that they have deseruid
Auauncement and gone without
And some also ben of the route
That comen but a while agone
And they auaunced were anon
These old men upon this thing
So as they durst ageyn the king
Among hem self compleynen often
But there is no thing said so soft
That it ne comes out at last
The king it wist and als fast
As he which was of high prudence
He shope therefore an euydence
Of hem that pleynen in that cas
To know in whose defaute it was
And al within his own intent
That noman wist what it meant
Anon he beat two cofres make
Of one semblaunce of one make
So lyche that no life thylk throw
That one may fro that other know
They were in to his Chamber brought
But noman wot why they be brout
And netheles the king has bid
That they be set in pryue stead
As he yt was of wisdom sly
When he thereto his time sygh
Al pryuelyche that none it wist
His own hondes that one kyst
Of fyn gold and fine perrye
The which out of his tresorye
Was take anon he feld full
That other cofre of straw and mull
With stones meuyd he feld also
Thus be they full both two
So that erlyche upon a day
He bad within there he lay
There should to fore his bed
A board up set and fair spread
And than he let the cofres fette
Upon the board and did hem set
He knew the names well of tho
The which ayene him grutched so
Both of his chamber and of his halle
Anon and sent for hem all
And said to hem in this wise
There shall no man him despise
I wot well ye have long served
And god wot what ye have deserved
But if it is on long on me
Of that ye bnauaunced be
Or else if it be long on you
The soth shall be preued now
To stop with your evil word
Loo here two Cofres on the board
These which you list of both two
And wyteth well that one of tho
As with Trosour so full bygone
That if ye hap therupone
Ye shall be rich men for ever
Now chese and take which you is lever
But be well ware or that ye take
For of that one I undertake
There is no manner good therein
Whereof ye myghten profit win
Now goth to gyder of one assent
And makes your auysement
For but I you this day auaunce
It stant upon your own chance
Al only in defaulte of grace
So shall be showed in this place
Upon you all well ofyne
That no defaute shall be mine
They knelen al and and with one voys
The king they thanken of this choys
And after that they up arise
And gone aside and hem auyse
And at last they acorde
Whereof her tale to record
That to what yssu they befalle
A knight shall speak for hem all
He kneleth down to the king
And says that they upon this thing
Or for to win or for to lose
Ben al auysed for to chese
Tho took this knyhht a yerd on hond
And goth there as the cofres stond
And with thassent of eueryehone
He leyd his yard upon one
And seyth the king hou thylk same
They chese in reguerden by name
And preyth him yt they myt it have
The king which would his honor save /
When he has herd the common voys
Has grants hem her own choys
And took hem thereupon the keye
But for he would it were seye
What good they have as they suppose
He bad anon the cofre unclose
Which was fulfilled of straw and stones
Thus be they served al at ones
This thing than in the same stead
Anon that other Cofre vndede
Where as they sawen great Richesse
Well more than they couthen guess
Loo serth the king now may ye see
That there is no defaute in me
For thy my self I wol acquyte
And bears ye your own wit
Of that fortune has refused
Thus was this wise king excused
And they left of here cuyl speech
And mercy of here king byseche

I find a tale hou frederyk
Of Rome that time emperor
Herd as he went a great clamor
Of two beggars upon the weye
That one of hem bygan to seye
A lord well may the man be Rich
Whom that a king list to rich
That other said no thing so
But he is rich and well begoo
To whom that god wol send well
And thus they maden words feel
Whereof this lord has head nome
And did hem both for to come
To the paleys where he shall ete
And bad ordeyne for her mete
Two pasteyes which he let do make
And a capon in that one was bake
And in that other for to win
Of floreyns all that* may within
He let do put a great Richesse
And even as lyche as might guess
Outward they were both two
This beggar was commanded tho
He that which held him to the king
That he first chese / upon this thing
He saw hem but he felt hem naught
So that upon his own thought
He chese the capon and forsook
That other / which his felawe took
But when he wist hou that it ferde
He seyth aloude that men it herd
Now am I certainly conceived
That he may lightly be deceived
That trysteth unto man's help
But well is him that god wol help
For he stant on the syker side
Which else should goo beside
I see my felawe well recover
And I mote duelle stylle pouer
Thus spak the beggar his intent
And pouer he came and pouer he went
Of that he has Richesse sought
His infortuue it would naught
So may it show in sundry wise
Between fortune and couetyse
The chance is cast upon a dee
But yet a man may full often see
Inowe of such netheles
Which put hem self ever in pres
To get hem good / and yet they fail
And for to speak of this entayle
Touchend of love in thy matere
My good sone as thon might here
That right as with tho men stood
Of infortune of worlds good
As thou have me herd tell above
Right so full often it stant by love
Though thou coueyte it evermore
Thou shall have no dele the more
But only that which the is shape
The remenaunt is but a iape
And netheles I now of tho
There ben that now coueyte so
That where as they a woman see
Ye ten or twelve though there be
The love is now so unadvised
That where the beauty stant assysed
The man's heart anon is there
And rouneth tales in her ere
And seyth how that he loves streyte
And thus he set him to coueyte
An honderd though he saw a day
So should he more than he may
But for the great couetyse
Of sotye and fool empryse
In each of hem he fynt somewhat
That pleseth him or this or that
Some one for she is white of kyn
Some one for she is noble of kyn
Some one for she has a rody cheke
Some one for that she seems meke
Some one for she has eyes greye
Some one for she can laugh and pleye
Some one for she is long and small
Some one for she is lyte and tal
Some one for she is pale and bleche
Some one for she is soft of speech
Some one for that she is camused
Some one for that she has not be used
Some one for she can dauuce / and sing
So that some thing to his lykyuge
He fynt and though no more he feel
But that she has a little hele
It is Enough that he therefore
Her love and thus an honderd score
While they be new he would he had
Whom he forsakes she shall be bad
The blind man no color demeth
But al is one right as him seems
So has his lust no judgment
Whom couetyse of love blent
Him thinks that to his couetyse
How all the world ne may suffyse
For by his will he would have all
If that it might so byfalle
So is he common as the street
I set naught of his beyete
My sone have thou such couetyse
Nay fader such love I despise
And while I live shall done ever
For in good feyth yet had I lever
Than to coueyte in such a weye
To ben for ever till I deye
As pour as Job and loueles
Out taken one for haules
His thanks is noman a live
For than a man should al vnthryue
There ought no wyseman coueyte
The law was not set so streyte
For thy my self with all to save
Such one there is I would have
And noue of al these other mo
My sone of that thou would so
I am naught wroth bnt over this
I wol the tell hou it is
For there be men which otherwise
Right ouly for the couetyse
Of that they see a woman rich
There wol they al her love affyche
Nonght for the beauty of her face
Ne yet for virtue ne for grace
Which she has else right Enough
But for the park and for the plough
And other things which thereto lo^geth /
For in none otherwise there longs /
To love but if they profyt find
And if the profit be behind
Her love is ever less and less
For after that she has richesse
Here love is of proporcyon
If thou have such condycyon
My sone tell right as it is
Mine holy fader nay Iwys
Condycyon such have I none
For truly fader I love one
So well with all mine hertes thoug^ht
That certes though she had naught
And were as pour as Medea
Which was exyled for Creusa
I would her naught the less love
Ne though she were at her above
As was the Rich queen Canda^e
Which to deserve love and grace
To Alysander that was king
Yofe many a worthy rich thing
Or else as Pantasylee
Which was the queen of Femyne
And great Richesse with her nam
When she for love of Hector came
To Troy in rescous of the town
I am of such condycyon
That though my lady of her selue
Where also rich as such twelve
I couthe not though it were so
No better love her than I do
For I love in so pleyne a wise
That for to speak of couetyse
As for pouerte or for richesse
My love is nouther more ne less
For in good feyth I tro we this
So covetous no man is
For why and he my lady syghe
That he thorugh lokyng of his eye
Ne should have such a stroke withyn
That for no gold he might wyn
He should naught her love asterte
But if he left there his heart
Be so it were such a man
That couthe-skylle of a woman
For there be men so rude some
When they among the women come
They gone under protectyon
That love and his affectyon
Ne shall not take hem by the sleue
For they ben out of that believe
Hem lusts of no lady cheer
But ever thynkend here and there
Where as the gold is in the Cofte
And wol none other love profre
But who so wot what love amou^teth
And by reason trulyche acompteth
Then may he know and taken head
That all the lust of womanhede
Which may ben in a lady face
My lady has and eke of grace
If men should yeuen here apryse
They may well seye hou she is wise
And sobre and simple of contenaunce
And all that to good governance
Belongs of a worthy wight
She has pleynly for thylk night
That she was bore as for the nones
Nature set in her al at ones
Beauty with bounte so byseyn
That I may well afferme and seyn
I saw yet never creature
Of comlyheede and of feture
In any kings Regyon
Be lyche her in comparyson
And thereto as I have you told
Yet has she more a thousand fold
Of bounte and shortly to tell
She is pure heed and well
And myrroure and ensample of good
Who so her virtues understood
Me thinks it ought enough suffyse
Withouten other couetyse
To love such one and to serve
Which with her chere can deserve
To be byloued better ywys
Than she par cas that rychest is
And has of gold a mylyon
Such has be mine opinion
And ever shall / and nevertheless
I say naught she is haueles
That she nys rich and well at ese
And has Enough where with to plese
Of worlds good whom that her list
But one thing I would well ye wist
That never for no worlds good
Mine heart unto her ward stood
But only right for purr love
That wot the high god above
Now fader what ye say thereto
Confessor
My sone I say it is well do
For take of this right good believe
What man that wol him self releue
To love in any other wise
He shall well find his couetyse
Shall sore grieve him at last
For such a love may not last
But now men seyn our days
Men taken but a few assayes
But if the cause be richesse
For thy the love is well the less
And who that would ensamples tell
By old days as they fell
Than might a man well understand
Such love may not long stand
Now herkne sone and thou shall here
A great ensample of this matere

Of puyle whysome was a king
A man of high complexyon
And young but his affectyon
After the nature of his age
Was yet not fall in his courage
The lust of women for to know
So it betyd upon a throw
This lord fell in to great sekenes
Phisyk has done the hesynes
Of sundry cures many one
To make him hoole and thereupon
A worthy master which there was
Yafe him counseyl upon this cas
That if he would have parfyte heel
He should with a woman dele
A fresshe a young a lusty wight
To done him compauye a night
For than he said him redely
That he shall be al hole there by
And otherwise he knew no cure
This king which stood in adventure
Of life and death for medycyne
Assented was and of couyne
His styward whom he trusts well
He took and told him every del
Hou that this master has said
And thereupon he has him prayed
And charged upon his lygeaunce
That he do make purueaunce
Of such one as be couenable
For his plesaunce and delytable
And bad him hou that ever it stood
That he shall spare for no good
For his will is right well to pay
The styward said he would assaye
Bnt now here after thou shall wit
As I find in the books write
What couetyse in love does
This styward for to tell soth
Among all the men on live
A lusty lady has to wyue
Which netheles for gold he took
And nout for love as seyth the book
A rich merchant of the land
Her fader was and her fond
So worthily / and such Richesse
Of worlds good and such largess
With her he yafe in marriage
That only for thylk advantage
Of gold the styward has her take
For lucre and naught for loves sake
And that was in the stiward well seen
Now herkne what it wol mean
The styward in his own heart
Sow that his lord may not asterte
His maladye but he have
A lusty woman him to save
And though he would give Enough
Of his tresour whereof he drough
Great couetyse in to his mind
And set his honor fer behind
Thus he whom gold has ouerset
Was trapped in his own net
The gold has made his wits lame
So that sechend his own shame
He rouneth in the kings ere
And said that he wyste where
A gentyl and a lusty one
Tho was and thither would he gone
But he mote yiue yeftes great
For but if it be through great beyete
Of gold he said he should not speed
The king him bad upon the need
That take an honderd pound he should
And give it where that he would
Be so it were in worthy place
And thus to stand in loves grace
This king his gold has habandouned
And when this tale was full rouned
The Styward took the gold and went
Within his heart and many a went
Of couetyse than he cast
Whereof a purpoos at the last
Ayene love and ayene his right
He took and said hou thylk night
His wife shall lygge by the kyng^
And goth thynkend upon this thing
Toward his Inn till he ca in home
In to the chamber and there he nome
His wife and told her all the cas
And she which read for shame was
With both her hands has him praid
^enelend / and in; this wise said
That she to reason and to skylle
In what thing that he bydde will
Is ready for to done his heste
But this thing were not honest
That he for gold her should selle
And he tho with his words fell
Forth with his gastely contenaunce
Seyth that she shall done obeysaunce
And follow his will in every place
And thus through strength of his ma
nace / Her Innocence is ouerlad
Whereof she was so sore adrad
That she his will mote need obey
And thereupon was shape a weye
That he his own wife by night
Has out of al men's sight
So pryuely that none it wist
Brout to the king which as him list
May do with her what he would
For when she was there as she should
With him a bed under the cloth
The styward took his leave and goth
In to the chamber fast by
But hou he slepte that wot not I
For he saw cause of Ielousye
But he which has the company
Of such a lusty one as she
Him thought that of his degree
There was noman so well at ese
She does all that she may to plese
So that al / his heart she had
And thus this king his joy lad
Till it was nyhe upon the day
The Styward than where she lay
Came to the bed and in his wise
Has bid she should arise
The king said nay she should not go
His styward said again naught so
For she mote gone er it be know
And so I swore that ylke throw
When I her fette to you here
The king his tale would not here
And seyth hou that he has her bout
For thy she shall depart naught
Till the bright day be hold
And in his arms he began her fold
As he which list for to pleye
And bad his styward gone aweye
And so he did ayene his will
And thus his wife a bed stylle
Lay with the king the long night
Till that it was high son light
But who she was he knew no thing
Tho came the styward to the king
And prayed him that without shame
In saving of her own name
He might leden home ayene
This lady and told him pleyne
Hou that it was his own wife
The king his ere unto his stryf
Has leyd and when that he it herd
Well nyhe out of his wit he ferde
And said A caytyf most of al
Where was it ever or this byfalle
That any Coward in this wise
Betoke his wife for conetyse
Thou have her and me begyled
And eke thine own estate reuyled
Whereof that buxome unto the
Here after shall she never be
For this auowe to god I make
After this day if I the take
Thou shall be honged and to draw
Now look anon thou be withdraw
So that I see the never more
This Styward that drad him sore
With all the have that he may
And fled awey the same day
And was exyled out of land
Loo there a nyce hysbond
Which thus his wif has lost for ever
But netheles she had a lever
The king her weddeth and honors
Whereof her name she secoureth
Which erst was lost through couetyse
Of him that lad her other wise
And has him self also forlore
My sone be thou ware therefore
Where thou shall love in any place
That thou no couetyse embrace
The which is not of loves kind
But for all that a man may find
Now in this time of thylk rage
Full great dysese in marriage
When venym medleth with the sucre^
And marriage is made for lucre
Or for the lust or for the hele
What man that shall with other dele
He may not fail to repent
My fader such is mine entente
But netheles good is to have
For good may oftyme save
The love which should else spylle
But god which wot my hertes will
I dar well take to witness
Yet was I never for Richesse
Be set with marriage none
For all mine heart is upon one
So freely that in the person
Stant al my worlds joy alone
I axe another park ne plough
If I her had it were Enough
Her love should me suffyse
Withouten other couetyse
Loo now my fader as of this
Touchend of me right as it is
My shryfte I am be know pleyn
And if yr wol ought else seyn
Of couetyse if there be more
In love agropeth out the sore

mY sone thou shall understand
Hou couetyse has yet on ho^de
In specyal two cou^seyllours
That been also his procurours
The first of hem is false witness
Which ever is ready to witness
What thing his master wol him hot
Periure is the second hot
Which spares naught to swear an oath
Though it be falls and god be wroth
That one shall falls wytnes bear
That other shall the thing for swear
When he his charged on the book
So what with hepe and what with croke
They make here master often win
And wol not know what is the sin
Of couetyse and thus men seyn
They make many a falls barg^eyn
There may no true quarrel arise
In thylk queste and thylk assyse
Where as they two the people inform
For they keep ever one manner form
That upon gold here conscience
They found and take here euydence
And thus with falls wytnes and oaths
They win hem mete drynk and clothe^
Right so there be who that hem knew
Of these lovers full many untrue
Now may a woman find ynowe
That each of hem when he shall wowe
Anon he would his hand down leyn
Upon a book and swear and seyn
That he wol feyth and truth bear
And thus he profereth him to swe^e
T^ se^uen ever till he deye
And al is very trecherye
For when the soth him self tries
The more he sw^reth the more he lies
When he his feyth makes al there m^st
Then may a woman trust him lest
For till he may his will acheue
He is no l^nger for to leave
Thus is the truth of love exyled
An^ ma^y a good woman begyled
And eke to speak of falls witness
There be now such many I g^sse
That lyche unto the prouysours
They make hem her preuy procura
tours To tell hou there is such a man
Which is worthy to love and can
All that a good man should conne
So that with lesyng he has bygo^ne
The cause in which he wol proceed
And also syker as the creed
They make of that they known falls
And thus full often about the hals
Love is of falls men embraced
But love which is so purchaced
Come afterward to little pryse
For thy my sone / if thou be wise
Now thou have herd this euydence
Thou might thine own conscience
Oppose if thou have be such one
Nay god wot fader I am none
Ne never was / for as men seyth
When that a man shall make his feyth
His heart and tongue must acorde
For if so be that they dyscorde
Then is he falls and else naught
And I dare say as of my thought
In love it is not dyscordable
Unto my word but a^ordablo
And m this wise fader I
May right well swear and saufly
That I my lady love well
For that acordeth every del
It needs naught to my soth saw
That I witness should draw
In to this day for never yett
Ne might it synke in to my wit
That I my counseyl should seye
To any wight or me bewreye
To sechen help in such manner
But only of my lady dear
And though a thousand men it wys^
That I her love and than ^em list
With me to swer^ and to witness
Yet were that no falls witness
For I dare unto this truth dwell
I love her more than I can tell
Thus am I fader gylteles
As ye have herd / and nethele^
In your dome I put it al
My sone wit in specyal
It shall not comonlyche fail
Al though it for a time faylle
That falls witness his cause speed
Upon the point of his falsheede
It shall afterward be kyd
Whereof so as it is betyd
Ensample of such things blind

IN greece whylome was a king
Of whom the fame and knoulechyng
Byleueth yet and peleus
He hyghte but it fell him thus
That his fortune her whele so lad
That he no child his own had
To regne after his decesse
He had a brother netheles
Whose right name was Eson
And he has the worthy knight Jason
Bygoten / in which in every land
Al other passed of his hond
In arms so that he the best
Was named and the worthyest
He sought worship oueral
Now herkne and I the tell shall
An adventure that he sought
Which afterward full dear he bought
There was an I Will which Colchos
Was cleped and thereof awos
Great speech in land about
That such marvel was none out
In all the wide world nowhere
As tho in that I Will there
There was a sheep as it was told
The which his flees bare al of gold
And so the gods had it set
That it ne might a wey be fette
By power of no worlds wight
And yet full many a worthy knight
At had assayed as they dorst
And ever it fell hem to the worst
But he that would it naught forsake
But of his knyghthode undertake
To do what thing thereto belongs
This worthy Jason sore alongeth
To see the strange regyons
And know the condycyous
Of other / marches where he went
And for that cause his hoole intent
He set Colchos for to seek
And thereupon he did* speak
To Peleus his eme the king
And he well paid was of that thing
And shope anon for his passage
Such as were of his lygnage
With other knights which he chees
With him he took and Hercules
Which full was of chyualrye
With Jason went in company
And that was in the month of may
When cold storms were away
The wynd was good ye ship was yare
They took her leave and forth they fare
Toward Colchos but on the weye
What hem byfelle is long to seye
Hou Lamedon the king of Troy
Which ought well have made hem ioyr
When they to rest a while him preide
Out of his land he hem congeyde
And so fell the dyssencyon
Which afterward was destructyon
Of that cite as men may here
But that is not to my matere
But thus this worthy folk gregoys
Fro that king which was not curtois
And fro his land with seyl vpdrawe
Then^e went hem forth and many a saw
They made and many a great manace
Till at last in to that place
Which as they sought they arryue
And stryken seyle and forth as blyue
They senten unto the king and tolden
Who were there and what they wolden
Oetes which than was king
When that he herd this tydyng
Of Jason which was comen there
And of these other what they were
He thought done hem great worship
For they anon come out of ship
And strayt unto the king they went
And by the hand Jason he hent
And that was at the paleys gate
So fer on the king came on his gate
Toward Jason to done hem chere
And he whom lakketh no manner
When he the king saw in presence
Yafe him ageyn such reverence
As to a kings state belongs
And thus the king him vnderfongeth
And Jason in his arm he caught
And forth in to the halle he straught
And there they sat and speak of thyngis
And Jason told him tho tydyngys
Why he was come and fair him prayde
To haste his time and the king said
Jason thou art a worthy knight
But it lies in no man's might
To done that thou art come fore
There has be many a knight forlore
Of that they wolden it assaye
But Jason him would not esmaye
And / said of / every / worlds cure
Fortune stant in adventure
Parauenter well parauenter woo
But hou as ever that it goo
It shall be with mine hond assayed
The king tho held him not well paid
For he the greeks sore dredde
In aunter if Jason ne spedde
He might thereof here a blame
For tho was all the worlds fame
In Greece as for to speak of arms
For thy he drad him of his harms
And began to preche him and to preye
But Jason would not obey
But said he would his purpoos hold
For ought that any man him told
When the king these words herd
And saw how that the knyt ansuerde
Yet for he would make him glad
After Medea gone he had
Which was his daughter and she came
And Jason which good head nam
When he her saw ageyn her goth
And she which was him nothing loath
Welcomed him in to that land
And soft took him by the hand
And down they seten both same
She had herd spoke of his name
And of his great worthynes
For thy she began her eye inpresse
Upon his face and his stature
And thought hou never creature
Was so welfarend as was he
And Jason right in such degree
Nc might not withholde his look
But so good head on her he took
That him ne thout under the heuene
Of beauty saw he never her euene
With all that fell to womanhede
Thus each of other took head
Though there was no word of record
Here hertes both of one acord
Ben set to love but as tho
There myghten be no words mo
The king him made great joye and fest
To al his men he yaf an hest
So as they wol his thank deserve
That they should al Jason serve
While that he would there duelle
And thus the day shortly to tell
With many myrthes is dyspent
Till night was come and tho they went
Echone of other took his leave
When they no longer myghten leave
A not hou Jason that night sleep
But well I wot that of the sheep
For which he came in to that isle

Upon the benche syttend on hy
With auaryce usure I syghe
Full clothed of his own suit
Which after good makes chase and suit
With his brocours that run about
Lyche unto ratches on a route
Such lucre is none above ground
Which is not of the ratches found
For where they see beyete sterte
That shall hem in no wise asterde
But they it drive in to the net
Of lucre which usure has set
Usure with the rich duelleth
To all that ever he byeth and sells
He has ordained of his sleyghte
Mesure^ double and double weyghte
Outward he sells by the less
And with the more he makes his tasse
Whereof his house is full withynne
He retcheth naught be so he win
Though that he lose ten or twelve
His love is al toward him selue
And to none other but he see
That he may win such three
For where he shall ought give or lene
He wol ayene ward take a been
There he has lent the small pese
And right so there be many of these
Lovers that though they* love a lyte
That scarsely would it weye a myte
Yet would they have a pound again
And does usure in his bargeyn
But certes such usure vnlyche
It falls more unto the rich
Als well of love as of beyete
Than unto hem that be not great
And as who says be simple and pouer
For seldom is when they recover
But if it be thorugh greet deserte
And netheles men see pouerte
With pursuit and contenaunce

Ne yet so mochel soth to seyn

That for the hoole I might have half
My thinks I were a goddess half
For where usure would have double
My conscience is not trouble
I bid never as to my dele
But of the hole an haluen dele
That is none excess as me thinks
But netheles it me forthynketh
For well I wot that wol not be
For every day the better I see
That ho^ so ever I give or lene
My love in place there I mean
For ought that ever I axe or crave
I can nothing ayeneward have

That I ne shall give and lene
My love and al my thought so clean
That toward me shall nougt believe
And if she of her good leave

I wot the last of my bargeyn

That I may never more the cost

She has me won to her man
Whereof me thinks good reason would
That she somdele reward should
And give a part there she has al
I not what fall herafter shall
But in to now yet dare I seyne
Her list never give again
A good word in such a wise
Whereof mine hope might arise
My greet love to compense
I not hou she her conscience
Excuse wol of this usure

She has my love and I have naught

And with mine heart I have it paid
But all this is aside laid
But I go loueles about
Her ought stand in right great doubt
Till she redress such a sin
That she wol al my love win
And yeueth me not to live by
Naught also much as grant mercy
Her list to seye of which I might
Some of my greet pain alyght
But of this point lo thus I fare
As he that pays for his Chaffare
And byeth it dear and yet has none
So mote he needs pouer gone
Thus bye I dear and have no love
That I ne may come above
To win of love none encrece
But I me will never the lose
Touchend usure of love acquyte
And if my lady be to wit
I pray to god such grace her send
That she my time it must amend

Touchend usure / I have al herd
How thou of love have wonnen small
But that thou tellest in thy tale

Me thinks thy words thou mysusist
For by thine own knowlechyng
Thou say that she for one lokyng
Thy hole heart fro the she took
She may be such that her one look
Is worth the heart many fold
And than have thou thy heart well sold
When thou have that is more worthy
And also that thou tellest for thy
How that her weight of love uneven
May to thy semyng under heaven
Stand ever even in that balaunce
The which stondeth in loves gouerna^ce

That though thy love more draw
And peyse in the balaunce more

Of doubt / but all of grace

There may no law him Iustyfye

That he ne will after his will

That wot no man till at the last

My sone / but abide thyn end
Per c^as al may to good wend

Engyned love for such deed
Is more venged as I read

in Ynos as tells the poet
The wiche was sometime king of Crete / A sone he had and androche / He hight
and so befell^ that he
unto Athenis for to ^ere
Was sent / and so he bare him there
For that he was of his lygnage
Such pride he took in his courage
That (...) forgeten has the scoles
And in ryote among fools
He did many things wrong
And used that life so long
Til at the last of that be wrought
He fond the meschyef yt which he sout
Where thorugh he fell yt he was slain
His fader the which it herd sayn
Was wroth / and all that ever he might
Of men of arms he him dyght
A strong power and forth he went
Unto Athenis where he brent
The pleyne country al about
The Cytees stood of him in doubt
As they no defense had
Again the power that he ladde
Egeus that was there king
His cou^ceylle took upon this thing
For he was than in the Cite
So that of pees in to trete
Bitwene mynos and Egeus
They feel and ben acorded thus
That king mynos fro year to year
Receive shall as thou shall here
Out of Athenys for truage
Of men that were of mighty age
Persons nine. of which he shall
His will do in special
For vengeance of his sons death
None other grace there ne geth
But for to take the Iuyse
And for that was done in such a wise
The which stood in a wonder ca as
For that time so it was
Whereof that men yet read and sing
King mynos had in his keeping
A cruel monstre as seith the geste
For he was half man and half beeste
And mynotaurus he was hot
The which was bigoten in a ryote
Upon Phasyfe his own wife
Whiles he was out upon the strif
Of that greet syege of Troy
But she that lost has al joy
When that she saw this moustre bore
Bad men ordeyne another fore
And it fell that same time thus
There was a Clerk one Dedalus
That had been of her assent
Of that her world has myswent
As he that made of his own wit
Whereof the remembrance is yet
For mynotaure such a hows
That was so strong and merueylous
That what man within went
There was so many a diverse went
That he ne shall come out
But go amasyd al about
And in this hows to look and ward
Was mynotaurus put in ward
That what life that therm came
Man or be he ouercam
And slew and fed him thereupon
And in this wise many one
Of Athenys for truage
Devoured were in that rage
For every year they shopen hem so
They of Athenys or they go
Toward thylke woeful channce
As it was set in ordinance
Upon fortune her lot they cast
Til that Theseus at the last
The which was ye kings son there
Among other that there were
In that there as it be fell
The lot upon his chance fell
He was a knight worthy with all
And when he saw his chance fall
He ferd as though he took no head
But all that ever he might speed
With him and with his felauship
Forth in to greece he goth by ship
Where that the king mynos he sought
And profereth all that him is ought
Upon the point of her acorde
This stern king / this cruel lord
Took every day one of the nine
And put him in to disciplyne
Of mynotaure to be devoured
But Theseus was so favored
That he was kept till at the last
And the mean while he cast
What mean thing him were best to do
And fell that Adryane tho
The which was the douter of mynos
And had herd the worthy los
Of Theseus and of his might
And saw that he was a lusty knight
For hole heart on him she laid
And he that also of love her prayed
So ferforth that they were alone
And ordained that anon
In what manner he should him save
And shope so that she did him have
A clewe of threde the wiche withynne
First at-the door he shall begin
And when he would ageyn ward wend
With him to take that one end
He ^^^^t go the same wey
And over this so as I sey
Of speech she took him a pelot
The which he should in to the throat
Of mynotaure cast right
Such wepen also for him she dyght
That he by reason may not fail
To make an end of his battle
For she him taught in diverse wise
Till he was co^nyng of that enpryse
How he this best should kylle
And thus shortly for to tell
So as this maiden him had taught
Theseus with his monstre faught
And smote of his head ye which he nam
And by the thread so as he came
He gothe again til he were out
Than was great wonder al about
Mynos the tribute has rebeced
And so the werre was al seced
Bitwene Athenis and hem of Crete
But now to speak of that sweet
The whose beauty was without wane
This fair maiden Adryane
When she saw Theseus sound
Was never yet upon this ground
A gladder wight than she was tho
Theseus dwelled a day or two
With this maiden spak and rowned
That she to him was abandouned
In all that ever she couthe
So that of her lusty youth
Al pryuely between hem twey
The first flower he took awey
For he so fair her than behyght
That ever while he live might
He should her take for his wife
And as his own hertes life
He should her love and truth her bear
And she that might not forbere
So sore loves him again
That what as ever he would seyne
With all her heart she it leuyth
And thus his purpoos he acheuyth
So that assured of his truth
With him she went and that was routhe
Fedra her young suster eke
A lusty maiden sobre and meke
Fulfilled of al curtosye
For susterhode and company
Of love / the which was hem between
To see her suster be made a queen
Her fader left and forth she went
With him that al his first intent
Forgate within a litel throw
So that it was al overthrow
When that she wend that it should stand
The ship was blown fro the land
Wherein they lay sailend there
This Adryan had mochel fere
Of that the wyndo so loud blewe
As she that of the sea ne knew
And praid for to rest a while
And so fell that vpoon an isle
That this night they ben dreue
Where he to her leave has give
And she shall land and take her rest
But that was nothing for her best
For when she was to land brought
The which at yt time thought nout
But al truth and took no keep
Has laid her down to sleep
As she that long has been forwatched
But certes she was evil matched
And fer from all loves kind
For more than the best unkind
Theseus the which no truth kept
While that this young lady slept
Fulfilled of his vnkyndeship
Has forgeten al godeshyp
The which Adryan had him done
And he bad the shypmen soon
Hale up the sail and not abide
But forth he gothe the same tide
Toward Athenys and there on land
He left his lady in the stronde
Slepend til that she awoke
But when that she cast up hyf look
Toward the stronde and saw no wit
Her heart than was sore aflyght
That she ne wist what to think
But drowe her to the water bryncke
Where so she biheld the sea at large
She saw no ship / she saw no barge
As ferforth as she might kenne
O lord she said such a sin
As all the world shall after here
Upon this woeful woman here
This worthy knyt has done and wrote
I wend I had his love bought
And so deserved at need
When that he stood upon his dread
And also the love he me behyght
It is great wondre how he might
Toward me now be unkind
And so to let out of his mind
Thing that he said his own mouth
But after this when it is couthe
And drawn to the worlds fame
It shall be hynderyng for his name
For well he wot and so wot I
He gaf his troth bodyly
That he my honor should keep
And with that word she began weep
And sorowed more than enough
Her fair tresses she to drough
And with her self she took such a strif
And she bitwene the death and the life
Swounend lay full often among
And all was this on him long
The which was to love unkind so
Whereof the wrong shall euermo
Stand in Cronycle of remembrance
And also it asks a vengeance
To be unkind in loves cas
So as theseus than was
Al though he were a noble knight
For he the law of loves right
Forfeyted has for alwey
That Adryane he putt awey
The which was a greece unkind deed
And after that so as I read
Fedra the which her suster is
He took instead of her and this
Fell afterward to mekel tene
For that vice of which I mean
Vnkyndeship whore it falls
The truth of man's heart it palleth
That he can no good deed acquyte
So may he stand of no merit
Toward god and also
Men call him the worlds so
For he no more than the fend
Unto another man's friend
But al toward him self alone
For thy my sone in thy person
This vice above all other flee
My fader as ye teache me
I thynk to do in this matere
But over this I would fayn here
Whereof I shall me shryue more
My good son and for thy lore
After the reule of couetyse
I shall the propyrte deuyse
Of every vice by and by
Now harken and be well ware thervp

I (...) the lygnage of Audry^^
My sone yet there is a vice
His right name is Rauyne
The which has a route of his couyne
Rauyne among the maystres dwells
And with his servants as men tells
Extorcion is now witholde
Rauyne of other men's fold
Makes his lord and pays naught
For where as ever it may be sought
In his hows there shall no thing lack
And that full often abyeth the pack
Of pour men that dwellen about
Thus sto^deth the common people in doubt
The which can do none amendment
For when him fails payment
Rauyne makes none other skyle
But takes by strength what he will
So ben other in the same wise
Lovers as I shall deuyse
That when not else may avail
Anon with strength they assail
And get of love the sesyne
When they see the time by Rauyne
Of love / Certes fader no
For I my lady love so
For though I were as was Pompey
That all the world me would obey
Or else such as Alisandre
I would not do such a sclaundre
He is no good man that so does
In good feyth sone thou seyst sooth
For he that wol of purueannce
By such a weye his lust auaunce
He shall it after sore abye
But if these old examples lie
Now good fader tell me one
So as they conne many one
Touchend of love in this matere
Now lysten my sone / and thou shall here
So as it has befallen or this
In loves cause how that it is
A man to take the Rauyne
The pray the which is femenyne

aN Emperor by old days
There was / and he at al assayes
A worthy knyt was of his
hand / There was no such in all the lo^d
But yet for all his vassellage
He stood un wedded al his age
And in Cronycle as it is told
He was an honderd winter old
But when men would his deeds peyse
And his knyghthode of arms preyse
Of that he did with his hondes
When he the kings and the lands
To his subjection put under
Of all that price had he no Wonder
For he it set at none acounte
And seid ^ll that might not amounte
Ageyn one point that he has nomen
That his flesh he has ouercomen
He was a virgyn as he said
On that battle his prys he laid
Lo now my sone auyse the
Fader all this may well be
But and al other did so
The world of men were sone ag^
And in the law men may find
How god to man the law of kind
Has set the world to multyplye
And who that will him Iustyfye
It is not to do the law
And nevertheless your good saw
Is good to keep who so may
I wol not there again seye nay
My sone take it as I say
If maydenhede be taken away
Without laws ordinance
It may not fail of vengeauuce
And if thou wylt the sooth wyten
Behold a tale the which is written
How that the king of Agamenon
When he the Cite of L^sbon
Had wonuen / a maiden there he fond
That was the fairest of the land
In that time that men wist
And he had of her what him list
Whereof that she was dangerous
Of ye thing yt which was most precious
This fair maiden cleped is
Creseyde the daughter of Crysys
The which was that time special
Of that time bishop pryncipal
Where Phoebus had his sacryfyce
So was it well the more vice
Agamenon was than in way
To Troyward and took a way
This maiden that he with him ladde
And great lust in her he had
But Phoebus yt which had great disdeyne
For yt this maiden was forleyn
Anon as he to Troy came
Mengeaunce upon this deed name
And sent a comune pestylence
They sought than her euydence
And made calculacion
To know in what condicyon
This death came in suddenly
And at the last redyly
The cause and also the man they fond
And forth with all the same stounde
Agamenon opposed was
The which has knowleched all ye cas
Of the folly that he has wrought
And thereupon mercy they sought
Toward the god in diverse wise
With prayer and with sacryfyce
And the maiden home they send
And gafe her gold enough to spend
For ever whiles she would live
And thus the syn was forgive
And all the pestylence seced
Loo what it is to be encrecid
Of love which is ylle won
It were letter be vnbegonne
Than take a thing without leave
Which thou must after needs leave
And yet have maugre forth with all
For thy to robben ouerall
In loves cause if thou begin
I not what ease thou shall win
My fader so will I wys
My sone be well ware of this
But now your examplarye
In love is cause of Robberye
I have it right well understand
But over this how so it stand
Yet wol I wit of your apryse
What thing is more of Couetyse

With Couetyse if I find
A servant of the same kind
Which steleth is hot and myche
^ye. With him is ever in company
Of whom if I shall tell sooth
He stalketh as a Pecok does
And takes his pray so couerte
That no man wot it in aperte
And wot the lord at home
Than would he stalk about and come
And what thing he fynt in his way
When that he saw the men away
He steleth it and goth forth with all
That thereof no man know shall
And eke ^uf often he goth a night
Withouten moan or sterre light
And with his craft the door vnpykyth
And takes therein what him lyketh
And if the door be so shet
That he be of his enter let
He will at the wyndowe in crept
And while the lord is fast a sleep
He steleth what thing him best list
And goth his wey or it be wist
Full often also by light of day
Yet would he stele and make assay
Under the cete his hond he put
And with a knyf his purs he cut
And receives what he find therein
And thus he auntreth him to win
And bears an horn and not blows
For no man of his counceyll knows
That he may get of his mychyng
It is al bylle under the wyng
And as an hound goth to fold
And has there taken what he would
His mouth upon the gras he wypeth
And so with feyned chere him slyketh
And what as ever of sheep he strangle
There is no man thereof shall iangle
As for to know who it deed
Right so does stelthe in every stead
Where as him list his pray take
He can so well his cause make
And so well feyne / and so well gloss
That there ne shall no man suppose
But that he were an Innocent
And thus a man's eye he blent
So that this craft he may use
Without help of any refuse
There ben lovers of that degree
With all her lust in pryuete
As who sey geten al by stelthe
And there of atteynen to great welthe
And for the time that it lasts
For love awayteth ever and casts
How he may stele and catch his pray
When he thereto may find a way
For be it night or be it day
He takes his part when he may
And if he may no more do
Yet wol he stele a kiss or two
Tell if thou ever dydest so
In any wise thy lady unto
My fader how my sone thus
If thou have stolen any kus
Or other thing that thereto longs
For no man such thieves hongeth
Tell on for thy and sey the truth
My fader nay / and that is routhe
For by will I am a thief
But she that is to me most lef^
Yet durst I never in pryuete
Mot ones take byr by the kne
To stele of her or this or that
And if I durst I wot well what
And netheles but if I lie
By stelthe ne by robberye
Of love which fell in my thought
To her did I never naught
But as me^ seyn where heart is failed
There shall no castle be assailed
But though I had hertes ten
And were as strong as all men
If I be not mine own man
I dare not vsen that I can
I may my self not recouere
Though I be man never so pouere
I bear an heart / and it is
So that me fails wit in this
How that I should of mine acorde
The servant led against the lord
For if my foot would owhere go
Or that my hondes would else do^
When that my heart is there again
The remenaunt is all in vein
And thus me lacks al we will
And yet ne dare I not steel
Of thing which longs unto love
And eke it is so hie above
I may not well thereto areche
But so be at time of speech
Full seld if that I stele may
A word or two and go my way
Betwyxt her / his estate and me
Comparyson there may none be
So that I feel and well wot
Al is to heavy and to hot
To set on hond without love
And thus I mote algate leave
To stele that I may not take
And in this wise I mote forsake
To ^en a thief again my will
Of thing which I may not fulfylle
For that serpent which never slepte
The flees of gold so well ne kept
In Colchos as the tale is told
That my lady a thousand fold
Is better yemed and bewaked
Where she be clothed or be naked
To keep her body night and day
She has a wardey^ ^dy ay
Which is so wonderful a wight
That him no man's might
With sword ne wepen may daunte
Ne with no sleyghte of charm encha^t^
Whereof he might be made tame
And danger is his right name
Which under lock and under key
That no man may her stele awey
And all the tresoure vnderfonge
That unto love may be long
The lest lokyng of her eye
That mote be stole if he it seye
And who so grutcheth for so lyte
He would sone set a wit
On him that would stelle more
And that me greueth wonder sore
For this proverb is ever new
That strange lokes maken ^trewe
A^ that wolden stele and pyke
For so well can no man syke
By him nether by no other mean
To whom danger would ^eue or lene
Of that tresoure he has to keep
So though I would stalk or crepe
And wait on eve and eke on morrow
Of danger shall I no thing borowe
And stele I wot well may I nout
And thus I am right well bethought
While danger stondeth in his office
Of stelthe which he clepeth a vice
I shall be gylty neuermo
Therefore I would he were ago
So fet that I never of him hert^
How so afterward it ferd
For than I might afterward perca^
Of love make sum purchaas
By stelth or by sum other way
That now stont fro me fer away
But fader as ye told above
Who steleth goth a night for love
I may not well that point forsake
That oftymes I ne wake
On nyghtes when that other sleep
But how I pray you take keep
When I am looked in such a wise
That by night I may arise
At sum wyndowe loken out
And see the howsyng al about
So that I may the chamber know
In which my lady as I trow
Lies in her bed and slepeth soft
Than is my heart a thief full often
For there I stand to behold
The long nyghtes that been cold
And thynk on her that lies here
And than I wysshe that I were there
As wys as was Nectanabus
Or ^ls as was Protheus
That couthen both of nygromance
In what lykenes in what semblau^ce
Right as hem list hem self transform
For if I were of such a form
I say that I would flee
In to her chamber for to see
If any grace would fall
So that I might under the palle
Sum thing of love pyke or stele
And thus I think thoughts feel
And though thereof no thing be sooth
Yet case as for a time it does
But at the last when I find
That I am fall in to my mind
And sce that I have stond long
And have no profit vnderfonge
Than stalk I to my bed within
And there to think I begin
Of love when I shall by night
My will is good / but my might
Me lacks both and of my grace
For what so that my thought enbrace
Yet have I not the better ferde
My fader / ^oo now have ye herd
What I by stelthe of ^oue have do
And how my will has be thereto
If I be worthy to penance
I put it unto your ordinance
My sone for stelthe I the byhete
Though it be for a time sweet
At end it does but little good
As by ensample how that it stood
Whilome I may the tell now
I pray you fader tell me how
My sone of him which gothe by day
By wey of stelthe to assay
In loves cause and takes his pray
Ouyde said as I shall say
And in his methamor he told
A tale which is good to hold

tHe poet upon this matere
Of si^lth wrote in this manner
Venus which has ye law in hand
Of thing which may not be withsta^d^
As she with the tresour toward
Of love has within her ward
Phoebus to love has so constreyned
That he without rest is payned
With all his heart to coueite
A maid which was warded streyte
Within chamber and kept so cloos
That seldom was when she discloos
Goth with her mother for to play
Lenchoter so as men say
This maiden hight / and Orc^anus
Her fader was. and befelle thus
This daughter that was kept so dear
And had been before year to year
Under her mother discyplyne
A clean malden and a vyrgyne
Upon the whoos natyuyte
Of comelyhede and of beauty
Nature has set all that she may
That lyche unto the fresshe may
With either months of the year
Sourmounteth so without pere
Was of this maiden the feiture
Whereof phoebus out of mesure
Her loves on every side
A waits if so may betyde
That he thorugh any sleygthe might
Her lusty maydenhede unright
The which were al his worlds wealth
And thus lurkyng upon his stelthe

Till it befelle upon a day
That he thorugh out her chamber wall

But upon this I shall be wreke
So that these maidens after this
Mow take ensample what it is
To suffer her maydenhede to be stole
Where that she the death may thole
And bad with that / go make a pytte
Wherein he has his daughter set

So that she was al quyck be grave

Has wrout thoru his power above
That she sprung up out the molde

Which stonte governs of the son
And thus when love is evil won
Full often it comes to repentayle
My fader that is no marvel
When that the counceyll is be wreyed
And oftyme love has pleyed

What that he thinks weren hid
But in your tale as betydde
Venus disturbed all the caas
And eke also broad day it was

And does his things out of sight

When hercules with Eolen
Which was ye love of his courage /
To geder upon a pylgremage

It fell hem by the way so
That they upon a day the cave

tHe hyhe god with all good
Purueyeth has for man's fode
Of clothes of mete and drink
Bade Adam that he should swynke
To geten him his sustenaunce
And eke be set in ordinance
Upon law of Moses
That though a man be haueles
He shall not by theft stele
But now a days there be feel
That wol no labor undertake
But what they may by stelthe take
They hold it sykerlyche won
And thus the law is overcome
Which god has set / and namely
With hem that so vntrewe^y
The gods rob of holy church
The theft which they than wyrch^
By name is cleped sacrylege
Ayene whom I think allege
Of his condition to tell
Which rifeleth both book and belle
So forth with all the remenaunt
To gods hows appertynaunt
Where that he should ^ydd^ his bid
He does his theft in holy stead
And takes what he fynt therein
For when he sees that he may wyn
He wendeth for no cursidnesse
That he ne briketh the holiness
And does to god no reverence
For he has lose his conscience
That though the pressed therefore to corse
He seyth he fares not the worse
And for to speak it otherwise
That man that lasseth the fraunchyse
And takes of holy church his pray
I note what bedes he shall pray
When he from god the which has give all The propirte in special
Which unto Crist him self is due
Bynemeth / he may not well eschew
The pain coming afterward
For he has made his forward
With sacryl^ge for to dwell
Which has his heritage in hell
And if we read of the old law
I find write in thylke dawe
Of princes there were three
Comparable al in this degree
And one of hem was cleped thus
The proud king Antyochus
That other Nabuzardon hight
Which enforced with all his might
The temple for to destroy and waste
And so ^e did in all have
The third which was after shamed
Was Nabogo donoser named
And he Jerusalem put under
Of sacrylege and many a wonder
There in the holy Temple he wrought
Wiche Balthazar his heir abought
When mane techel Phares wryt
Was on the wall as thou myt wit
^o as the bible has declared
But for all that ^t is not spared
Yet now a day that men it pylle
And maken argument and skylle
To sacrylege as it belongs
For what man that thereafter longs
He takes no head what he does
And right so for to tell sooth
An loves cause if I shall trete
There ben of such small and great
If they no leyser find else
They will not leten for the belles
Ne though they see the priest at mass
That wol they leten ouerpasse
If that they fond her love there
They stand and tell in her ere
And ask of god none other grace
While that they ben in holy place
But or they go sum ananntage
There will they have and some pyllage
Of goodly words and of byheste
Or else they take at the lest
Out of her hond a ryng or glove
So nyhe the weder they will shoue
And as she said she shall not forgete
Now I this token of her can get
Thus halowe they the hye feste
Such theft may no church areste
For all is leful that hem lyketh
To whom that else it myslyketh
And eke right in the self kind
In great Cytees men may find
This lusty folk that make hem gay
And wait upon the holy day
In chirches and in mynstres eke
They gone the women for to seek
And where that such one gooth about
To sore the fairest of all the route
Where as they sytten al a rewe
There will he his body most show
His crooked keyned and thereon set
An ouche with a chapelet
Which late come out of the greues
Or else one of the grene leaves
And all for he should seem fresshe
And thus he looks on the flesh
Right as an hawk which has a sit
Upon the foul where he shall light
And as he were a fayrye
He she weth him to fore her ^ye
(...) holy place where they sytte
Al for to make her hertes flytte
His eye nowhere wol abide
But look and pry on every side
On here and her as him hest lyketh
And otherwhyle among he syketh
Thinks of hem that was for me
And so there thynken two or three
And yet he loves none at all
But where as ever his chance fall
And netheles to sey soothe
The cause why he so does
Is for to stele an heart or two
Ouce of the Church or that he go
And as I said it here above
It is a sacrylege of love
For well may be that he steleth away
That he never after yield may
Tell me for thy my sone anon
Have thou do sacrylege or none
As I have said in this manner
My fader as of this matere
I will you tell redyly
What I have do bnt truly
I may excuse mine intent
That I never to church went
In such manner as ye me shryue
For no man that is on live
The cause why I have it last
May be / for I unto that craft
Am no thing able for to stele
Though there were never so feel
Bnt yet will I not sey this
When I am there my lady is
In whom lies holy my quarelle
And she to church or to Chappelle
Goo to matens or to mass
That time I wait well and pass
To church I come and there I stand
And though I take a look in hond^
My contenannce is on the look
Bnt toward her is al my look
And if so fall that I pray
Unto my god and somewhat say
Of pater noster and of Creed
Al is for that I would speed
So that my bid in holy church
There might sum miracle wirche
My lady berte for to change
Which ever to me has be strange
So that all my devotion
And al mine contemplacion
With all my heart and my courage
Is only set on her image
And ever I wait upon the tide
If she look any thing a side
That I me may on her auyse
Anon I am with Couetyse
So smyt^ that me were leef
To be in holy church a thief
But not to stele a vestyment
For that is no thing my talent
But I would stele if that I might
A glad word or a goodly sight
And ever my service I profere
And namely when she goth offer
For her I led then if that I may
For somewhat would I stele away
When I beclyppe her on the wast
Yet at the last I stele a taste
And other while grant mercy
She seith* and so win I thereby
A lusty touch a good word eke
But all the remenannt to seek
Is fro my purpoos wonder far
So may I say as I said err
In holy church if that I wowe
My conscience yet would I allow
Be so that upon amendment
I might get assignement
Wherefore I speed in other place
Such sacrylege I hold a grace
And thus my fader sooth to sey
In church right as in the wey
If I might ought of love take
Such hansell have I not forsake
But finally I me confess
There is in me no holiness
While I her see in any stead
And yet for onght that ever I deed
No sacrylege of her I took
But as it were a word or look
Or else if that I herd frede
When I toward offryng her led
Take thereof what I take may
For else ^ere I naught away
For though I would ought ^ls have
At other things ben so save
And kept with such a pryuelege
That I may do no sacrylege
God wot my will netheles
Though I must needs keep pees
And in all gree sone mine let it pass
My will thereto is not the less
For I might otherwise awey
For thy my fader I you prey
Tell what thou thynkest thereupon
If I thereof have gylt or none
Thy will my sone is for to blame
The remenaunt is but a game
That I have the told as yet
But take this lere in to thy wit
That all thing has time and stead
The which serves for the bid
^^e Chamber is of another speech
But if thou wystest of the wreche
How sacrylege it has abought
T^ow sholdest use it right naught
And for thou shall the more amend
A tale on the I wol dispende
Hic in amoris causa super istius vi (...) articulo ponit exemplum Et narrat

tO al men as who says know
It is and in ye world thoru blow
How that of Troy lamedon
To Hercules and to Iasen
When toward Colchos out of gr^^^
By see seylyng upon a piece
Of land of Troy rest preyde
But he wrongfully conueyde
And for they found him so vyleyne
When they came in to greece again
With power that they get might
Toward Troy they have hem dyght
And they took such vengeance
Whereof stant yet in remembrance
For they destroyed king and all
And leften but the brent wall
The greeks of Troyes many slow
And prisoners they took ynowe
Among the which there was one
The kings daughter lamedone
Esyona the fair thing
Which unto the lamon the king
By Hercules and by the assent
Of all the hole parliament
Was at his will give and granted
And thus has great Troy dannted
And him to torn in such manner
But after this now shall thou here
The cause why the tale I tell
Upon the chances that bifelle
King lamedon which dyed thus
He had a sone one priamus
Which was not thylke time at home
But when he herd of this he come
And fond how the Cite was fall
Which he bygan upon the wall
And made there a Cite new
That they which other lands knew
Tho se^den that of lyme and stone
In all the world so fair was none
And on that one side of the town
The king let make ylyowne
That hye toure that strong place
Which was adrad of no manace
Of quarrel none nor of engyne
And though men would make a mine
No man's craft it might approach
For it was set upon a roche
The walls of the Town about
Hem stood of all the world no doubt
And after the proporcyon
Syx gates were there of the town
Of such inform / of such entayle
That hem to see was great meruayl^
The dyches were broad and deep
And few men it might keep
From all the world as seems tho
But if the gods weren foo
Great prees unto that Cite drowe
So that there was of people ynowe
Of burgeys that therein dwellen
There may no man's tongue tellen
How that Cite was rich of good
When all was made and all well stood
King Pry^mus tho him bethought
What they of greece whylome wrought
And what was of her swerd devoured
And how his suster dishououred
With thelamon awey was ladde
And he thynkyng he wex vnglad
And set anon a parliament
To which the lords were assent
In many a wise there was spoke
How that they myghten ben awroke
But at the last netheles
They seid al acord and pees
To setten either party in rest
It thought hem al for the best
With reasonable amendment
And thus was Anthenor forth sent
To ask Esyona again
And wit what they would seyne
So passes he the sea by barge
To greece for to sey his charge
The which he said redyly
Unto the lords by and by
But where he spak in greece about
He herd not but words stout
And namelyche of Thelamon
The maiden would he not for gone
He said for no manner thing
And bad him gone home to his king
For there gate he none amend
For ought he couthe do or send
This Anthenor ayene goth home
Unto his king / and when he come
He told in greece what that he herd
And how that thelamon answered
And how they were at her above
That they wol neither pees ne love
But every man shall done his best
But for men seyen that night has rest
The king bythought him all ye nyt
And erly when the day was light
He took his counceyll of this matere
And they acord in this manner
That he withouten any let
A certain time should set
A parliament to ben auysed
And in this wise it was anysed
Of parliament he set a day
And that was in the month of may
This priamus had in his sight
A wife and Hecuba she hight
By whom that time she and he
Sons five had and daughters three
Beside two and thyrty mo
And weren knights al tho
But not upon his wit bygete
But else where he might hem get:
Of which he had know
Such was the world that ylk throw
And so he was of children rich
And thereof was no man him lyche
Of parliament the day was come
There ben the lords al and some
Tho was prouounced and purposed
And all the cause hem was disclosed
How Anthenor in greece ferde
They sytten ay stylle and herd
And tho spak every man about
There was alleged many a doubt
And many a proud word spoke also
But for the most party as tho
They wysten not what was the best
Or for to werre or for to rest
But he that was without fere
Hector among the lords there
His tale told in such a wise
And said lords ye ben wise
Ye known this as well as I
Above al other most worthy
Stant now in great manhood
Of worthynes and of knyghthode
For who so will it well agrope
To hem bylongeth al Europe
Which is the third part even
Of all the world under the heaven
And we be but folk a few
So were it reason to eschew
The peril or we fall therein
Better is to leave than to bygyn
Thing which may not be acheued
He is not wise that find him grieved
And does so that his grieve be more
For who that looks all to fore
And will not see what is behind
He may full often his harms find
Wyck is to strif and have the worse
We have encheson for to corse
This wot I well / and for to hate
The greeks / but or we debate
With hem that been of such a might
It is full good that every wight
Be of him self right well bythought
But as for me thus sey I naught
For while that my life may stand
If that ye taken werre in hand
Fall it to the best or to the werst
I shall my seluen be the ferst
To grieve hem what ever I may
I stylle not ones say nay
To thing which yt your cou^ceil demeth
For unto me more well it quemeth
The werre certes than the pees
But this I say netheles
As me belongs for to say
Now shape ye the best way
When Hector had said his deuyse
Next after him tho spak paryse
Which was his brother and alyed
When him best thought thus he seid
Strong thing it is to suffer wrong
And suffer shame is more strong
But we have suffered both the two
And for all that yet have we do
What so we might to reform
This wrong and shame in better form
Sent Anthenor as ye well know
And they her great words blow
Upon her wrongful deeds eke
And who that wol not him self meke
To pees and list no reason take
Men seyn Reason will him forsake
For in the multitude of men
Is not the strength / for with ten
It has be seen in true quarele
Ayene an honderd haluendele
And has the better by gods grace
Thus has befalle in many place
And if it like unto you all
I will assay how so it bifalle
Our enemy if I may grieve
For I have caught a great believe
Upon a pleyne point I wol declare
This yonder day as I began fare
To hunte unto the great heart
Which was to fore my hounds sterte
And every man went on his side
Him to pursewe and I to ride
Bigan to chase / and sooth to say
Within a while out of my way
I rode / and nyst where I was
And slope me caught and on the grass
Beside a well I leyd me down
To sleep and in a vysyoun
To me the god Mercurye came
Goddesses three with him he name
Mynerue Venus and Juno
And in his hond an Appel tho
He held of gold with lettres write
And thus he did me to wit
How that they put hem upon me
That to the fairest of hem three
Of gold that Appel should I give
With each of hem I was shryue
And echone fair me behyght
But Venus said if that she might
That Appel of my gift get
She would it neuermore forgete
And said how that in greece land
She would bring in to my hand
Of all this earth the fairest
So that me thought it for the best
To her and yaf that appel tho
Thus hope I well if that I goo
But she for me will so ordeyne
That they matere for to pleyne
Shall have or that I come again
Now have ye herd that I would seyne
Say ye what stont in your auyse
And every man tho said his
And sundry causes they record
But at the last they acorde
That paris shall to greece wend
And thus the parliament took an end
Cassandre when she herd of this
The which to paris suster is
Anon she began to weep and wayle
And said alas what may us ayle
Fortune with her blind whele
Ne will not let us stand well
For this I dare well undertake
That if paris his wey take
As it is seid that he shall do
We ben ever than fordoo
This maiden Cassandre hight
In all the world as it bears sight
In books as men find write
Is that Sybell of whom ye wit
That al men yet clepen sage
When that she wist of this vyage
How Paris should to greece fare
No woman might werse fare
Ne sorrow more than she did
And right so in the same stead
Ferd Helenus which was her brother
Of prophecy / and such another
And al was hold but a iape
So that purpoos which was shape
Or were hem leef or were hem loathe
Was hold / and in to greece goth
This paris with his retenaunce
And as it fell upon his chance
Of greece he londeth in an isle
And him was told that same while
Of folk which he began to freyne
Tho was in that isle queen Eleyne
And eke of countrees there about
Of ladies many a lufty rowte
With mochel worthy people also
And why they comen thedertho
The cause stood in such a wise
For worship and for sacryfyse
That they to Venus would make
As they to fore had undertake
Some of good will and some of biheste
For than was her hyhe feste
Within a Temple which was there
When paris wist what they were
Anon he shope his ordinance
To gone te done his obeysaunce
To Venus on her holy day
And did upon his best array
With great richesse he him behongeth
As it to such a lord longs
He was not armed netheles
But as it were in land of pees
And thus he gothe out of ship
And takes with him his felauship
In such manner as I you say
Unto the temple he hold his way
Tydyng which gothe oueral
To great and small forth with all
Come to the queen's ere and told
How paris come and that he would
Do sacryfyce unto Venus
And when she herd tell thus
She thought how that ever it be
That she will him abide and see
Forth comes paris with glad vysage
In to the temple on pylgremage
Where unto Venus the goddess
He yeueth and offreth great richesse
And prays her that he pray would
On that other side he began behold
And see where this lady stood
And forth in his fresshe mode
Goth where she was and made her chere
As he well couthe in his manner
That of his worlds such plesaunce
She took that al her acquaintance
As ferforth as the heart lay
He stale or that he went away
So goth he forth and took his leave
And thought anon as it was eve
He would done his sacrylege
That many a man shall abyge
When he ayene to ship was come
To him he has his counceyll nome
And all devised the matere
In such a wise as thou shall here
Within night al pryuely
His men he warns by and by
That they be armed ready soon
For certain thing which was to done
And they anon be ready all
And each on other began call
And went hem out upon the stronde
And took her purpoos there on land
Of what thing they would do
Toward the temple / and forth there go
So fyl it that of devotion
Heleyn in contemplaaon
With many another worthy wight
Was in the temple and woke al night
To bid and pray to the image
Of venus as was than usage
So that paris right as him list
In to the temple or they wyste
Came with his men al suddenly
And al at ones set a skrye
On hem which in the temple were
Fr tho was much people there
Bnt of defense was no bote
So suffer they that suffer mote
Paris unto the queen went
And her in both his arms hent
With him and with his felauship
And forth they bear her in to ship
Up goth the sail / and forth they went
And such a wynd fortune hem sent
Till they the haven of Troy caught
Where out of ship / anon they straut
And gone hem forth toward the town
The which came with procession
Ayene Paris to seen his pray
And every man began to say
To paris and to his felauship
All that they couthen of worship
Was none so little man in Troy
That he ne made myrthe and joy
Of that Paris had wonnen Eleyn
But all that night is sorrow and peyn
To Helenus and to Cassandre
For they it token shame and sklaundre
And loss of all the common grace
That Paris out of holy place
By stelthe has take a man's wife
Whereof he shall lose his life
And many a worthy man thereto
And the Cite before do
Which never shall be made ayene
And so it fell right as they seyne
The sacrylege which he wrought
Was cause why the greeks sought
Unto the town. and it belay
And wolden never part away
Till what by sleyght and what by strength
They had it wonnen in bread and length
And brent and slain that was therein
Now so my sone such a syn
Is sacrylege in holy stead
Beware therefore / and bid thy bid
And do no thing in holy church
But that thou might by reason wyrche
And eke take heed of Achilles
When he unto his love chees
Polixena that was also
In holy temple of Appollo
Which was the cause that he dyede
And al his lust was leyd aside
And Troylus upon Creseyde
Also his first love leyde
In holy place and how he ferde
As who seyth all the world it herd
Forsake he was for Dyomede
Such was of lust his last mede
For thy my sone I would read
By this ensample as thou might read
Seche else where thou wylt thy grace
And ware the well in holy place
What thou to love do or speak
In aunter if it be so wreke
As ^^ou have herd me tell to fore
And take good head also therefore
Upon what form of Anaryce
More than of any other vice
I have divided in parties
The branches which of companyes
Through out the world in general
Like as ye now here shall
Of Couetyse and periurye
Of falls brocage and of vsurye
Of scarcenes and vnkyndeship
Which never drough to felouship
Of Robbery and of pryue stelthe
Which done is for the worlds wealth
Of Rauyn and of sacrylege
Which take the conscience of a grege
Al though it may richesse atteyne
It floureth / bnt it shall not greyne
Unto the sweet of rightwysenesse
But who that would do largess
Upon the reule as it is give
So might a man with thought leave
Toward his god / and eke also
Toward the world / for by the two
Largess a wayteth as belongs
To neither part that he wrongeth
He keeps him self and keeps his friends
So stonte he sauf to both his ends
In such wise that he be sure
That he excedeth no mesure
Whereof my sone thou shall wit
So as Philosophre has write
