^E(...)ix the two extremytres
Of vice stont the propyrtees
Of v^rtu and to pr^ue it so
Take auaryce and take also
The vice of prodegalyte
Betwix hem lyberalyte
Which is the virtue of largess
Stant and governs his noblesse
For tho two vices in discord
Stant ever as I find of record
So that bitwene debate
Largess rules his estate
For in such wise as Auaryce
As I to fore have told the vice
Thorugh streyte holdyng and scarsenesse
Stant in contrary to largess
Right so prodegalyte
Reuers but not in such degree
For so as Auaryce spares
And for to keep his tresoure cares
That other al his own and more
Ayene the wysemans lore
Yeueth and dispendeth here and there
So that him retcheth never where
While he may borugh he wol dispende
Til at the last he seith I wend
But that is spoken al to late
For than is pouerte at the yate
And takes him even by the sleue
For ^rst will he no wysedom leave
And right as auaryce is sin
That would his tresoure keep and win
Right so yonre prodegalyte
But of largess in his degree
Which even stant bitwene the two
The high god and the man also
The virtue each of hem commends
For he him seluen first amendeth
That over al his name spredeth
And to al other where it needs
He yaf his good in such a wise
That he makes many a man rise
Which else should fall low
Largess may not be unknow
For what land he regneth in
It may not ^ayle for to win
Of his deserte love and grace
Where it shall fail in other place
And thus bitwene to much and lyte
Larges^e which is not to wit
Holds ever forth the myddel way
But who that wol torn a way
Fro that to prodegalyte
Anon he leueth the propyrte
Of virtue / and goth to the vice
For in such wise as Auaryce
Left for scarsenes his good name
R^g^t so that other is to blame
Which ^^^rgh his wast mesure excedeth
For no man wot what harm it bedeth
But mochel joy there leueth
Where that largeness an heart gydeth
For ^^o m^sur^ is so governed
^^^t he to be the par^y^s is learned
To god and to the world also
He does Reason to both the two
The pour folk of his alms
Releued ben in distress
Of thurst / of honger and of cold
The yeft of him was never sold
But freely give and netheles
The mighty god of his encrces
Reward him of double grace
The ^^uen ^e does him to purchase
And yeueth him eke ye worldis good
And thus the cete for the hoode
^orgesse takes / and yet no sin
^^ ^^th bow so that ever he win
What man has horse men give horse
And who none has / of him no for^
For he may than on foot goo
The world has ever stond so
But for to loken of the twey
A man to go the syker wey
Better is to give than to take
With yeft a man may friends make
But who yt takes outher great or small
He takes a charge forth with all
And stant not fre till it be quyte
So for to deem in man's wit
It helps more a man to have
His own good for to crave
Of other men / and make him bond
Where else he may stand vnbonde
Seneca / Si res tue tibi non sufficient fac vt rebus tuis sufficias

Seneca counceyled in this wise
And seyth but if thy good suffyce
Unto the lykyng of thy will
Withdraw thy lust and hold the stylle
And be to thy good suffysaunt
For that thing is appertynaunt
To truth and causes to be fre
After the rule of charity
Which first begins of him self
For thou richest other twelf
Whereof thou shall thy self be pouer
I not what thonk thou might recoue^
While that a man has good to ye^e
With great rentes he may leave
And has his friends oneral
And eueryche of hem tell shall
The which he has his full pak
They say a good felawe is Jack
And when it foyleth at the last
Anon his price they ouercast
For than is there none other law
But Iak was a good felawe
When they him pour and nedy se^
They let him pass and fare well he
All that he wend of company
Is than turned to folly
But now to speak in other kind
Of love a man may such find
That where they come in every row^^
They cast and wast her love about
Till all her time is ouergone
And than have they love none
For who that loves oueral
It is no reason that he shall
Of love have any propyr^e
For thy my sone auyse the
If thou of love have ben to large
For such a man is not to charge
And if so be that thou have
Dyspended al thy time in wast
And set thy love in sundry place
Though thou the substance of thy grace
Lose at the last it is no wonder
For he that put him seluen under
As who says common over all
He leseth the love specialle
Of any one if she be wise
For love shall not bear the pryse
By reason when it passes one
So have I seen many one
That were of love well at ese
Which after fell in great dysese
Thorugh wast of love that they spent
In sundry places where they went
Right so my sone I ask of the
If thou with prodegalyte
Have here or there thy love wasted
My fader nay / but I have tasted
In many a place where I have goo
And yet love I never one of tho
But for to drive forth the day
For leueth well my heart is ay
Withouten mo for evermore
All upon one for I no more
Desire but her love allone
So make I many a pryue moan
For well I feel I have dispended
My long love and not amended
My speed for ought I find yet
If this be wast to your wit
Of love and prodegalyte
Now good fader demeth ye
But of one thing I will me shr^^^
That I shall for no love thryue
But if her self will me releue
My sone that may well I leave
And netheles me seems so
For ought that thou bast yet mysdo
Of time which thou have myspendyd
It may with grace be amendyd
For thing which may be worth the co^^
Per chance is newther wast ne lo^^
^^^ what thing stont in adventure
That can no worlds creature
Tell in certain how it shall end
Till he there of may see an end
So that I note as yet therefore
If thou my son have won or lore
For oftyme as it is seen
When somer has lost al his grene
And is with winter wast and bare
That him is left no thing to spare
Al is recouerd in a throw
The cold winter is over blow
And still ben the sharp showers
And suddenly against his flowers
The somer happens and is rich
And so per caas thy grace lyche
My sone though thou be now pouer
Of love yet thou might recover
My fader certes grant mercy
Ye have me taught so redyly
That ever while I live shall
The better I may beware with all
Of thing which ye have said or this
But evermore how that it is
Toward my shryft as it belongs
To wit of other points me longs
Whereof that ye me wolden teache
With all my heart I you byseche

tHe great sin orygenal / Which every man in gouernal / Upon his birth has

When Adam of thylk Appel bote
His sweet morcelle was so hot
Which dedely made the kind
In the books as I find
This vice which so out of rule
Has set us al is cleped gule
Of the which the branches ben so great
That of hem all I wol not irete
But only as touching to two
I think to speak of no mo
Whereof the first is dronkeship
Which bears the cup felauship
Full many a wonder does that vice
He can of a wyseman make a nyce
And of a fool that him shall seem
That he can all the law deem
And give every Judgment
Which longs to the fyrmament
Both of the sterre^ and of the moon
And* thus^ makes a great clerk soon
Of him that is a lewd man
There is no thing that he ne can
While he has dronkeship on hand
He knows the sea / he knows ye lord
He is a noble man of arms
And yet no strength is in his arms
There he was strong ynowe to fore
With dronkeship it is forlore
And al is changed his estate
And wexeth anon so feeble and ma^e
That he may nether go ne come
But al to geder he is benome
The power both of hand and foot
So that algate abide he mote
And al his wits be foryete
The which is to him such a let
That he note never what he does
Ne which is false / ne which is sooth
Ne which is day ne which is night
And for ye time he knows no wit
That he ne wot so much as this
What manner thing him seluen is
Or he be man or he be best
That hold I right a sorry fest
When he that Reason understood
So sodenlyche he is wexe wood
Or else lyche the deed man
Which another go ne speak can
Thus often he is to bed brought
And where he lies he reteheth naught
Till he arise upon the mow we
And than he seith / O which a sorrow
It is a man to be drynkeles
So that half drunk in such a rees
With dry mouth he stert him up
He says bail sa the cup
That made him lose his wit again
Is than a morrow al be leyne
The cup is all that ever him pleseth
And also that most him dyseseth
It is the cup whom he serves
Which al care from him herueth
And al balys to him brings
In joy wepeth / in soro we he syngeth
It may no while stont in verse
For dronkenshyp is so diverse
He drynketh the wyn / but at the last
The wyn drynketh him and bynt him
Fast / And leyth him dronke by ye wall
As him which is his bond thrall^
And al in his subjection
And lyche to such condycyon
As for to speak it otherwise
It falls that the most wise
B^n other while of love adoted
And so bywhapped and assoted
O^ dronken men / and never yet
Was none which half so lost his wytt
Of drink as they of such things do
Which cleped the ^olyf woe
And wexen of her own thought
So dr^nk that they ne knew naught
What reason is more or less
Such is the kind of that sykenesse
And that is not for lack of brain
But love is so great a main
That where he takes a heart on hand
There may no thing his myt withsto^d
With which Salamon was nome
And strong Sampson overcome
The knyghtly Dauyd him ne might
Rescue that he with the sight
Of Bersabe ne was bestad
^yrgyly also was ouerlad
And Aristotiles was put under
For thy my sone it is no wonder
If thou he drunk of love among
Which is above al other strong
And if so is that thou so be
Tell me thy shryft in prynyte
It is no shame of such a thewe
A young man to be dronkelewe
Of such Phisyk as I can a part
And as me seems in that art
Thou sholdest by phisonomye
Be shapen to that melodye
Of louedronke / and that is routhe
A holy fader that is truth
That ye me tell I am beknowe
That I with love am so bythrowe
And al my heart is so thorugh sonkr
That I am verylyche drunk
And yet I may both speak and goo
But I overcome so
And turned fro my self so clean
That often I wot not what I mean
So that excusen I ne may
My heart fro the first day
That I am to my lady hythe
I was never yet sobre sithe
Where I her see or see her not
With musyng of my thought
Of love which my heart assayleth
So dronk that my heart fails
And all my brain is ouertorned
And my manner so my^torned
That I foryete all that I can
And stand like a mased man
That often when I would play
It makes me draw out of the way
In soleyn place by my self
As does a laborer to delf
Which can no gentylmans chere
Or else as a lewd friar
When he is put to his penance
Right so lose I my contenaunce
And if it needs so vetyde
That I in company abide
Where as I must dance and sing
The houe dance and carolynge
Or for to goo the new foot
I may not well heue up my foot
If that she be not in the way
For than is al myrthe away
And weye anon of thought so full
Whereof my lymmes ben so dull
I may uneaths goo a pas
For thns it is / and ever hit was
When I on such thoughts muse
The lust and mirth that men use
When I see not my lady byme
Al is foryete for the time
So ferforth that my wits chaungen
And al lusts fro me straungen
That they seyn al truly
And swore that I am not I
For as the man which often drynketh
The wyn that in his stomach synketh
Wexeth drunk and wytles for a throw
Right so my lust is overthrow
And of mine own thought so mate
I wexe / that to mine estate
There is no lyme will me ser^e
But as a dronk man I swerue
And suffer such a passion
That men have great compassyon
And eueriche by him self merueyleth
What thing it is what one eyleth
Such is the manner of my woe
Which time that I am hurt so
T^l efte again that I her see
But than it were a nycete
To tell you how that I fare
For when I may upon her stare
Her woman he de her gentylnesse
My heart is full of such gladness
That ouerpasseth so my wit
That I wot nowhere where it sit
But am so dronken of that sight
Me thinks that for the time I myt
Right streyte thorugh the hole wall
And than I may well if I shall
Both sing and dance and lepe about
And hold forth the lusty rowte
But netheles it falls so
Full often that I fro her gos
Ne may but as it were a stake
I stand auysement to take
And look upon her fair face
That for the while out of the place
For all the world ne might I wen^e
Such lust comes than to my mind
So that without mete and drink
Of lusts thoughts which I think
Me thinks I might stand ever
And so it were to me lever
Than such a sight for to leave
For well is me that I have leave
To have so mochel of my will
And thus thynkyng I stond stylle
Without blemysshyng of mine eye
Right as me thought that I sye
Of paradys the most joy
And so there while I me reioy^
In to my heart a great desire
The which is hoter than the fire
Al sodenlyche upon me renneth
That all my thought within brenneth
And am so ferforth overcome
That I note where I am bycome
So that among the hertes strong
Instead of drink I vnderfonge
A thought so sweet in my courage
That never pyement ne vernage
Was half so sweet for to daynke
For as I would than I think
As though I were at mine above
For so thorugh drunk I am of love
That all that my soty demeth
Is soothe as than it to me seems
And while I may the thoughtrs keep
Me thinks as though I were a sleep
And that I were in gods barme
But when I see mine own harm
And that I sodenlyche awake
Out of my thought and head take
How that the sooth stant in deed
Than is my sykernes in dread
And joy torneth in to woo
So that the hete is al ago
Of such soty as I was ynne
And than Inward I begin
To take of love a new thurst
Which me greueth all there worst
For than comes the blanch Fever
With chele and make me to cheuer
And so it coldeth at my heart
That wonder is how I asterte
In such a point that I ne deye
For certes there was never keye
Ne frosen is upon the wall
More Inly cold than I am all
And thus I suffer the hot chele
Which passes other points feel
In Cold I brenne and feese in hete
And than I drynk a bitter sweet
With dry lyppe and eyes wete
Loo thus I tempre my dyete
And take a draught of such relees
That al my wit is herteles
And al my heart therein sit
Is as who says without wit
So that I preue it by reason
In making of comparyson
There may no difference be
Bytwyx a drunk man and me
But all the werst of euerychone
Is ever that I thurst in one
The more that my heart drynketh
The more I may so me thinks
My thurst shall never be acqueynte
God sheld that I be not dreynte
Of such a superfluyte
For well I feel in my degree
That al my wit is ouercast
Whereof I am the more aghast
That in defante of ladyship
Per chance in such a dronkeship
I may be cede or I beware
For certes fader this I dare
Beknowe and in my thyrst tell
But I a draught have of a well
In which my death is and my life
My joy is turned in to staf
That sobre shall I never worth
But as a dronken man for worth
So that in land where I fare
The lust is lore of my welfare
As he that may no bote find
But this me thinks a wonder kind
As I am dronk of that I drynk
Of these thoughts that I think
Of which I find no relees
But if I might netheles
Of such a drink as I coueyte
So as me lust have one receyte
I should assobre and fare well
But so fortune upon her whele
On he me deyneth not to set
For evermore I find a let
The botyler is not my friend
Which has the key by the bend
I may wysshe and that I waste
For well I wot so fresshe a taste
But if my grace be the more
I shall assay neuermore
Thus am I drunk of that I see
Forcastyng is forfendyd me
And I can not my seluen staunche
So that my fader of this branch
I am gytlyf to tell truth
My sone that me thinks routhe
For love drunk is the meschyef
Above all other the most chyef
If he no lusty thought assay
Which may his sorry thurst alay
As for the time that it lesseth
To him which other joy mysseth
For thy my sone above all
Think well how so it befalle
And keep the wits that thou have
And late hem not be drunk in wast
But netheles there is no wight
That may withstonde loves might
But why the cause is as I find
But that there is diverse kind
Of love drunk why men pleyneth
After the Country which al ordeyneth
I will the tell the manner
Now list my sone / and thou shall here

And right so changed his estat^
He that of love is delycate
For though he had to his hand
The best wife of all the land
Or the fairest love of all
Yet would his heart on other fall
And thynk hem more delycious
Than he has in his own hou^
Men seyn it is now often so

Of sight is al my first food

Her body round / her myddel small
So well bigone with good array
Which passes all the lust of may
When he is most with soft showers
Full clothed in lusty flowers
With such sightes by and by
Mine eye is fed fnll finally
When he the port and the manner
Sees of her womanlyche chere
Than has he such delight on hand
He thinks he might stylle stand
And that he has full suffysaunce
Of lyue^^de and of sustenaunce
And to his part euermo
And if it thought all other so
Fro then would he never wend
But there unto the worlds end
He would abide if that he might
And feden him upon the sight
For though I might stand ay
In to the time of domes day
And look upon her ever in one
Yet when I should fro her gone
Mine eye would as though he fast
Ben honger storuen also fast
Til efte ayene that he her sye
Such is nature of mine eye
There is no lust so deyntefull
Of which a man should not be full
Of that the stomak vnderfongeth
But ever in one mine eye longs
For look how that a goushauk tyreth
Right so does he when he pyreth
And tutyth on her womanhede
For he may never fully feed
His lust but ever y lyche sore
Him hongreth so that he the more
Desires to be fed algate
And thus my eye is made the gate
Thugh which ye deyntees of my thou^
Of lust ben to mine heart brought
Right as my eye with his look
Is to mine heart a lusty Cook
O^ loves feed delycate
Right so my ere is in his estate
Where as my eye may not serve
Can well mine eres thonk deserve
And feden him fro day to day
With such fode as he may
For thus it is that oueral
Where that I come in special
I may here of my lady price
I here one sey that she is wise
Another seith that she is good
And sum men seyn / of worthy blood
That she is one / and is also
So fair that there is none so
And some preise her goodly chere
Thus every thing that I may here
Which sowneth to my lady good
Is to my heart a lusty food
And eke my ere has over this
A deynte feste when so is
That I may here her selum speak
For than anon my fast I break
On such words as she seyth
That full of truth and full of feith
They ben and of so good disporte
That to my ere great comfort
They done as they that been delices
For all the metes and all the spyce^
That any Lumbard couthe make
Ne be so lusty for to take
Ne so ferforth restauratif
I seye as for mine own lif
As ben the words of her mouth
For as the wyndowes of the southe
Ben most debonaire of all debonair^
So when her lust to speak fair
The virtue of her goodly speech
Is verily my hertes leche
And if it so bifalle among
That she carole upon a song
When I it here I am so fed
That I am fro my life so led
As though I were in paradys
For certes as to mine auys
When I here of her vois the steu^
Me thinks it is a bliss of heu^
And eke m other vois also
Full oftyme it falls so
Mine ere with a good petaunce
Is fed of redyng and of romaunce
Of Ydome and of Amadas
That whilome were in my cas
And eke of other many a store
That loueden long or I was bode
For when I of her loves read
Mine ere with the tale I fed
And with the lust of her storye
Sometime I drew it to memory
How sorrow may not ever last
And so comes hope in at the last
When I none other food know
And that endures but a throw
Right as it were a chery feste
But for to counten at the lest
As for the while yet it eseth
And somdele of my heart appeseth
For what thing to my ere spredeth
Which is plesaunt somdele it eseth
With words such as she may get
My lust instead of other mete
Loo thus my fader as I sey
Of lust the which my eye has sey
And eke of that my ere has herd
Full often I have the better ferd
And the two bryngen in the third
The which has in my heart amydde
His place take to array
The lusty food which assay
I mete and namelyche on nyghtes
When that me lacks al sightes
And that my heryng is awey
Then is he ready in the wey
My rere souper for to make
Of which my hertes fode I take
This lusty Cooks name is hoote
Thought which has ever his pottes
hot / Of love boylyng on the fire
With fantasye and with desire
Of which full often or this she fed
My heart when I was a bed
And than he set upon my lord
Both every sight and every word
Of lust which I have herd or seyn
But yet is not my fest all pleyn
But all of words and of fisshes
Thereof I have my full disshes
But as of felyng and of taste
Yet might I never have one repaste
And thus as ye have herd to forn
I lycke honey on the thorn
And as who seith upon the brydell
I chewe so that all is ydell
As in effect the fode I have
But as a man that would him save
When he is syke by medicine
Right so of love the famyn
I fond m all that ever I may
To feed and drink forth the day
Til I may have the gretter feste
Which al my honger might areste
Loo such ben my lusts three
Of that I think and here and see
I take of love my fedyng
Without tastyng or felyng
As the pour does of the heir
I live and am in good espyer^
That for none such delycacye
I trow I do no glotenye
And netheles to your auys
My holy father that been wys
I recommaunde mine estate
Of that I have been delycate
My sone I understand well
That thou have told I here euerydele
And as me thinks by thy tale
It ben delytes wonder small
Whereof thou take thy loves food
But sone if that thou understood
What is to ben delycious
Thou would not be curyous
Upon the lust of thyn estate
To ben to fore delycate
Whereof that thou reason excede
For in the books thou might read
If man's wisdom shall be showed
It ought well to ben eschewed
In love as well as other wey
For as these holy books sey
The bodily delyces all
In every point how so they fall
Unto the soul done greuaunce
And for to take in remembreunce
A tale acordaunt unto this
wiche of great understanding is
In man's soul reasonable
I think to tell / and is no fable

oF Cristes word who will it read
How yt this vice is for to dread
In the euangely it tells pleyne
wiche must algate be certain
For crist him self bears witness
And though the clerk and the clergesse
In latin tongue it read and sing
Yet for the more knowlechyng
Of truth which is good to wit
I shall declare as I it wr^te
In Englys^he / for thus it bigan
Crist seith there was a rich man
A mighty lord of great estate
And he was eke so delycate
Of his clothyng that every day
Of purpir / and bice he made him gay
And ete and drank to his fylle
After the lusts of his will
As he which stood al in delyce
And took no head of thylk vice
And as it should so betyde
A pour Laar upon a tide
Came to the gate and axeth mete
But there might he no thing get
His dedely honger for to staunche
But he which had his full paunche
Of all lusts at the board
Ne deyneth not to speak a word
Onlyche a Cromme for to give
Whereof the peure might leave
Upon the yeft of his alms
Thus lay this pour in great distress
Ac^lde and hongred at the gate
For which he might goo no gate
So was he woeful besene
That there as he lay on the grene
The hounds comen fro the halle
Where that this sike man was fall
And as he lay there for to dye
The wounds of his maladye
They lyeken for to done him ese
But he was full of such dysese
That he may not the death escape
But as it was that time shape
The so wle fro the body passes
And he whom no thing ouerpasseth
The high god up to the heaven
Him took where he has set him even
In Abraham's barme on high
Where he the heuens ioyr sighe
And had all that he have would
And fell as it befalle should
This rich man this same throw
With sodeyne death was ouerblowe
And forth withouten any went
In to hell straight he went
The fend in to the fire him drough
Where that he had pain enough
Of flamme which that ever brenneth
And as his eye about renneth
Toward the heaven he cast his look
Where that he saw and head took
How Laar set was in his see
As far as ever he might see
With Abraham / and than he prayde
Unto the patriarch and said
Send Laar down fro thylk sete
And do that he his finger wete
In water / so that he may drop
Upon my tongue for to stop
The great hete in which I hrenne
But Abraham auswerd then
And seid to him in this wise
My sone thou the might auyse
And take in thy remembrance
How Lalar had great penance
Whiles he was in that other life
But thou in all thy lusty iolyf
The bodily delytes soughtest
For thy so as thou than wroughtest
Now shall thou take to thy reward
Of dedely pain herafter ward
In hell which shall ener last
And this Laar now at the last
The worlds pain is over ronn^
In heaven he has his life begone
Of joy which is endeles
But that thou praydest nevertheless
That I shall Laar to the send
With water on his fyngers end
Thine hot tongue for to kele
Thou shall not such graces feel
For in that folble place of sin
For ever in which thou shall ben Inn
Comes none out of this place thidder
Ne none of you may come hydder
Thus be ye parted now a two
The rich ayeneward cried tho
O Abraham since hit so is
That laar may not do me this
Which I have axed in this place
I would pray another grace
For I have yet of brethren five
That with my fader ben alive
To geder dwellen in one hows
To whom as thou art gracious
I pray that thou would send
Laar so that he might wend

That afterward they be not shent
Of such peynes as I dry
Loo this I pray / and this I cry
That they may hem self amend
The patriarch anon send
Of his prayer answer nay
And said him how that every day
His brethren might know and here
Of moses in earth here
And of prophets other mo
What hem was best and he said no
But if there might a man arise
From death to life in such a wise
To tellen hem how that it were
He said then of pure fere
They sholden than beware thereby
Quod Abraham / nay sikerly
For if they now will not obey
To such as teache hem the wey
And al day preche and al day tell
How that it stont of heaven and hell
They will not than taken head
Though it befelle so in deed
That any deed man so arered
To ben of him no better lered
Than of another man on live
If thou my sone can descryue
This tale as Christ him self told
Thou shall have cause to be hold
To see so great an euydence
There of the sooth experyence
Has showed openlyche at the eye
That bodily delycacye
Of him which yeueth no alms
Shall after fall in great distress
And that was seen upon the rich
For he ne would unto his lyche
A cro^me yeuen of his bread
Than afterward when he was deed
A drop of water him was werned
Thus may a man's wit be learned
Of hem that so delytes taken
When they with death ben overtaken
That erst was sweet is than sour
But he that is gouernoure
Of worlds good if he be wise
Within his herb he set no price
Of all the world / and yet he uses
The good that he nothing refuses
As he which lord is of the things
The ouches and the rich things
The clothe of gold and the perrye
He takes.and yet the delycacye
He leueth though he were all this
The best mete that there is
He eteth and drynketh the best drink
And takes none head to think
Delycacye to put away
As he which goth the right way
Not only for to feed and clothe
His body / but his soul both
But they that taken otherwise
Her lusts ben none of the wise
And that whylome was showed eke
If thou these old books seek
As well by reason as by kind
Of old ensamples as men find

tHat man yt would him well auise
Delycacye is to despise
When kind acordeth not with all
Whereof ensample in special
Of new whylome may be told
Which ayens kind many fold
His lusts took till at the last
That god him would all ouercast
Of whom the Cronyke is so pleyne
Me lust no more of him to seyne
And netheles for glotonye
Of bodily delycacye
To know his stomak how it ferd
Of that no man to fore herd
Which he within him self bethought
A wonder subtyle thing be wrought
Three men upon election
Of age and of complexion
Lyche to him self by all way
He took to wards him to play
And ete and drank as well as he
Thereof was no dyersyte
For every day when that they ete
Tofore his o^ne board they sete
And of such mete as he was served
Al though they had it not deserved
They token service of the same
But afterward at thylk game
Was in to woeful ernest turned
For when they were thus soiourned
Within a time at after mete
Nero which had not foryete
The lusts of his freel estate
As he which al was delycate
To know thylke experyence
The men let come in his presence
And to that one the same tide
A Courser that he should ride
In to the field anon he bad
Whereof this man was wonder glad
And goth to pryke and dance about
That other while that he was out
He leyd upon his bed to sleep
The third which he would keep
Within his chamber fair and soft
He gothe now up now down full often
Walkyng a pace that he ne slepte
Till he which on the Courser lepte
Was comen fro the field again
New than as books seyne
These men did done take al three
And slew hem for he would see
Whoos stomach was best defied
And when he has the sooth tried
He found that he which goth the pas
Defied best of al was
Which afterward he used ay
And thus what thing unto his pay
Was most plesaunt he left none
With any lust he was bygone
Whereof body might glade
For he no abstynence made
But most of al erthely things
Of women unto the lykynges
Nero set al his hole heart
For lust should him not asterte
When he the thurst of love him caught
Where that him lust to take a draught
He spares neither wife ne maid
That such another as men said
In all this world was never yet
He was so drunk in all his wit
Thorugh sundry lusts which he took
That ever while there is a book
Of New men shall read and sing
Unto the worlds knowlechyng
My good sone as thou have herd
For ever yet it has so ferd
Delycacye in loves cas
Without reason it is and was
For where that love his heart set
Him thinks / it might be no bet
And though it be not fully mete
The lust of love is eure svete
Loo thus to geder of felauship
Delycacye and dronkeship
Whereof reason stant out of herre
Have made full many a man to err
In loves cause most of all
For than how so that ever it fall
Wit can no reason understand
But late the gouernannce stand
To will which than wexeth so wild
That he can not him self shyld
Fro the peril but out of fere
The way he secheth here and there
Him retcheth not upon what fyde
For oftyme he goth beside
And does such thing without dread
Whereof him ought well to dread
But when that love assoted sore
It passes all men's lore
What lust it is that he ordeyneth
There as no man's might restreyneth
And of god takes he none head
But laws without dread
His purpoos for he wol acheue
Against the points of believe
He tempts heaven and earth and hell
Here afterward as I shall tell

WHo dare do thing which love ne dare /
To love is every law unware /
But to the laws of his best
The fisshe. the foul / the man / the beast
Of all the worlds kind loutith
For love is he which no thing douteth*
In man's heart where he sytte
He comes not toward his wit
The woo no more than the well
No more the hete than the chele
No more the wete than the dry
No more to live than to dye
So that to fore ne behind
He sees no thing but as the blind
Without insight of his courage
He does mecuayles in his rage
To what thing that he will him draw
There is no god there is no law
Of whom that he takes heed
But as baiard the blind stead
Tille he fall in the dyche a mydde
He goth there no man will him bydde
He stant so ferforth out of rewle
There is no wit that may him reule
And thus to tell him the sooth
Full many a thing he does
That were better to be laft
Among the which is such craft
That sum men clepen sorcerye
Which is for to wynue his drewry
With many a circumstaunce he uses
There is no point which he refuses
The craft which Saturnus found
To make prykes in the sound
That Geamaunce cleped is
Full often he uses amys
And of the flood his Idromaunce
And of the fire the romaunce
With questions echone of tho
He tempts often. and eke also
Acremaunce in Judgment
To love he brings of his assent
For these crafts as I find
A man may do by wey of kind
Be so / it be to good intent
But he goth al another went
For rather than he should fail
With nygromancye he would assail
To make his incantacion
With hot subfumygacion
Thilk art which spatula is bote
And used is of common rote
Among paine^s which that craft eke
Of which his auctor Those the greek
He wercheth one and one by row
Rachell is not to him unknow
Ne Salamon Candarye
His Ideote his entonye
The figure and the how with all
Of balachame and of Genball
The selle and thereupon chymage
Of the byth for his advantage
He takes. and somewhat of Gy^ere
Which helpend is to the matere
Babilla with her sons seven
Which heth renounced to the heaven
With ceornes both square and round
He grateth efte upon the ground
Making his inuocacion
And for full informacion
The s^ole which hono^us
Wr^te / he pursues / and loo thus
Magyke he uses for to win ne
His love and spares for no sin
And over that of his soty
Right as he sees sorcerye
Of hem that been magycyens
Right so of the naturyens
Upon the sterres from above
His wey he secheth unto love
As far as he hem understands
In many a sundry wise he fondeth
He makes image he makes seulpture
He makes writing / he makes figure
He makes his cala^lacions
He makes his demonstracions
His hours of Astronomye
He keeps as for that party
Which longs to the inspectyon
Of love and his affection
He would now in hell seche
The devil him self for to byseche
If that he wist for to speed
To get of love his lusty mede
Whereof that he has his heart set
He led never to fare bet
Ne wit of other heaven more

Have ben or thie I read the leave

Which t^uchith unto this matere

That I nold in my lusty youth
Binethe in hell and eke above

A tale which is good to know
To the my sone I shall beknowe

Vlixes at the syege there
Was one by name in special
Of whom yet the memoryall
Abides / for while there is a mouth
For ever his name shall be couthe
He was a worthy knight and king
And clerk knowing of every thing
He was a great rethoryen
He was a great magycyen

Vlixes knew this token naught
And praid to wit in sum party^
What thing it might ^ygnyfye
A sign it is which answered
Of an empire / and forth it ferd
Al suddenly when he that said
Vlyxes out of sleep he brayd
And that was right ayene the day
That longer slepen he ne may
Ayene a man has knowlechyng
Save of him self of all thing
His own chance no man knows
But as fortune it on him throws
Was yet never so wise a Clerk
Which might know al gods werk
Ne the secret which god has set
Ayene a man may not be let
Vlyxes though that he be wise
With all his wit in his auyse
The more that he his sweuen acounteth
The less he wot what it amounts
For all his calculacion
He sees none demonstracion
Al pleynly for to know an end
But netheles how so it wend
He drad him of his own sone
That makes him well ye more astone
And shope thereof anon with all
So that within a castle wall
Thelamon his sone he shette
Till he might know the bette
The sooth / for there he ne knew
Til that fortune him ouerthrewe
But netheles for sykernesse
Where that he might wit and guess
A place strengest in his land
There let he make of lyme and sonde
A strength where he would dwell
Was never man yet herd tell
Of such another as it was
And for to strength him in that cas
Of al his ^onde the sykerest
Of seruanntes and of the worthyest
To keep him within ward
He charged hem they sholden hard
And make such an ordinance
For love ne for acquaintance
That were it erly / were it late
They should beat in at the yate
No mauer man what so betydde
But it so were him self it bydde
But all that might him not auayl^
For whom fortune will assail
There may be no resistance
Which might a man make defense
That al shall be must fall algate
This Cyrces which I spoke of tate
On whom Vlyxes has bigete
A child though he it have foryete
When tym^ came as it was won
She was delyuerd of a son
Which cleped is thelogonus
The child when he was bore thus
About his mother to full age
That he can reason and langage
In good estate was draw forth
And when he was so mochel w^^th
To stand in a man's stead
Circes his mother has him bid
That he shall to his fader go
And told him al to geder tho
What man he was that him began
And when ^lelogonus herd that
Was ware and had full knowlechyng
How that his fader was a king
He prayed his mother fair this
To go where that his fader is
And she him granted that he shall
And made hem ready forth with all
It was that time such vsaunce
That every man the cong^ysaunce
Of his Country bare in his hand
When he went in to strange land
And thus was every man therefore
Well know where that he was bore
For espyall or myst^o wings
They did than such things
That every man may other know
S^o it bifelle in that throw
Thelogonus as in this cas
Of his Contre the sign was
Three fisshes which he should bear
Upon the pynon of a spear
And when he was thus arrayd
And had his harneys all assayd
That he was ready euerydele
His mother bad him fare well
And said him that he should s^ythe
His fader great a thousand ^ythe
Thelogonus his mother ky^^
And took his leave and where he wist
His fader was / the way he name
Til he unto Nachare came
Which of that land the chyef Cite
Was cleped / and there asks he
Where was the king / and how he ferde
And when that he the sooth herd
Where that the king Vlix^s was
Alone upon his ho^s great paas
He rood^ him forth and in his hand
He bare the signal of his land
With fisshes three as I have told
And thus he went in to that hold
Where that his own fader dwells
The cause why he came he tells
Unto the kepars of the gate
And would have cemen in there ate
But shortly they him said nay
And as fair as ever he may
Besought and told hem of this
How that the king his fader is
But they with proud words great
Biganne to manace and threte
But he go fro the gate fast
They would him take and set fast
Fro words unto strokes thus
They fell so that Thelogonus
Was sore hurt and well nyhe deed
But with his sharp speres head
He makes defense how so it fall
And wan the yate upon hem all
And has slain of the best five
And they aseryeden as belyue
Thorugh out the castle al about
On every side men came out
Whereof the kings heart aflyght
And he with all the have yt he might
A spear caught / and out he goes
As he that nyhe was wood and wroth
He saw the yates full of blood
Thelogonus and where he stood
He saw also but he ne knew
What man he was and to him threw
His spear / and he sterte out aside
But desteny which should betyde
Befelle that ylke time so
Thelogonus knew no thing tho
What man it was that to him cast
And whiles his own spear last
With all the sign thereupon
He cast unto the king anon
And smote him with a dedely wound
Vlix^s fell anon to ground
Tho every man the king the king
Began to cry and of this thing
Thelogonus which saw the caas
On knees fell / and seid alas
I have mine own fader slain
Now I would deye wonder fayn^
Now slay me who that ever will
For certes it is right good skylle
He cries he wepeth / he seid therefore
Alas that ever was I bore
That this unhappy destyne
So woefully comes in by me
This king which yet has life ynoug^
His heart ayene unto him drough
And to that voice an ere he leyd
And understood all that he seid
And began to speak and said on high
Bring me this man and when he syghe
Thelogonus his thought he set
Upon the sweuen which he met
And axeth that he might see
His spear / on which the fysshes three
He saw upon a pensel wrought
Tho wist he well / it fails naught
And bad him that he tell should
Fro whens he came and what he would
Thelogonus in sorrow and woo
So as he might told tho
Unto Vlixes all the caas
How that Cyrces his mother was
And so forth seid him every dele
How that his mother great him well
And in what wise she him sent
Tho wist Vlixes what it meant
And took gym in his arms soft
And al bledyng kyst him often
And said sone whiles I live
This infortune I the foryeue
After his other sone in have
He sent and he bigan him has^s
And came unto his fader ty^e
But when he saw him in such plyte
He would have ronnen upon that other
Anon and slain his own brother
Ne had been that Vlixes
Bitwene hem made acord and pe^s
And to his heir thelamacus
He had that he Thelogonus
With all his power should keep
Till he were of his wounds deep
Al hole and than he should him y^^^
Land where upon to live
Thelamacus when he this herd
Unto his fad^^ he answered
And said he would done his will
So dwellen they to geder stylle
These brethren and the fader sterueth
Lo whereof sorcery serves
Thorugh sorcerye his lust he wan
Thorugh sorcery his woe bygan
Thorugh sorcerye his love he chese
Thorugh sorcerye his life he lose
The child was get^ in sorcerye
Which did all this felonye
Thing which was ayene kind wrote
Unkindly it was bought
The child his own fader slough
That was vnkyndeship enough
For thy take heed how that it is
So for to win love amys
Which ends ^l his joy in woe
For all this art I find also
That has be do^ for loves sake
Where thou might ensample take
A great Cronycle Emperyall
Which ever in memoryall
Among the men how so it wend
Shall dwell unto the worlds end

tHe hye Creatoure of things
Which is king of al kings
Full many worlds chance
L^te slide under his sufferaunce
There wot noman the cause why
But he which is al mighty
And that proved whilome thus
When that the king Nectanabus
Which had Egypt for to lead
But for he sey before the deed
Thorugh magyke of his sorcerye
Whereof he couthe a great party
His enemies to him comende
Fro whom he might not him defend
Out of his own land he fled
And in the wise as he him dredde
It fell for all his wytchecraft
So that Egypt was him beraft
And he desguysed fled awey
By ship / and held the right wey
To Macedoyne where that he
Ar^yueth at the chyef Cite
Three yomen of his Chamber there
All only for to serve him were
The which he trusts wonder well
For they were true as any stele
And happens that they with him lad
Part of the best good he had
They took lodgyng in the town
After the disposicioun
Where as him thought best to dwell
He axeth than and herd tell
How that the king was out go
Upon a werre he had tho
But in that cite than was
The queen which Olympias
Was hoote and with solempnyte
The feste of her natyuyte
As it be fell was than hold
And for her lust to biholde
And prayed of the people about
She shope her for to ride out
And after mete al openly
Anon were al men ready
And that was in the Monethe of may
This lusty queen on good array
Was set upon a mule white
To seen it was a great delight
The joy that the Eyte made
With fresshe things and with glade
The noble t^une was al behonged
And every wight was sore alonged
To s^e this lusty lady ride
There was great myrthe on every side
Where as passes by the street
Th^re was full many tymbre beat
And many a maid carolyng
And thus through out yt t^un playeng
This queen unto a pleyne rode
Where that she houed and abode
To see diverse g^me pley
The lusty folk Just and torney
And so forth every other man
Which play couthe / ^is play bigan
To plese with this noble queen
Nectanabus came to the grene
Among other and drough him nyghe
But when that he this lady syghe
And of her beauty head took
He ^^uthe not withdraw his look
To see naught else in the field
But stood / and only her biheld
Of his clothyng and of his chere
He was al vnlyche other there
So that it happens at the last
The queen upon him her eye cast
And knew that he was s^rau^ge anon
But he biheld her ever in one
Without blemysshyng of his cheer
She took good ^ede of h^s manner
And wondreth why he did so
And bad men sheld for him goo
He came and did her reverence
And she axeth in silence
From whom he came and what he would
And he with sobre words told
And seyth madame a Clerk I am
To you and in message I came
The which I may not tellen here
But if it like you to here
It must be said al pryuely
Where none shall be but ye and I
Thus for the time he took his leave
The day goth forth till it was eve
That every man mote let his werk
And she thought ever upon this clerk
What thing it is that he would men's
And in this wise abode the queen
It passes over thylk night
Till it was on the moro we light
She send for him and he came
With him his Astrolahe he name
Which was of fine gold precious
With points and cercles merueylous
And eke the heavenly fygures
Wronght in a book full of peyntures
He took this lady for to show
And told of each of hem by rewe
The course and the condycyon
And she with great affectyon
Sat stylle and herd what he would
And thus when he sees time he told
And feyneth with his words wise
A tale and seyth in such a wise
Madame but a while agoo
Where I was in Egypt tho
And radde in scole of this science
It fell in to my conscience
That I in to the temple went
And there with all my hole intent
As I my sacryfice deed
One of the gods has me ^ed^
That I you warn pryuely
So that ye make you ready
And that ye be no thing agaste
For he such love has to you cast
That ye shall ben his own dear
And he shall be your bedfere
Til ye conceive and be with child
And with that word* she wex al myld^
And somdele bicame for shame
And axrth him that gods name
Which so wol done her company
And he seid amos of luby
And she said that may I not leave
But if I see a better preue
Madame quod Nectanabus
In token that it shall be thus
This night for enformacion
Ye shall hane a vysyon
That Amos shall to you appear
To she we and teache in what maner^
The thing shall afterward befalle
Ye oughten well abouen all
To make joy of such a lord
And when ye be of one acord
He shall a sone of you begete
Which with his swerd shall wyn and get
The wide world in length and bread
Al erthely kings shall him dread
And in such a wise I you behote
The god of the earth he shall be hot
If this be sooth tho quod the queen
This night thou se^^st it shall be seen
And if it fall in to my grace
Of god Amos that I purchase
To take of him so great worship
I wol do the such ladyship
Whereof thou shall for euermo
Be rich / and he thanked her tho
And took his leave / and forth he went
She wist little what he meant
For it was gyle and sorcerye
All that she took for prophecye
Nectanabus thorugh out the day
When he came home where he lay
His chamber with him self took
And ouertorneth many a book
And thorugh the craft of art mage
Of wex he forgeth an image
And looks his equacions
And eke the constellacions
He looks the con^unctions
He looks the recepcions
His signs his hour his ascendent
And dr^weth fortune of his assent
The name of the queen Olimpias
In thylk image written was
A mids in the front above
And thus to win his lust of love
Nectanabus this werk has dyght
And when it came within night
That every wight is fall a sleep
He thought he would his time keep
As he which has his hour appointed
And than first he has anoyn^eed
With sond^y herbs that figure
And thereupon he began conjure
So that thorugh his enchauntement
This lady which was Innocent
And wist no thing of this gyle
Met as she slepte thylke while
How fro the heaven came a light
Which al her chamber made light
And as she looked to and fro
She sey her thought a dragon tho
Whoos scherdes shynen as the son
And has his soft paas begone
With all the chere that he may
Toward the head there she lay
Til he came to the beds side
And she lay stylle and no thing cryde
For he did al his things fair
And was curtoys and debonayre
And as he stood her fast by
His form he thaunged suddenly
And the figure of man he nome
And to her in to her bed he come
And such thing there of love he wrote
Whereof so as her than thought
Thorugh lykyng of this god Amos
With child anon her womb ^roos
And she was wonder glad with all
Nectanabus which causes all
Of this metred the substance
When he sees time his nygromance
He stynt and no thing more seide
Of his carecte and she abreyde
Out of her sleep and leueth well
That it is sooth than enery dele
Of that this Clerk her had told
And was the gladder many fold
In hope of such a glad metrede
Which after shall befalle in deed
She longs sore after the day
That she her sweuen tell may
To this gylour in pryuete
Which knew it as well as she
And netheles on the morrow soon
She left all other things to done
And for him sent and all the caas
She told him pleynly as it was
And said how than well she wist
That she his words might tryst
For she fond her auysyon
Right after the condycyon
Which he her had told tofore
And prayed him hertely therefore
That he her hold couuenaunt
So forth of all the remenaunt
That she may thorugh his ordinance
Toward the god do such plesaunce
That she wakyng might him keep
In such wise as she met in sleep
And he that couthe gyle enough
When he this herd for joy he lough
And said madame it shall be do
But this I warn you thereto
This nyt when that he comes to play
That there be no life in the way
But I that shall at his liking
Ordeyne so for his coming
That ye ne shall of him fail
For this madame I you conusaile
That ye it keep so pryue
That no wight else but we three
Have knowlechyng how that it is
For else might it fare amys
If ye did ought that should him grieve
And thus he makes her to bileue
And fayneth under gyle feyth
But netheles all that he seyth
She troweth. and ayene the night
She has within her chamber dyght
Where as this gyloure fast by
Upon this god shall pryuely
Awayte as ye make her to wene
And thus this noble gentyl queen
When she most trust was deceived
The nyt came the chamber is weyued
Nectanabus has take his place
And when he saw time of space
Thorugh deceyte of his magyke
He put him out of man's like
And of a dragon took he the form
As he which would al conform
To that she saw in sweuen or this
And thus to chamber comen he is
The queen lay a bed and syghe
And hops ever as he came nyghe
That he god of luby were
So that she the less fere
But for he would her more assure
Yet efte he changed his figure
And of a wether the likeness
He took in figure of his noblesse
With large horns for the nones
Of fine gold and precious stones
A Corowne on his head he bare
And sodenlyche or she was ware
As he which all gyle can
His form he turns in to man
And came to bed / and she lay stylle
Where as she suffered all his will
And she which wend not mysdo
But netheles it happened so
Al though she were in part deceived
Yet for all that she has conceived
The worthyest of all the kythe
Which was ever to fore or sith
Of conquest and of Chyualrye
So that thorugh gyle and sorcerye
There was that noble knight bego^ne
Which all the world has after wo^ne
Thus fell the thing which fall should
Nectanabus has that he would
With gyle he has his love spedde
With gyle he came in to the bed
With gyle he goth him out again
He was a shrewed chambyrlayne
So to begyle a worthy queen
And that on him was after seen
But netheles the thing is do
This false god was soon goo
With his deceyte and held him cloos
Till morrow came that he aroos
And tho when time of leyser was
Tho queen told him all the cas
As she that gyle none supposes
And of two points she him opposes
One was if that this god no more
Will come ayene and evermore
How she shall stonden in acord
With king philip her own lord
When he comes home and sees her groan
Madame he seyth let me alone
As for the god I undertake
That when it lyketh you to take
His company at any throw
If I a day to fore it know
He shall be with you on the night
And he his will of such a might
To keep you from al blame
For thy comfort you madame
There shall none other cause be
Thus took he leave / and forth goth he
And tho began he for to muse
How he the queen might excuse
Toward the king of that is fall
And fonnd a craft among all
Through which he has a sefoul dasited

That he flewe forth when it was nyt
Unto the kings tent right
Where that he lay amyddes his host
And when he was a sleep most
With that the sefoull to him brought
Another charm which he wrought
At home within his chamber stylle

And makes him for to dreme and see

Which was between him and ye queen

In sweuen how that the god Amoo

Was set and grave thereupon
A sone in which when he came night

With a prente as he tho met

And sighed for his wives sake

With that he hasted him to rise
Anon and sent after the wise
Among the which there was one
A Clerk his name is Amphyone

And said as sykerly as the life
A god has leyn by thy wife
And get a sone which shall win The world and all that was withynne

So shall the world obey his heestes
Which with his swerd shall all be wo^ne
As far as shyneth any son
The king was doutif of this dome
But netheles when that he come
Again in to his own land

He might not him self stere
That he ne made her heavy chere
But he which couthe of all sorrow

Thorugh the deceyte of Nygromaunce
Took of a dragon the semblaunce

As though they should deye anon

But goth toward the deyse on hye

About his neck ayeneward leyde
And thus the queen with him pleyde
In sight of al men about
And at the last he began to loute
And obeysaunce unto her make
And he that would his leave take
And suddenly his lothely form
In to an egle he began transform
And flewe and set him on a rail
Whereof the king had great marvel
For there he plumeth him and pyketh
As does an hawke when him well
likes And after that him self he shoke
Whereof that all the halle quoke
As it a terremote were
They saiden all god was there
In such a rees and forth he flygh
The king which all this wonder sighe
When he came to his chamber alone
Unto the queen he made his moan
And of foryeuenes he her prayed
For than he knew well as he said
She was with child than with a god
Than was the king without rod
Chastysed and the queen excused
Of that she had been accused
And for the gretter euydence
Yet after that in the presence
Of king philip and of other mo
When they roode in the feldes tho

The which anon as they her seye
Fleyng let an egg down fall
And it to brake among hem all
And as they token thereof keep
They saw out of the shelle crepe
A little serpent out of the ground
Which rampeth al about round
And in ayene it wol have won
But for the brennyng of the son
It might not / and so he deyde
And thereupon the clerks seide
As the serpent when it was out
Went enuyroun the shelle about
And might not torn in again
So shall it fall in certain
This child the world shall enuyroune
And above all to bear the Crown
Him shall befalle in his young age
He shall desire in his courage
When all the world is in his hand
To turn again in to the land
Where he was bore and in his weye
Home ward he shall with poison deye
The king which all this saw and herd
Fro that day forth how so it ferd
His Ielousye has all foryete
But he which has the child beg^ete
Nectanabus in pryuete
The time of his natyuyte
Upon the constellacion
A wayteth and relacion
Makes to the queen how she shall d^
And every hour appoynteth so
That no mynute thereof was lore
So that in due time is bore
This child and forth with thereupon
There fell wondres many one
Of terremote vnyuersell
The son took color of the stele
And left his light / the wyndes blewe
And many strengthes ouerthrewe
The sea his propre kind changed
And all the world his form changed
The thonder with his fyry beuen
So cruel was upon the heaven
That every erthely creature
Tho thought his life in adventure
The tempest at the last seceth
The child is kept his age encreceth
And Alysaunder his name is hot
To whom Calystre and Arystote
To techen him philosophye
Endenden and Astronomye
With other things which he couthe
Also to teache him in his youth
Nectanabus took upon hand
But every man may understand
Of sorcerye how that it wend
It will him self prove at the end
And namely for to begyle
A lady which without gyle
Supposes all that she hereth
But often he that evil stereth
His ship is dreynte therein a mydde
And in this caas right so betydde
Nectauabus upon a night
When it was fair and sterre bright
This young lord lad upon high
Above a tower where as he syghe
The sterres such as he acounteth
He sees what each of hem amounts
And though he knew of al thing
Yet has he no knowlechyng
That shall unto him self befalle
When he has told his words all
This young lord than him opposes
And asks if that he supposes
What death he shall him self deye
He seith or fortune is aweye
And every sterre has lost his won
Or else of mine own son
I shall be slain I may not fle
Thought Alysandre in pryuyte
Hereof this old dotard lies
And or that other ought aspyeth
Al sodenlyche his old bones
He shoof over the wall for the nones
And seyth him / lie down there a part
Whereof now serves al thyn art
Thou know al other men's chance
And of thy self have ygnoraunce
That thou have said among all
Of thy person it is not befalle
Neccanabus which has his death
Yet whiles him lasts life or brethe
To Alysander he spak and said
That he with wrong blame on him leid
Fro point to point and al che cas
He told how he hie son was
Tho he which sorry was enough
Out of the dyche his fader drough
And told his mother how it ferde
In counceyl / and when she it herd
And knew the tokenes which he told
She nyst what she sey should
But stood abashed as for the while
Of his magyke and of his gyle
She thought how she was deceived
That she has of a man conceived
And wend a god it had be
But netheles such degree
So as she might her honor save
She shope the body was begraue
And thus Nectanabus abought
The sorcery which he wrought
Though upon the creatures
Thorugh his carectis and figures
The maystry and the power had
His creator to naught him lad
Again whose law his crafde he uses
When he for lust his god refuses
And took him to the deuyls ^aft
Lo what profit is him belaft
That thing through which he we^de have
sto^de / First him exiled out of land
Which was his own / and from a king
Made him to be an vnderlyng
And sythen to deceive a queen
That torneth him to mochel ^^ne

Incipit liber Septimus
I Genius the priest of love
My sone as you have praid above
That I the scole shall declare
Of Aristotle and eke the fare
Of Alysaundre how he was taught
I am somdele thereof distraught
For it is not the matere
Of love why we sytcen here
To shryue as Menus bad
But nenertheles for it is glad
So as thou see for thyn apryse
To here of such things wise
Whereof thou might the time bliss
So as I can I shall the wysse
For wysedom is at every throw
Above al other thing to know
In loves cause and else where
For thy my sone unto thyn ere
Though it be not in the Regystre
Of Venus / yet of that Calystre
And Aristotle whylome write
To Alysander thou shall wit
But for the lores ben dynerse
I thynk first to the reherce
The nature of the philosophy
Which Aristotle of his clergy
Wise and expert in the seyence
Declared thylke intellygence
As of the points in pryncipalle
Whereof the first in specialle
Is Theoryk / which is grounded
On him which al ye world has founded
Which comprehended all that lore
And for to loken ouermore
Next of seyence the second
Is Rethoryk whoos facounde
Above al other is eloquent
To tell a tale in Judgment
So well can no man speak as he
The last seyence of the three
Is practyke whoos office
The virtue tries fro the vice
And techeth upon good thewes
To slay the company of shrewes
Which stant in disposicion
Of man's fre election
Practyke enformeth eke the rewle
How that a worthy king shall rule
His realm both in werre and pees
Lo this done Aristotle's
These three scyrncrs has divided
And the nature also decydeed
Whereof that each of hem shall serve
The first which is conserve
And kepar of the remenaunt
And that which is most suffysaunt
And chyef of the philosophye
If I thereof shall specyfye
So as the philosophre told
Now harken / and keep that thou it hold

Nota hic de prima planeta que alnes inferior luna dicitur

Bynethe al other stont ye moan
Which has with ye see to done

Upon his change it shall be know

Mo^e in his governance dwell
To weye and wane in his degree

Out take only the moon light
Which is not of him self bright

And yet he has not al full won

De secunda planeta que Mercurius diciture

Of the planetes the second
Above the moon has take his bond
Mercurye and his nature is this
That under him who that bore is
In book he shall be studyous
And in writing curyous
And slouthe and lustles in travail
In thing which else might avail
He loves ese he loves rest
So is he not the worthyest
But yet with somdele business
His heart is set upon richesse
And as in this condycion
The effect and disposicion
Of this planete of his chance
Is most in Burgoyne and in France
De tercia planeta que Venus dicitur

Next to Mercurye as will befalle
Stant the planets which men call
Venus whoos constellacion
Governs all the nation

Is most comune in lumbardye

Nota de quinta planeta que mars dicitur

Mars the planete batayllous

Nota hic de auctoribus illis qui ad Astronomy scienciam pre ceteris studi
oflus intendentes libros super hoc distinctis nominibus composuerunt

The science of Astronomye
Which pryncipalle is of clergy
To deny bitwene woe and well
In things that been naturele
They had a great trauaill on hand
That made it first he understand
And they also which evermore
Her study set upon this lore
They worden gracious and wise
And worthy for to bear a pryse
And whom hit lyketh for to wit
Of hem that this science write
One of the first which it wrote
After Noe it was Nembrote
To his disciple Ychonyton
And made a book forth theru^pon
The which magastre eleped was
Another Auctor in this cas
Is Arachell the which men note
Which a clerk know mote
Dane tholome is not the leest
Which makes the book of alma^^est
And Affraganus does the same
Whoos book Cathenus by name
Gebus and Alpetragus eke
Of palmesta which men seek
The books made / and over this
Full many a worthy clerk is
That written upon the clergy
The books of Aldemetry
Pal nestry and eke also
Which as belonging both two
So as they ben naturyens
Unto these Astronomyens
Men seyn that Abraham was one
Bnt whether that he wrote or none
That find I not and Moses
Eke was another but Hermes
Above al other in this science
He had a great experyence
Thoaigh him were many a sterre assised /
Whoos books ben yet auctorysed
I may not known all tho
That written in the time tho
Of this science / but I find
Of Judgment by wey of kind
That in one point thry al accorden
Of sterees which they recorden
That men may see upon the heaven
There ben a thousand sterres even
And two and twenty to the sight
Which ben of hem self so bright
That men may deem what they be
The nature and the propyrte
Now bast thou herd in such a wise
These noble philosophres wise
Informed this young king
And made him have a knowlechyng
Of thing which first the party
Belongs of philosophye
Which Rethoryke cleped is
As thou to fore have herd or this
But now to speak of the second
Which Aristotle bath so fond
'And techeth how to speak fair
Which is a thing full necessaire
The counterpeyse the balaunce
Where lacks other suffisaunce

Hic tractat de secunda part philosophy / cuius nomen Rethorica facundos
efficit / loquitur eciam de eiusdem duabus speciebus / scilicet gramatica
logica quacum doctrina Rethorica sua verba perornat

Above all erthely creatures
The which maker of natures
The world to man has given alone
So that the speech of his person
Or for to lose or for to win
The hertes thought which is within
May show what it would mean
And that is nowhere else seen
Of kind with none other be
So should he be the more honest
To whom god has so great gift
And look well that he ne shyft
His words to noue wicked bse
For word the techer of vertuse
Io cleped in philosophy
Whereof touching this party
Is Rethoryke the science
Appropred to the reverence
Of words that been reasonable
And for this art shall be vaylable
With goodly words for to like
It has grammar / it has logyke
That seruen both unto the speech
Gramer has first for to teache
To speak upon congruyte
Logyke has eke in his degree
Bitwene the truth and the falshede
The pleyne words for to shede
So that no thing shall goo beside
That he the right shall not decyde
Whereof full many a great debate
Reformed is to good estate
And pees sustained upon lofte
With easy words and with soft
Where strength should let it fall
The philosophre among all
For they commenden this science
Which has the rewle of eloquence
In stone and gras virtue there is
But yet the books tellen this
That word about al erthely things
Is virtuous in his doings
Where so it be euylle or good
For if the words semen good
And ben well spoke at man's ere
When that there is no truth there
They done full often full great deceyte
For when the word to the conceyte
Discordeth in so double wise
Such Rethoryke is to despise
In every place and for to dread
For Plyxes thus I read
And in the book of Troy is found
His eloquence and his faconde
Of goodly words which he told
Has made that Anthenor him sold
The town which he with treson wan
Word has begyled many a man
With word the wyld be is dau^ted
With word the serpent is enchaunted
Of word among the men of arms
Ben wounds heled with the charms
Words ben virtuous and fine
Where lacks other medycyne
Of sorcery the carectes
The words ben of sundry sects
Of euylle and eke of good also
The words maken friend and foo
Of foo a friend and pees of werre
And werre of pees and out of herre
The word the worlds cause entryketh
And reconcyleth whom him lyketh
The word under the cope of heaven
Set every thing or odd or even
With word the hyhe god is plesyd
With word the worlds ben apesed
The soft word the loud stylleth
Where lacks good yt word futfylloth
To make amends for the wrong
When words medlen with the song
It does plesaunce well the more
But for to look upon this lore
How Tullius his Rethoryke
Compouneth there a man may pyke
How that he shall his words set
How he shall loose how he shall knet
And in what wise he shall pronounce
His tale pleyne without frounce
Whereof ensample if thou wylt seche
Take heed and read whi^ome the speech
Nota de eloquencia Iulij in causa Cateline contra Tilenum et alios tunc vrbis
Roman continentes

oF Julius and Cithero
Which consul was of rome tho
Of Caton eke and Tillene
Behold the words hem bit wene
When the treson of Catelyne
Discovered was and the couyne
Of hem that were of his assent
Was know and spoke in parliament
And asked how and in what wise
Men should done hem to Iewyse
Cillenus first his tale told
And as he was to truth behold
The common proufite for to save*
He said treson should have
A cruel death* and thus they speak
The consul both and Caton eke
And saiden that for such a wrong
There may no pain be to strong
But Julius with words wise
His tale told al other wise
As he which would his death respite
And foundeth how he might excyte
The Iuges thorugh his eloquence
Fro death to torn the sentence
And set her hertes to pity
Now told they / now cold he
They speken plain after the law
But he the words of his saw
Colored in another wey
Spekyng / and thus bitwene the swey
To trece upon this Judgment
Made each of hem his argument
Whereof the tales for to lere
There may a man the scole here
Of Rethoryke the eloquence
Which is the second of science
Touching to philosophye
Whereof a man shall justifye
His words in disputacion
And knytt upon conclusion
His argument in such a form
Which may the pleyne troth inform
And the subtle cautele abate
Which every true man shall debate

tHe first which theoryk

Scyences of philosophy
I have hem told as in party
So as the philosophre it told

Tell of the thirdde what it is
The which practyke cleped is
Practyke stant upon three things
To ward the governance of kings
Whereof the first Etyke is named
The whoos seyence stant proclaimed
To trehe of virtue thylke rule
How that a king him self shall rule
Of his moral condition
With worthy disposicion
Of good living in his person
Which is the chyef in his corone
It makes a king also to learn

In mete in drink in clothing eke
There is no wisdom for to seek

Which this science al one
Ne techeth as by wey of kind
That there nothing leave behind

Belongs to Iconomyke
Which techeth thylke honest
Thorugh which a king in his degree
His wife and child shall rule and gy

Which in his household should abide
And his estate on every side
In such manner for to lead
That he his household not myslede
Practyke has yet the thyrdde appryse
Which techeth how and in what wise
Thorugh hyhe purueyed ordinance
A king shall set in gouernannce

Which longs unto regalye

And so forth of the remenaunt

Whoos art is cleped Mathematyke
And though they be not all like
Yet nevertheless how so it fall
One law mote govern hem all

tHe kings question was this
Of things which strengest is
The win the woman or yt king
And that they should upon this thing
Of her answer auysed be
He gaf hem days fully three
And has bihote hem by his feyth
That who so best reason seith
He shall receive a worthy mede
Upon this thing they token head
And studied on disputacion
That they by diverse opinion
Of arguments that they hold
Arphages first his tale told
And said how yt the strength of kings
Is myghtyest of al things
For king has power over man
And man is which reason can
As he which is of his nature
The most noble creature
Of all tho that god has wrought
And by that skylle it seems naught
He seith that any ^rthely thing
May be so mighty as a king
A king may spylle a kyng^e may save
A king may make a lord a knave
And of a knave a lord also
The power of a king stondeth so
That he the laws over passes
What he will make less he it lasseth
What he wol make more he moreth
He sleeth that no man it restores
But he alone al other tameth
Who him displeseth he grameth
And stant him self of law fre
Loo this is a kings might seith he
So as his reason can argue
Is strengest and of most valewe
But Monachas seith other wise
That wine is of the more empryse
And that he shows by this wey
The wine full often takes awey

While that the life her will enbrace
And by this skylle Monachas
Answered has upon this was

Next after truth the second
In polecye as it is found
Which serves to the worlds fame

There may no avarice abrege

Ne which was friend ne which foo

Within hem self the people fond
That it was good to make a king
Which might appesen all this thing

And thus above hem al stood
The king upon his regalye
As he which has to iustefye
The worlds good for couetyse
So sit it well in all wise
A king between more and less

That is to say if that he be
Toward his self large and free

Touching of his condition

IN a cronycle I read thus
Of the rightful lygurgyus
Which of athenes prince was
How he the law in every was
Whereof he should his people rule
Has set upon so good a rule
In all this world that cite none
Of law was so well begone
Forthwith the truth of governance
There was emonge hem no distannce
But every man has his encrees
There was without werre pees
Without envy love stood
Richesse upon the comune good
And not upon the synguler
Ordained was and the power
Of hom that weren in estate
Was sauf whereof upon debate
There stood no thing so that in rest
Might every man his herre rest

Whereof the people stood in ese
He which for ever would plese

How that his law in the cite

And there upon his wit he cast
What thing him were best to sayen
That his purpoos might atteyne
A parlemente and thus he set
His wysdom ^here that he be set

God wot and so ye woten all

To do justice and equity

Whereof that ye ben al glade
It was the god and no thing I

He has commanded of his grace

Which far out in an isle

Which him to speak as he has bid

That ever while ye world shall dwell

That ye me would assure and say

My laws for to keep and hold

That fro that time that he gothe

In every point keep and fulfille

But here now well to what entente

And has been ever and ever shall

Thorough which the hye mageste

I Read in old books thus
There was a due which spertachus
Men cleped and was a wetrour
A cruel man a conqueror
With strong power which he ladde

That they none other good took

That they be fled upon the rage

Unto the good avails
But, ellis oftyme it faylleth
To such as be not well disposed
This tale needs not to be glosed
For it is openly showed
That god to hem that been well thewed
Has give and granted the victory
So that thensaumple of this hystarye
Is good for every king to hold
First in him self that he behold
If he be good of his living
And yt the folk which he shall bring
Be good also for than he may
Be glad of many a^ merry day
In what that ever he has to done
For he which sit above the moon
In all thing may spylle and speed
In every caas and every need
His good king so well he dresseth
That al his foo men he represseth
So that there may no man him dear
And also well he can forbere
And suffer a wicked king to fall
In hands of his foon all

SO as these old gestes seyn
The proud tyrauntee Romayn
T^rquynus which was then king
And wrout many a wro^gful thing

Emenge the which arrous was one
^y^e to his fader of manners
So that within few years
With treson and with tyranny

And token head of no Justice
Which dew was to her office
Upon the rule of governance
But all that ever was ^lesaunce
Unto the flesshes lust they took
And fyl so that they undertook
A werre which was not acheued
But often time he had hem grieved
A^eyn the folk which than hight
The gabyens and al by night
Thus arrous when he was at home
In rome a pryup place he nome

And made him wou^des x or twelfe
Upon the bakke as he was sce^
And so forth with his hurtes grene
In all the haste that he may
He rode and came that other day
Unto gabye the cite
And in he went and when that he
Was know anon the yates was shet
The lords al upon him set
With drawn swerdes in hand
And arrous would hem not withstonde
And said I am here at your will
As lecf it is that ye me spylle
As if mine own fader deed
And forth within that same stead
He prayed hem that they would see
And told hem in what degree
His fader and his bredern both
Which he said weren wroth
Him had beten and reuyled
And out of rome for ever exyl^d
And thus he made hem to believe
And said if that he might a^heue

By so that they him help would
When that the lords herd sayn
How wooful he was besayn
They took pity of his grieve
And yet it was hem wonder ^eue
That rome him had exyled so
This Gabyens by coun^^yl tho

And strength hem with all his might

That he was bathed and anoynte
Till that he was in lusty point
And what he would than he had
That he al hole the cite ladde
Right as he would him self deuyse
And than he thought him in ye whse
He might his tyranny show
And took to his counceyl a shrewe
Whom to his fader forth he sent
And in his message he tho went
And prayed his fader for to say
By his auyse he find a weye
How they might the cite win
While he stood so well therein
And when the messenger was come
To rome and has in counceyl nome
The king it fell perchance so
That they were in a gardyn tho
This messager forth with the king
And when he had told the thing
In what manner that it stood
And that turquynus understood
By the message how that it ferde
Anon he took in hand a yerde
And in the gardyn as they gone
The lyly croppes one and one
Where that they were sprongen out
He smote of as they stood about
And said unto the messengere
Lo this thing which I do now here
Shall be instead of thyn answer
And in this wise as I me bear
Thou shall unto my sone tell
And he no longer would dwell
But took his leave and goes with all
Unto his lord and told him all
How that his fader had do
When arrous herd him tell so
Anon he wist what it mente
And thereto set al his entente
Till he thorugh fraud and trechery^
The princes h^edes of gabye
Has smyten of and al was won
His fader came t^fore the son
In to the town with the romeyns
And took and slew the cyteseyns
Without reason or pyce
That he no spares no degree
And for the speed of this conqueste
He let do make a rich feste
With a solemn sacrefyse
In phoebus temple and in this wise
When the romans assembled were
In presence of hem al there
Upon the auter when al was dygkt
And that the fyres were a light

An hydous serpent openly
Came out and has deuoured^ all

The fyres queynte and forth anon
So as he came so is he gone
In to the deep ground ageyn
And every man began to s^yn
A lord what may this sygnefye
And thereupon they pray and cry
To phoebus that they myt know
The cause and he the same throw
With gastely voys that al it herd
The romans in this wise answerde
And said how for the wickedness
Of pride and of vnrightwysnesse
That tarquyne and his sone has do
The sacrefyse is wasted so
Which might not ben axceptable
Upon such sin abhomynable
And over that yet he hem wysseth
And says which of hem first kysseth
His mother he shall take wreche
Upon the wrong and of that speech
They ben within her hertes glade
Though they no semblaunce made
There was a knyt which buitus hight
And he with all the haste he might
To ground fyl and there kyste
But none of hem the cause wyste
But wend that he had sporned
Perchance and so was turned
But brutus al another mente
For he knew well in his entente
How therthe of every man's kind
Is mother but they weren blind
And saw not so far as he
But when they leften the cite
And comen home to rome ageyn
Than every man which was romeyn
And mother has to her he bend
And kyst and each of hem wend
To be the first upon the chance
Of torquyne for to do vengeance
So as they herden phelus seyn
But every time has his certain
So must it needs then abide
Till afterward upon a tide

tArquinus made vnskylfully
A werre which was fast by
Ageyn a town with walls strong
Which ardea was cleped long
And cast a sege there about
That there may no man pass out
So it befyl upon a night
Arrous which had his souper dyght
A part of the chyualrye
With him to sowpe in company
Has bid and when they comen were
And set at sowper there
Emonge her other words glade
Arrous a great spekyng made
Who had tho the best wife
Of rome and there began a stryf
For arrous says he has the best
So iangle they withouten rest
Till at last one collatyne
A worthy knight and was cosyne
To arrous said him in this wise
It is quoth he of none emprise
To speak a word but of the deed
Thereof it is to take heed
Anon for thy this same tide
Lepe on thy horse and let us ride
So may we know both two
Unawarely what our wives do
And that shall be a true assaye
This arrous says not ones nay
On horsbacke anon they lepte
In such manner and no thing slepte
Rydyng forth till that they come
Al pryuelye within rome
In strange place and down they light
They took a chamber out of sight
They ben dysgysyd for a throw
So that no life should hem know
And to that paleys first they sout
To see what thing this lady wrout
Of which arrous made a vaunte
And they her saw al glad semblau^t
Al full of myrthes and of bordes
But emonge al other words
She spoke not of her husbond
And when they had al understand
Of thylke place what hem list
They gone hem forth that none it wist
Beside thylke yate of bras
Collacea which cleped was
Where collatyn has his dwelling
There founden they at home sittyng
Lncrece his wife al enuyronned
With women which were abandoned
To werche and she wrought also with all

Before my husbondes were
Which with his sword and his spear
Lies at siege in great dysese
And if it should him not dysplese
Now would god I had him here
For certes till that I may here
So^me good tydyng of his estate
My heart is ever upon debate
For so as al men witness
He is of such an hardynesse

With that the water in her eye
Aroos that she ne might stop
And as men seen the dew bedroppe
The leaves and the flowers eke
Right so upon her whyt cheke
The wooful salt teeris fell
When collatyn has herd her tell
The menyng of her true heart
A none with that to her he sterte

Now is he come to yon here
That ye most bouen as ye sayn
And she with goodely chere ageyn
