And the color which erste was pale
To beauty than was restored
So that it might not be mored
The kings sone which was nyghe
And of this lady herd and syghe
The things as they ben befalle
The reason of his wits all
Has lost for love upon his part
Came than and his fyry darte
With such a wound him has y smite
That he must needs feel and wit *
Of thylke blind maladye
To which no cure of surgerye
Can help but yet nethelees
At thylke time he, held his pees
That he no countenance made
But openly with words glade
So as he could in his manner
He spoke and made frendely chere
Till it was time for to go
And collatyne with him also
His leave took so that by night
With all the haste that they might
They ryden to the syege ageyn
But arous was so woo byseyn
With thoutes which upon him ro^ne
That he al by the broad son
To bed goes not for to rest
But for to thenke upon the best
And the fairest forth with all
That ever he saw or ever shall
So as him thought in his courage
Where he portreyed her image
First the fetures of her face
In which nature had al grace
Of womanlye bewte bysette
So that it might not be bette
And how her yelow here was tressed
And her atyre so well adressed

And how she spoke and how she wrout
That he foryeten has no dele
But al it aketh him so well
That in word or in deed
Her lacked nout of womanhede

Was soupled but not half a right

But that he might by sum croke

For where honor is remeuable

Whose other name was claudius
Was gouerrnour of the cite
There fyl a wonder to se
Touching a gentyl maid as thus

Lovers that comen to behold
But most of hem that ^en old
They stoden there that at ylke tyd^
To see what end shall betyde
Upon the cure of my sotye
There might I here great party^
Spe king and each his own aduy^
Has told one that another this
But emonge all this I herd
They weren woo that I so ferde
And sayden that for no ryote
An old man should not asso^^
For as they tolden redyly
There is in him no cause why
But if he would him self be ny^^
So were he well the more nyce
And thus despu^^n sum of tho
And sum ^ayden no thing so
But that the wild loves rage
In man's life forbereth none age
While there is oil for to fire
The lamps be lightly set a fire
And is full hard or it be queynte
But only if it be sum seynte
And thus me thou^t in sundry place
God which prescrueth in his grace
Of hem that walken up and down
There was dy^^rs opinion
And so for a while it last
Till that cupyde at the last
Forthwith his mother full aduysed
Has determined and devised
Unto what point he would descend
And all this time I was lyggende
Upon the ground tofore his eyes
And they that my dysese syen
Supposen not that I should lyuen
But he which would than yeuen
His grace so as it may be
This blind god which may not see
Has groped till that he me fonds
And as he put forth his hand
Upon my body where I lay
Me thought a fyry lau^cegaye
Which whylom thorugh my heart he (...)
He pulls out and also fast
As this was do / cupyde name
His weye I note where he became
And so did all the remenaunte
Which unto him was entendaunt
Of hem that in a vysyon
I had a reuelacion
So as I told now tofore
But venus went not therefore
Ne genyus which thylke time
A^oden both fast byme
And she which may the hertes bind
In loves cause and eke unbind
Or I out of my trance aroos
Venus which held a box cloos
And would not I should deye
Took out more cold then any keye
An oynement and in such apoynte
She has my wounded her^^ anoynte
My temples and my royames also
And forth with all she take me tho
A wonder myrcour for to hold
In which she bad me to behold
And take heed of that I s^ye
Wherein anon my hertes e^^
I cast and saw my color fade
Mine eyes dym and al vnglade
My chekes thynne and al my face
With elde I might see defa^e
So ^yueled and so woo bysayn
That there was no thing full ne plain
I fawe also mine h^^ris hoar
My will was tho to ^ce no more
Therewith for there was no plesaunce
And then in to my remembrance
I drew mine old days passed
And res^n it has compassed
Quod ^^atus hoi^s me^sius a^ni (...)

I made a ^^knesse of my self
Unto the sundry months (...)
Whereof the year in his estate
Is made and stante in no debute
That like to other none accords
For who the times well records
And then at ma^che if he begin
When that the lusty year comes in
Ty^ it be passed septem^re
The mighty yongth he may remember
In which the year has his deduyte
Of gras of flower of corn of f^^yte
Of leef and eke the Wyn grape
And afterward this time is shape
To frost to snow to wind to reyne
Ty^ efte that march be come again
The wyntrr will no summer know
The grene leef is over throw
The clothed ^rthe is than bare
Dyspoyled is the summer fare
Tha^erst was hot is than chele
And thus thynkyng thoughts fel^
I was out of my swo^^e asrayed
Whereof I saw my wits a^trayed
And began to c^^pe hem home ageyn
And when reason it herd seyn
That loves rage was albeye
He came to me the right (...)
And has remenyd the sotye
Of thylke unwise fantasye
Whereof that I was wont to plain
So that of thylke fyry pain
I was made s^bre and hole enough
Venus beheld me then and lough
And ^xeth as it were in game
What love was and I for shame
Ne wist what I should answer
And nethelesse I began to swear
That by my troth I know him neu^t
So far it was out of my thought
Right as it had never be
My good sone tho ^d she
Now at this time I leave it we^e
So goes the fortune of my Whele
For thy my counceyl is thou love
Madame I said by your love
Ye wot well and so do I
That I am un behouely
Your court fxo this day forth to seru^
And for I may no thonke deserve
And also for I am refused
I pray you to ben excused
And nethelees as for the last
While that my wits has me^ last
Tow^hyng my confession
I axe an absolucion
Of genyus or that I goo
The prcest anon was ready the
And said sone as of thy shryfte
Thou have full pardon and full yefte
Foryete it thou and so will I
My holy fader grant mercy
Quod I to him and to the queen
I fyl on knees upon the grene
And took my love for to wend
But she that would make an end
As thereto which was most able
A pay^e of ^edes black as sable
She took and hynge mine neck about
Upon the gaudees al without
Was write of gold pur reposere
^o thus she said Johan gowere
Now thou a^te at last cast
Thus have I for thy ^^as cast
That thou of love no more seche
But my will is that thou beseech
And pray^ herafter for the pees
And that thou make a pleyn relees
To love which takes l^tel head
Of old men upon the need
When that the lusts ^en albeye
For thy to the nys but one weye
For which reason be thy ^yde
For he may sone him self mysgyde
That sees not the pery^^e tofore
My sone be well were therefore
And keep the sentence of my lore
And tarry thou my court no more
But goo there moralle virtue dwells
Where ben thy books as m^n tells
Which of long time thou have write
For this I do the well to wit
If thou thyn hele will purchase
Thou might not make such a chase
Where that the game is not prouable
It were a thing unreasonable
A ^^an to be so ouerseye
For thy take heed of that I seye
For in the law of my commune
We be not shapen to comune
Thy self and I never after this
Now have I said all that there is
Of love as for thy fynal end
A dew for I mo^e fro the wend
And great well chau^^^ when ye me^e
As my discyple and my poet
For in the (...) of his youth
In sundry wise a^ he well couthe
Of dy^ees and of songs glade
The which he for my sake made
The bond fulfilled is over all
Whereof to him in specyalle
Above al other I am most hold
For thy now in his days old
Thou shall him tell this message
That (...) upon his latter age
To set an end of al his work
As he which is mine own clerk
Do make his testament of love
As thou have done thy shryfte about
So that my court it may record
Madame I can me well accord
Quod I to tell as ye me ^ydde
And with that word it so betydde
Out of sight al sodeynlye
Enclosed in a sterred sky
Venus which is the queen of love
Was take in to her place above
More wist I not where she bycam
And thus of her my leave I nam
And forth with all the same ty^e
Her priest which would not abide
Or me be leef or me be booth
Out of my sight forth he gooth
And I was left withouten help
So wist I not whereof to yelpe
But that only I had lore
My time / and was sorry therefore
And thus bywhaped in my thought
When al was turned in to naught
I stood amassed for a while
And in my self I began to smyle
Thynkyng upon the bedes ^lake
And how they were me betake
For that I should bid and pray
And when I saw none other way
But only that I was refused
Unto the life which I had used
I thought never to torn ageyn
And in this Wise soth to sayn
Homewarde a soft paas I went
Where as with all mine hole entente
Upon the point that I am shryue
I think to bydde while I live
Marce precor xpriste populus quo gau det iste / Anglia ne triste subeat rex
sum resist / Corrige quosque fragiles absolve reatus / vnde deo gratus
vigeat ^ocus iste beatus

hE which within days seven
This large world forthwith the heaven
Of his eternal prouydence
Has maad / and thylke intellygence
In man's soul reasonable
Has shape to be perdurable
Whereof the ^an of his feture
Above al erthely creature
After the soul is inmortal
To thylke lord in special
As he which is of al things
The creator and of the kings
Has the fortunes upon hand
His grace and mercy for to fond
Upon my bare knees I preye
That he this land in syker weye
Will set upon good governance
For if men taken remembrance
What is to live in unity
There is no state in his degree
That n^ ought to desire pees
Without which it is no lees
To seche and look in to the last
There may no worlds joy last
First for to look the clergy
Hem ought well to iustefye
Thing which bylongeth to their cure
As for to pray and to pro^^re
Our pees toward the heaven above
And eke to set rest and love
Emonge us on this earth here
For if they wrought in this manner
After the rule of charity
I hope that men sholden see
This land amended and over this
To seche and look how it is
Touchend of the chyualrye
Which for to look in sum party
Is worthy for to be commendyd
And in sum part to ^e amended
That of her large retenue
The land is full of meyntenue
Which causes that common right
In few contrees stand up ^ight
Extorcyon / contek / rauyne
Withholde ben of that couyne
Al day men here great compleynte
Of the disease of the constreynte
Whereof the people is sore oppressyd
God grant it mote be redressyd
For of knyghthode thordre would
That they deffende and keep should
The common right and the fraunchyse
Of holy church in all wise
So that no wicked man it dear
And thereof serves shield and spear
But for it goes now other weye
Our grace goes the more aweye
And for to ^oken ouermore
Whereof the people pleynen sore
Toward the laws of our land
Men say yt troth has broke his bo^de
And with brocage is goon aweye
So that no man can see the weye
Where for to find rightwisnesse
And if men seek sykernesse
Upon the lucre of marchandye
Compassement and trycherye
Of synguler prouffyte to win
Men sayn is cause of mochel sin
And namely of dyuysyoun
Which many a noble town
Fro welthe and fro prosperyte
Has brought to great aduersyte
So were it good to be allone
For mochel grace thereupon
Unto the cytees should fall
Which might avail to us all
If these estates amended were
So that the virtues stoden there
And that the vices were aweye
Me thinks I durst then seye
This lands grace should arise
But yet to look in other wise
There is astate as ye shall here
Above al other on earth here
Which has the land in his balaunce
To him bylongeth the lygeaunce
Of clerk of knight of man of law
Under his hand al is forth draw
The merchant and the laborer
So stante it al in his power
Or for to spylle or for to save
But though he such power have
And that his myghtes be so large
He has hem naught without charge
To which that every king is swore
So were it good that he therefore
First unto the rightwysnes entende
Whereof that he him self amend
Toward his god and leave vice
Which is the chyef of his office
And after all the remenaunt
He shall upon his covenant
Govern and led in such a wise
So that there be no tyrannyse
Whereof that he his people grieve
Or ellis may he naught acheue
That longs to his regalye
For if a king will Iustefye
His land and hem that ^en within
First at him self he must begin
To keep and rule his own estate
That in him self be no debute
Toward his god for otherwise
There may none erthely king suffyse
Of his kingdom the folk to lead
But he the king of heaven dread
For what king set him upon pride
Ad takes his lust on every side
And will not goo the right weye
Though god his grace cast aweye
No wondre is / for at last
He shall well wit it may not last
The pomp which he secheth here
But what king with humble chere
After the law of god escheweth
The vices / and the virtues selveth
His grace shall be suffysauunt
To govern all the remenaunte
Which longs to his duete
So that in his prosperity
The people shall not be oppressyd
Whereof his name shall be blessed
For ever and be memoryalle
And now to speak as in fynalle
Tolbchyng that I undertook
In english for to make a book
Which stante between ernest and game
I have it made as thylke same
Which axe for to be excused
And that my book be not refused
Of lered men when they it see
For lack of curyosyte
For thylke scole of eboquence
Bylongeth not to my science
Upon the form of rethorike
My words for to peynte and pyke
As tullyus sometime wrote
But this I know and thus I wot
That I have done my true pain
With rude words and with pleyne
In all that ever I couthe and might
This book to write as I behyght
So as sekenes it suffer would
And also for my days old
That I am feeble and Impotente
I wot not how the world is went
So pray I to my lords all
Now in mine age how so byfalle
That I mote stonden in their grace
For though me lack to purchase
Her worthy thank as by deserte
Yet the symplesse of my pouerte
Desires for to do plesaunce
To hem under whose governance
I hope spker to abide
But now upon my last tide
That I this book have made and write
My muse does me for to wit
And says it shall be for my best
Fro thie day ferth to take rest
That I no more of love make
Which many a horte has overtake
And ouertorned as the blind
Fro reason in to salbe of kind
Where as the wysdem goes aweye
And can not see the right weye
How to govern his own estate
But every day stante in debate
Within him self and can not leave
And thus for thy my synal leave
I take now for evermore
Without making any more
Of love and of his dedely hele
Which no physycyen can hele
For his nature is so diverse
That it has ever sum trauers
Or of to much or of to lyte
That plainly may no man delight
For him fails or that or this
But thylke love which that is
Within a man's heart affermed
And stante of charity conformed
Such love is goodly for to have
Such love may the body save
Such love may the selvle amend
The high god such love us send
Forthwith the remenaunte of grace
So that above in thylke place
Where rests love and al pees
Our joy may be endelees
Amen
